mt0: <pad> The Editors' Group said this was "very disturbing" because it showed the divisions of journalists within and between countries.</s>

en: "In 2022, it's really undeniable that media polarization and information chaos are really fueling social divisions in ways that are pretty new," said Clayton Weimers, deputy director of RSF for the United States, told VOA. He said the prevalence of partisan news around the world has come at the expense of authentic journalism.
nya: "M'chaka cha 2022, sitingatsutse kuti kugawanikana pakati pa wofalitsa nkhani komanso chisokonezo pa mauthenga ndi zomwe zikusokoneza maubale mu njia zatsopano," a ClaytonWeimers , wachiwiri kwa mkulu wa RSF ku United States anawuza VOA. Iwo anati kuchuluka kwa nkhani zokomera mbali imodzi padziko lonse kwabisa utolankhani weniweni.
mt0: <pad> "In 2022, we cannot deny that divisions among journalists and misinformation are the new challenges for relations," Clayton Weimers, vice president of RSF in the United States told VOA. He said the globalization of biased news has obscured true journalistic work.</s>

en: The group's annual report ranks 180 countries based on the environment for independent journalism. This year, however, RSF said it used a new method that blends each country's political, legal, economic, sociocultural and security conditions.
nya: Lipoti la pachaka la gululi lili ndi ndandanda wa mayiko 180 kutengera ndi mmene wolemba nkhani amagwilira ntchito. Chaka chino, RSF yati yagwiritsa ntchito njira yatsopano yomwe ikuphatikiza kayendetsedwe ka ndale, malamulo, chuma, maubale komanso chitetezo cha dziko lililonse
mt0: <pad> The RSF's annual report lists 180 countries according to the journalist's work. This year, RSF used a new methodology that combines politics, law, economics, relations and security of each country.</s>

en: Now, the index classifies a record 28 countries as "having very bad media freedom." That group includes China, which is exporting censorship beyond its borders while also amplifying the Kremlin's propaganda on Russia's devastating war against Ukraine.
nya: Ndandandayu wapeza kuti mayiko 28 samapereka ufulu kwa wofalitsa nkhani. Dziko la China ndi limodzi mwa mayiko omwe ali m'gululi pamene likulamula wolemba nkhani ngakhale a m'mayiko ena komanso kupitiliza kuyipitsa mbiri ya ku Kremlin pa nkhondo ya ku Russia ndi Ukraine.
mt0: <pad> The list found 28 countries that do not provide press freedom. China is one of the countries that are in this group as it continues to control even foreign journalists and keeps smearing the Kremlin's reputation in the war between Russia and Ukraine.</s>

en: Russia, China among worst
nya: Russia ndi China ali pakati pa mayiko oyipitsitsa
mt0: <pad> Russia and China are among the most corrupt countries in the world.</s>

en: Since its invasion of Ukraine on February 24, Russia has sought total control over news coverage, passing a new law that carries 15-year prison terms for reporting "false news" on the military, and even forbids calling the conflict a "war."
nya: Kuchokera 24 February pomwe dziko la Russia linalowa mu dziko la Ukraine mwa upandu, dziko la Russia likulamula nkhani zoyenera kulembedwa pobweretsa lamulo loti wolemba nkhani zabodza zokhudza asilikari akakhala kundende kwa zaka khumi ndi zisanu. Dziko la Russia likukananso kutchula kusagwirizanaku kuti ndi nkhondo.
mt0: <pad> From 24 February when Russia invaded Ukraine by force, Russia has been controlling press coverage by introducing a law that will jail anyone who reports false information about the military for 15 years. Russia also refuses to call the conflict a war.</s>

en: That has forced most remaining independent news outlets, including the renowned Novaya Gazeta newspaper, Ekho Moskvy radio and Dozhd TV, to shut down or move outside Russia to continue operating.
nya: Izi zachititsa kuti nyumba zowulutsa mawu komanso nyuzipepala zoyima pazokha kuphatikizapo nyuzipepala yotchuka ya Novaya Gazeta, wayileis ya Ekho Moskvy ndi kanema wa Dozhd zitseke ma ofesi awo kapena kusamuka ku Russia kuti akapitilire kugwira ntchito yawo.
mt0: <pad> This has caused a number of independent media organizations and newspapers including the popular Novaya Gazeta, radio station Ekho Moskvy and TV channel Dozhd to close their offices or move out of Russia to continue their work.</s>

en: With independent voices absent, experts say, the Russian government has been able to flood state-run airwaves with propaganda that downplays the war and spreads false or misleading justifications for the Kremlin's invasion.
nya: Popanda nyumba zowulutsa mawu zoyima pazokha, dziko la Russia likufalitsa nkhani zosokoneza makamaka pa upandu wa ku Kremlin kudzera m'ma wayilesi oyendetsedwa ndi boma.
mt0: <pad> Without independent media, Russia is propagating misinformation mainly on Kremlin conspiracy through state-run radio stations.</s>

en: Russia's media repression stands at 155 out of 180 countries included in RSF's index, where one is the most free and 180 the least.
nya: Kuzunzidwa kwa wofalitsa nkhani kwapangitsa kuti dziko la Russia likhale pa nambala 155 pa mayiko 180 omwe ali pa ndandanda wa RSF. Pa nambala yoyamba pali dziko lomwe limapereka ufulu wonse kwa atola nkhani pamene pa nambala 180 pali dziko lomwe silipereka ufulu wonse.
mt0: <pad> The persecution of journalists has placed Russia at the 155th place in the RSF list of 180 countries. The first is a country that provides full freedom to journalists and the 180th is a country that does not provide full freedom to journalists.</s>

en: "It's safe to say at this point that the free press is a thing of the past in Russia," Clayton said.
nya: "Pakali panopa tikhoza kunena kuti ufulu wa atolankhani ku Russia ndi mbiri yakale," anatero a Clayton.
mt0: <pad> "Right now we can say that freedom of the press in Russia is history," Clayton said.</s>

en: Throughout Russian President Vladimir Putin's 22 years in power, Moscow has been targeting journalists and the independent press, he said.
nya: Mu ulamuliro wa zaka 22 wa pulezidenti wa ku Russia, Vladimir Putin, Moscow yakhala ikulimbana ndi wolemba nkhani komanso atola nkhani omwe si a boma.
mt0: <pad> During the 22 years of the presidency of Russian President Vladimir Putin, Moscow has been battling journalists and independent media.</s>

en: "But since the invasion of Ukraine, it seems that Putin has really finished off the independent media once and for all in Russia," Clayton said. "At this point, it is impossible to accurately report on the war in Ukraine."
nya: "Kuchokera pomwe dziko la Russia linalowa m'dziko la Ukraine mwa upandu, zikuwonetsa kuti a Putin athana ndi nyumba zonse zowulutsa mawu zoyima pazokha ku Russia," anatero a Clayton. "Panopa ndi zosatheka kutulutsa lipoti lolondola lokhudza nkhondo ya ku Ukraine."
mt0: <pad> "Since the invasion of Ukraine, it has been clear that Putin has destroyed all independent media in Russia," Clayton said. "This makes it impossible to provide a credible report on the conflict in Ukraine."</s>

en: China ranked 175th in the new report. And now that it is firmly under Beijing's influence, Hong Kong also registered a dramatic decline, ranking 148th out of 180 following a lengthy series of raids and arrests that shuttered pro-democracy news sites.
nya: Dziko la China lili pa nambala 175 mu lipoti latsopano. Kutengera zomwe zikuchitika ku Beijing, Hong Kong nayo yatsika pa ndandandawu kufika pa nambala 148 mwa 180 kutsatira ziwawa zomwe zakhala zikuchitika kwa nthawi yaitali komanso kumangidwa kwa anthu zomwe zachititsa kuti malo atsopano ogwirizana ndi ulamuliro wa demokalase atsekedwe.
mt0: <pad> China is ranked 175th in the new report. Hong Kong has also fallen down the list to 148th out of 180 after long-running violence and arrests that have led to the closure of the new pro-democracy centers in Hong Kong.</s>

en: RSF's country file on China says it is the world's biggest jailer of journalists, with 120 in detention. The regime uses coercion, harassment, intimidation and surveillance to keep independent and foreign journalists from reporting on issues deemed "sensitive."
nya: RSF, mu lipoti la sabata iliyonse yati, pa mayiko onse, dziko la China ndi lomwe limapititsa atolankhani ambiri kundende. Pakali pano atolankhani 120 ali kundende. Ulamulirowu umagwiritsa ntchito mphamvu, nkhanza, kuopseza komanso kuwonetsetsa kuti atolankhani omwe si a boma komanso a kunja sakulemba nkhani zokhudzana ndi zomwe zikuchitika.
mt0: <pad> RSF, in its weekly report, said that China is the country with the most journalists imprisoned. At present 120 journalists are in jail. The government uses power, brutality, intimidation and ensures that non-state and international journalists don't report on the events.</s>

en: "President Xi Jinping, in power since 2013, has restored a media culture worthy of the Maoist era, in which freely accessing information has become a crime and to provide information an even greater crime," RSF's country file states.
nya: Pulezidenti Xi Jinping, yemwe wakhala pampando kuchoka m'chaka cha 2013, wabwezeretsa ulamuliro wakale wa mu nthawi ya Maoist pamene kupeza nkhani ndi mlandu ndipo kupereka uthenga ndi mlandu wawukulu, lipoti la sabata la RSF latero.
mt0: <pad> President Xi Jinping, who has been in power since 2013, has restored the old Maoist style of leadership by finding and prosecuting and punishing those who are responsible for serious crimes, a weekly RSF report later said.</s>

en: Rising authoritarianism
nya: Kukula kwa ulamuliro wankhanza.
mt0: <pad> The rise of a brutal dictatorship</s>

en: North Korea remains the worst country in the rankings at 180th. Elsewhere in the Asia-Pacific region, political turmoil, conflict and rising authoritarianism have wiped out years of progress.
nya: Dziko la North Korea ndi lomwe lili pamapeto pa nambala 180. Mbali ina ya chigawo cha Asia-Pacific, chisokonezo pankhani zandale, kusamvana komanso kukula kwa ulamuliro wa chipani chimodzi ndi zomwe zikubwezeretsa chitukuko m'mbuyo.
mt0: <pad> North Korea is the last country on the list at number 180. In the rest of Asia-Pacific region, political unrest, instability and the rise of one-party rule are causing development to lag behind.</s>

en: The 2021 coup in Myanmar marked a 10-year setback for media rights, with journalists detained, media licenses revoked, and many news outlets returning to exile. Under the military junta, Myanmar, ranking 176th, is one of the world's biggest jailers of journalists.
nya: Kulanda boma mwaupandu komwe kunachitika ku Myanmar mu 2021 kwawonetsa kuti kwa zaka khumi tsopano ufulu wa wofalitsa nkhani unabwerera m'mbuyo pamene atolankhani ena anamangidwa, wofalitsa nkhani kuletsedwa kugwiritsa ntchito ziphaso zawo komanso nyumba zowulutsila mawu zina zinathawa m'dzikomo. Pansi pa ulamuliro wa asilikari a jinta, Myanmar ili pa nambala 176 ndipo ndi limodzi mwa omwe amapititsa atolankhani ambiri kundende.
mt0: <pad> The military coup in Myanmar in 2021 has shown that for the first time in 10 years, press freedom has been backed down as journalists were arrested, journalists were banned from using their passports and some media houses fled the country. Under thejunta, Myanmar is ranked 176th and one of the most jailed journalists in the world.</s>

en: In Afghanistan, the Taliban insurgents pledged to uphold press freedom when they took power in August 2021. Instead, RSF said the "Taliban's seizure of power has further worsened conditions for reporters and news organizations, who are the targets of all forms of intimidation and violence." Afghanistan ranked 154th.
nya: Zigawenga za Taliban ku Afghanistan zinalonjeza kuti zikadzatenga boma mu August 2021, ufulu wa atolankhani udzalemekezedwa. Koma RSF yati kutenga boma kwa Taliban kwawonjezera mavuto a atolankhani komanso mabungwe a wofalitsa nkhani omwe akuchitidwa chipongwe ndi upandu. Dziko la Afghanistani lili pa nambala 154.
mt0: <pad> The Taliban in Afghanistan have promised to respect press freedom after they take over in August 2021.</s>

en: Across Africa, laws criminalizing online journalism have dealt a new blow to the right to information, RSF said, while the spread of rumors, propaganda, and disinformation has contributed to undermine access to quality information.
nya: Mu Africa, malamulo otsegulira mulandu utolankhani wa pa intaneti akutsekereza ufulu wopeza uthenga mu Africa, inatero RSF, pamene kufala kwa mphekesera, nkhani zabodza ndi kuyipitsirana mbiri kukuchititsa kuti kupeza uthenga woyenera kuzivuta.
mt0: <pad> In Africa, the spread of rumors, fake news and gossip is making access to reliable information difficult, the RSF said, while the proliferation of rumors, fake news and gossip is making access to reliable information difficult.</s>

en: In Ethiopia, the war in the Tigray region, with its communication blackouts and restricted access, were the main factors that placed the country 114 on the index. Neighboring Eritrea and Djibouti are far worse, ranking near the bottom at 179 and 164, respectively.
nya: Nkhondo ya m'chigawo cha Tigray ku Ethiopia komanso kutsekereza mapezedwe a mauthenga ndi komwe kwapangitsa kuti dzikoli likhale pa nambala 114 pa ndandanda. Mayiko oyandikana nawo a Eritrea ndi Djibouti alinso kumapeto pa ndandandawu pomwe ali pa nambala 179 ndi 164.
mt0: <pad> The Tigray region war in Ethiopia and the media censorship have caused the country to be ranked 114th on the list. Eritrea and Djibouti are also in the bottom of the list with 179th and 164th respectively.</s>

en: African media continue to struggle economically, RSF said it its accompanying analysis.
nya: Wofalitsa nkhani a mu Africa akupitilira kukumana ndi mavuto a zachuma, inatero RSF potsatira kafukufuku wawo.
mt0: <pad> African journalists continue to face financial difficulties, the RSF said after its research.</s>

en: "Despite a wave of liberalization in the 1990s, there are still, too often, cases of arbitrary censorship, especially on the internet, with occasional network shutdowns in some countries, arrests of journalists and violent attacks," the group said.
nya: "Ngakhale panali ufulu mu zaka za mma 1990, pali nkhani zomwe zikuchitika zokhudza kulamulila wofalitsa nkhani, makamaka pa intaneti pamene kawirikawiri netiweki zikutsekedwa m'mayiko ena, atolankhani akumangidwa komanso kuchitidwa upandu," linatero gululi.
mt0: <pad> "Even though there was some freedom in the 1990s, there are problems with media control, particularly online where networks are often blocked in other countries, journalists are arrested and harassed," the group said.</s>

en: Clayton said the rising authoritarianism feeds on itself.
nya: A Clayton ati palibe chomwe chikuyambitsa ulamuliro wankhanza.
mt0: <pad> Clayton and nothing is causing the brutal rule.</s>

en: "When we allow a culture of impunity to exist where authoritarians are allowed to go after journalists, harass them, arrest them, beat them in the streets and kill them, it has a knock-on effect," he said. "It emboldens that same authoritarian to do it again next time, and it emboldens other authoritarians who are watching to do the same."
nya: "Tikamapanda kupereka chilango kwa akuluakulu omwe amalimbana ndi atolankhani powachita nkhanza, kuwamanga, kuwamenya m'misewu komanso kuwapha zotsatira zake ndi zoti akuluakuluwa azichita izi mobwereza-bwereza ndipo alimbikitsa akuluakulu ena kuchita chimodzimodzi," iwo anatero.
mt0: <pad> "If we don't punish those who abusively, arrest, beat and kill journalists, the result is that they will continue to do it and will inspire other officials to do the same," they said.</s>

en: US not perfect
nya: US nayo ili ndi mavuto ake
mt0: <pad> US also has problems.</s>

en: After a period of seeing its media attacked as "fake news" by former President Donald Trump, the United States retained a relatively high ranking of 42 in RSF's index. That is largely thanks to the return of regular White House and federal agency press briefings.
nya: Patapita nthawi pamene pulezidenti wakale, a Donald Trump, anati wofalitsa nkhani amafalitsa nkhani zabodza, dziko la United States likafika pa nambala 42 mu ndandanda wa RSF. Izi zachitika kamba ka misonkhano ya atolankhani yomwe imachitika-chitika yofotokoza zochitika  ku White House ndi nthambi za boma.
mt0: <pad> After the former president, Donald Trump, said journalists were "fake news," the United States has gone up to 42th on the RSF list. This is due to the frequent press conferences held by the White House and other government agencies to discuss events at the White House and other government agencies.</s>

en: But RSF said problems persist, including "the disappearance of local newspapers, the systematic polarization of the media, and the erosion of journalism by digital platforms amid a climate of animosity and aggression toward journalists, among others."
nya: Koma RSF yati mavuto alipobe monga nyuzipepala zina kuasiya kugwira ntchito, kugawanika kwa wofalitsa nkhani komanso intaneti kutenga malo a utolankhani pamene udani ndi kuzunzidwa kwa atolankani zikupitilira.
mt0: <pad> But the RSF said problems remained, such as some newspapers closing, media divisions and the internet taking over the role of journalism while violence and harassment of journalists continued.</s>

en: Barriers exist, for instance, when it comes to covering state governments and protests.
nya: Zotchinga zimadza panthawi yofuna kufalitsa uthenga wa zochitika ku boma komanso zionetsero.
mt0: <pad> The walls are closed during times of government events and protests.</s>

en: "We typically find that this is either due to just a blatant disregard for the laws governing open records or meetings, or they're simply misinterpreting them. An individual is misinterpreting whether a journalist can be present at a particular event," said Beth Francesco, senior director of the National Press Club Journalism Institute.
nya: "Timapeza kuti izi zimachitika chifukwa chosasamala kapena kutanthauzira molakwika malamulo obweretsa poyera misonkhano. Munthu akhoza kusamvetsa kuti atolankhani akuyenera kupezeka pa zochitika zina," a Beth Francesco, mkulu wa National Press Club Journalism Institute ndiwo ananeza izi.
mt0: <pad> "We found that this happens because of inaction or misinterpretation of the rules on meetings. One may not understand that journalists are allowed to attend other events," said Beth Francesco, director of the National Press Club Journalism Institute.</s>

en: A few bright spots
nya: Pali chiyembekezo.
mt0: <pad> There is hope.</s>

en: Despite an overall trend of decline, Clayton said there are positives.
nya: Ngakhale pali kubwelera m'mbuyo, a Clayton ati pali chiyembekezo.
mt0: <pad> Although Clayton and there is hope, there is hope.</s>

en: Some governments provide funding for news media without interfering in their operations, to ensure independence from political influence.
nya: Ma boma ena amapereka thandizo la chuma kwa wofalitsa nkhani opanda kulowelera kagwiridwe ka ntchito yawo kuti wofalitsa nkhaniwa akhale oyima pawokha, osaphatikiza ntchito yawo ndi ndale.
mt0: <pad> Some governments provide financial support to media without meddling in their operations to ensure that the media remain independent, not linked to politics.</s>

en: "If you look at the top of our list, some of the things that stand out are these are countries that have robust public funding for media," he said, noting that "it's always important to separate state funding for media and state-controlled media."
nya: "Mukayang'ana pa ndandanda wathu mupeza kuti mayiko omwe amathanziza wofalitsa nkhani pa chuma ndi omwe ali patsogolo," iwo anatinso, "ndikofunika kukhala ndi thumba lothandiza wofalitsa nkhani oyima pawokha komanso a boma."
mt0: <pad> "You can see from our list that countries that support media are the ones that are ahead," they said, "it is important to have a fund for both independent and government media."</s>

en: Three Scandinavian countries — Norway, Denmark and Sweden — respectively come at the top of RSF's index. Estonia, a former Soviet Union republic, ranked 4th.
nya: Mayiko atatu a mtundu wa chi German - Norway, Denmark ndi Sweden - ndi omwe akutsogolera ndandanda wa RSF. Dziko la Estonia lomwe linali mu Soviet Union ndi lomwe lili pa nambala yachinayi.
mt0: <pad> Three German-speaking countries - Norway, Denmark and Sweden - are leading the RSF list. The former Soviet Union country Estonia is on the fourth place.</s>

en: RSF said the free exercise of journalism plays a major role in emerging democracies such as East Timor, ranked 17, Bhutan, ranked 33, and Mongolia, ranked 90.
nya: RSF yati kuchita utolankhani mwaufulu kumatenga gawo lalikulu poyambitsa ulamuliro wa demokalase monga dziko la East Timo lomwe lili pa nambala 17, dziko la Bhutan panambala 33 ndi dziko la Mongolia pa nambala 90.
mt0: <pad> RSF says that free press plays an important role in promoting democracy in East Timor, ranked 17th, Bhutan at 33rd and Mongolia at 90th.</s>

en: East Timor was one country whose ranking skyrocketed, rising 54 places. But RSF cautioned that because of its change in methodology this year, "care should be taken when comparing the 2022 rankings and scores with those from 2021."
nya: East Timor ndi limodzi mwa mayiko omwe anakwera pa ndandandawu ndi malo 54. RSF yachenjeza kuti kamba ka kusintha mmachitidwe a zinthu, ndi pofunika kusamala pofananitsa ndandanda wa 2022 ndi wa 2021.
mt0: <pad> East Timor is one of the countries that have risen in the rankings with a 54th place. RSF warns that due to the change in the system, it is important to be careful when comparing the 2022 and 2021 rankings.</s>

en: UN’s Guterres Meets with Nigerian Leaders After Visiting Volatile Borno State
nya: Mlembi wa UN akumana ndi atsogoleri a ku Nigeria atayendera ku Borno State komwe kunachitika za upandu.
mt0: <pad> UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon met with Nigerian leaders after visiting the Borno State where violence broke out.</s>

en: U.N. Secretary General Antonio Guterres met with Nigerian leaders Wednesday at the end of a two-day visit to Nigeria and three-nation trip to Africa. On Tuesday, he visited internally displaced people (IDPs) in northeast Nigeria and called for them to be safely returned to their homes. Nigerian authorities plan to close all IDP camps in the next few years despite security concerns.  Antonio Guterres arrived the United Nations house in Abuja around 9 a.m. Wednesday and met with U.N. local coordinators before holding talks with Nigerian womens representatives.
nya: Mlembi wa U.N a Antonio Guterres anakumana ndi atsogoleri a ku Nigeria lachitatu pamene anali paulendo woyendera dziko la Nigeria kwa masiku awiri komanso mayiko atatu a mu Africa. Lachiwiri, mlembiyu anayendera anthu omwe anathawa kwawo, Internally Displaced People (IDPs,) ndipo wapempha kuti anthuwa abwelere kwawo alibwino. Akuluakulu a ku Nigeria ali ndi chikonzero chofuna kutseka malo onse omwe anthu othawa kwawo amakhala ngakhale kuti izi zikhoza kuyika miyoyo yawo pachiopsezo. Antonio Guterres anafika kunyumba ya United Nations ku Abuja lachitatu nthawi ya 9 koloko m'mawa ndipo anayamba kukumana ndi oyang'anira UN asanayankhule ndi nthumwi ya azimayi ku Nigeria.
mt0: <pad> UN Secretary General Antonio Guterres met with Nigerian leaders on Wednesday as he was on a two-day visit to the country and three other African countries. On Tuesday, Guterres visited IDP camps and urged them to return safely. The Nigerian authorities have been trying to close all refugee camps despite the risk of putting their lives at risk.</s>

en: The delegates, led by Nigeria's minister for womens affairs, Pauline Kedem Tallen, discussed gender equality and the inclusion of women in politics with the U.N. secretary-general.
nya: Mnthumwizi motsogozedwa ndi nduna yowona za azimayi a Pauline Kedem Tallen, anakambirana ndi mlembi wa U.N za kusasiyanitsa pakati pa amayi ndi abambo komanso ubwino wophatikiza azimayi pandale.
mt0: <pad> The delegation, led by the minister of women Pauline Kedem Tallen, spoke to the UN secretary general about gender disparity and the need to include women in politics.</s>

en: "His coming to Nigeria today has given us hope, because we know that he will lend his voice to all the issues affecting women, gender-based violence, early marriage, lack of implementation of some of our laws," said Tallen.
nya: "Kubwera kwawo kwatipatsa chiyembekezo chifukwa tikudziwa kuti atiyankhulira pa nkhani zokhudza azimayi monga nkhanza zochitira amayi, kukwatiwa nsanga komanso kusagwiritsa ntchito malamulo ena," anatero a Tallen.
mt0: <pad> "Their arrival gives us hope because we know they will speak up for women's issues such as childbirth, childbirth and other issues," said Tallen.</s>

en: Guterres afterwards met with Nigeria's religious leaders and later attended a wreath-laying ceremony at the U.N. house to remember the 23 people killed during the 2011 bombing of the building.
nya: A Guterres anakumananso ndi atsogoleri a mipingo ku Nigeria komanso anakhala nawo pa mwambo woyika nkhata ku nyumba ya U.N pokumbukita anthu 23 omwe anafa bomba litaphulitsidwa pa nyumbayi.
mt0: <pad> Guterres also met with religious leaders in Nigeria and attended a ceremony to commemorate the 23 people who died in the UN building bomb blast.</s>

en: He began his three-nation Africa visit Sunday in Senegal as part of his Ramadan solidarity tour, and later went to Niger.
nya: Iwo anayamba ulendo wawo woyendera mayiko atatu a mu Africa lamulungu ndipo anayambira kupita ku Senegal ngati gawo la mwambo wa Ramadan kenako anapita ku Niger.
mt0: <pad> They began their trip to three African countries on Sunday and started in Senegal as part of the Ramadan festival then went to Niger.</s>

en: On Tuesday, he visited northeastern Borno state and met with the state governor as well as IDPs and families impacted by the Boko Haram conflict.
nya: Lachiwiri, iwo anayendera kumadzulo kwa chigawo cha kumpoto ku Borno State komwe anakumana ndi ma gavanala, IDPs komanso maanja onse omwe anakhudzidwa ndi ziwawa za Boko Haram.
mt0: <pad> On Tuesday, they visited the western part of the north-western region of Borno State where they met with officials, IDPs and all families affected by Boko Haram's conflict.</s>

en: Guterres also visited repentant Boko Haram fighters and praised authorities' reintegration program for more than 1,000 former fighters.
nya: A Guterres anayenderanso anthu omwe anatuluka m'gulu la Boko Haram ndipo ayamikira akuluakulu a pologalamu yobwezeretsa anthuwa chifukwa cha anthu oposera 1000 omwe anatuluka m'gulili.
mt0: <pad> Guterres also visited the refugees of Boko Haram and praised the officials of the repatriation program for over 1,000 people who have been repatriated.</s>

en: He also commended authorities efforts to resettle displaced people back to their communities and called for more support to rebuild the region.  "The Borno that I found today is the Borno of hope, the Borno with future and I was very impressed to see the policy that is being deployed here, recognizing that you don't fight terrorism just by military means, you fight terrorism addressing the root causes of terrorism," he said. "The people that I met today in the IDP camps want to go back home in safety and dignity. The way to address terrorism effectively is to provide not only hope but a future of reality."
nya: Iwo ayamikiranso akuluakulu kamba koyesetsa kubwezeretsa anthu omwe anathawa kwawo ndipo apempha thandizo kuti amangenso mzindawu. "Borno yemwe ndampeza lero ndi wodzala ndi chiyembekezo komanso ali ndi tsogolo. Ndasangalala ndi malamulo omwe akugwiritsidwa ntchito pozindikira kuti sitimathana ndi ziwawa pochita nkhondo koma pothana ndi chomwe chimayambitsa ziwawazo," iwo antero. "Anthu omwe ndakumana nawo lero ku malo osungirako anthu othawa kwawo akufuna kubwerera kwawo mwaulemu komanso alibwino. Njira imodzi yofuna kuthana ndi ziwawa si kupereka chiyembekezo chokha komatsogolo lenileni."
mt0: <pad> They also thanked the government for its efforts to rebuild Borno.</s>

en: Nigerian authorities have been closing IDP camps since late last year and want to close all camps by 2026. More than 2 million people have been displaced from their homes since the start of the Boko Haram insurgency in 2009.
nya: Akuluakulu a ku Nigeria akhala akutseka malo osungirako anthu othawa kwawo kuyambira ku mapeto a chaka chatha ndipo akufuna kuti pofika m'chaka cha 2026 malo onsewa adzakhale atatsekedwa. Anthu oposa 2 miliyoni anathawa kwawo kuchoka m'chaka cha 2009 pomwe ziwawa za Boko Haram zinayamba.
mt0: <pad> Nigerian authorities have been closing refugee camps since the end of last year and hope to close all by 2026. Over 2 million people fled their homes in 2009 when Boko Haram began fighting.</s>

en: But aid groups have been warning some communities may still be attacked.
nya: Magulu osamalira anthu achenjeza kuti madera ena akhonza kuchitidwabe chiwembu.
mt0: <pad> Rights groups warn that other areas may still be at risk.</s>

en: "There are multiple solutions when it comes to resettlement. We need to get people stabilized," said Adenike Oladosu, a climate justice activist, met with the U.N. secretary-general. "Climate change is leading to the rise of armed conflicts affecting people in the region and around and the need for us to see that we have more climate action and not always military action."
nya: "Pali njira zambiri pofuna kuthana ndi kusamuka. Anthu akuyenera kukhazikika," a Adenike Oladosu, omwe ndi womenyera ufulu wa chilengedwe, ananena izi atakumana ndi mlembi wa U.N. "Kusintha kwa nyengo ndi komwe kukubweretsa kusagwirizana  komwe kumakhudza anthu choncho tikuyenera kuzindikira kuti tikuyenera kuchitapo kanthu pa kusintha kwa nyengo osati pa ziwawa zokha."
mt0: <pad> "There are many ways to deal with the displacement. People need to be stable," Adenike Oladosu, an environmental rights activist, said after meeting with the UN's spokesman. "Climate change is causing the disagreements that affect people so we need to realize that we have to act on climate change not just on violent conflicts," he said.</s>

en: The U.N. secretary-general ended his visit at the Abuja presidential village, where he met with President Muhammadu Buhari and his top Cabinet members.
nya: Mlembi wa U.N anamaliza ulendo wake poyendera mudzi wa pulezidenti komwe anakumana ndi pulezidenti Muhammadu Buhari ndi akuluakulu ake a boma ku Abuja.
mt0: <pad> The UN Secretary General ended his visit by visiting the president's village where he met with President Muhammadu Buhari and his government officials in Abuja.</s>

en: Al-Shabab Raids African Union Military Base
nya: Al-Shabab iwukira maziko a asilikali a African Union.
mt0: <pad> Al-Shabab attacked a base of the African Union troops in Somalia.</s>

en: Al-Shabab fighters stormed an African Union military base in the village of El-Baraf in Somalias Middle Shabelle region early Tuesday, local officials and security sources say.
nya: Lachiwiri mmawa gulu la Al-Shabab linakasokoneza malo omwe asilikari a African Union akukhala m'mudzi wa El-Baraf, pakati pa chigawo cha Shabelle, adindo a m'mudziwu ndi achitetezo ndiwo ananena izi.
mt0: <pad> Tuesday morning Al-Shabab militants attacked the camp of African Union troops in El-Baraf, in the central Shabelle region, local and security officials said.</s>

en: Officials told VOA Somali that the militants briefly seized the base before withdrawing from it. State media said Burundian solders at the base repulsed the attack.
nya: Adindo awuza VOA Somali kuti zigawengazi sizinakhalitse pamalowa. Wofalitsa nkhani a boma ati asilikari a ku Burundi omwe anali pamalowa anathawa.
mt0: <pad> Adindo told VOA Somali that the earthquakes did not hit the site. The government journalist and Burundian soldiers were evacuated.</s>

en: "The Federal Government of Somalia condemns in the strongest possible terms the heinous attack targeting the African Union Transition Mission in Somalia forward operating base in Elbaraf, Middle Shabelle," the Somali Ministry of Foreign Affairs posted on its official Facebook page.
nya: "Boma la ku Somalia likudzudzula mtchitidwe woyipa wolimbana ndi asilikari a African Union Transition Mission ku Somalia omwe akukhala ku Elbaraf, pakati pa Shabelle," unduna woona zakunja ku Somalia unanena izi pa tsamba lawo la mchezo la Facebook.
mt0: <pad> "Somalia bomb blasts a criminal attack on the African Union transition mission in Somalia troops based in Elbaraf, central Shabelle," the Somali ministry of foreign affairs said on their Facebook page.</s>

en: "We extend our deepest condolences to the victims of this terrorist attack and their families."
nya: "Tikupepesa onse omwe akhudzidwa ndi ziwawazi komanso mabanja awo."
mt0: <pad> "We apologize to all those affected by the violence and their families.</s>

en: The Mayor of El-Baraf, Abdullahi Haji Muhumed, said the militants started their attack with two suicide truck bombs. He said the militants then fought their way onto the base.
nya: Mfumu ya mzinda wa El-Baraf, a Abdullahi Haji Muhumed, ati zigawengazi zinayamba upanduwu pophulitsa mabomba awiri kenako kupita komwe kunali asilikari.
mt0: <pad> The chief of the city of El-Baraf, Abdullahi Haji Muhumed, and the militants began the violence by blowing up two bombs and then marching towards a military post.</s>

en: Al-Shabab claimed the killing of 173 African Union forces. The group also claimed responsibility for capturing AU forces as prisoners-of-war. Both claims could not be independently verified. AU force headquarters and Somali military officials could not be immediately reached for comment.
nya: Al-Shabab yati inapha asilikari 173 a African Union. Gululi lavomerezanso kuti ndilo linagwira asilikari a AU kuti akhale akaidi awo owathandizira kumenya nkhondo, koma izi sizinatsimikizidwe. Likulu la asilikari a AU komanso adindo a asilikari a ku Somali sanapezeke kuti ayankhulepo pa nkhaniyi.
mt0: <pad> Al-Shabab says it has killed 173 African Union soldiers. The group also admitted that it held AU soldiers as hostages, but this has not been confirmed. The headquarters of the AU forces and the Somali military have not yet responded to the allegation.</s>

en: In an interview with VOA, Muhumed, who was not at the village at the time of the attack, said he was told there were "many deaths" among Burundian forces but could not give an exact figure.
nya: Poyankhula ndi VOA, a Muhumed ati iwo sanali m'mudzimu pamene ziwawazi zimachitika. Iwo ati, "inali nkondo yoopsa."
mt0: <pad> Speaking with VOA, Mr. Muhumed said they were not in the house when the violence occurred. He said, "It was a terrible fight."</s>

en: "Fighting like this never happened in this area," he said. "It was heavy fighting."
nya: "Sitinaonepo nkhondo ngati imeneyi," iwo anatero. "Inali nkhondo yayikulu."
mt0: <pad> "We've never seen a war like this," they said. "It was a great war."</s>

en: He said two civilians were also killed and more than 10 others injured.
nya: Iwo anati anthu awiri anaphedwa ndipo ena oposera khumi anavulazidwa.
mt0: <pad> They said two people were killed and over 10 injured.</s>

en: Muhumed confirmed to VOA that al-Shabab militants withdrew from the base. He also reported airstrikes targeting the militants as they left the base but did not say who was responsible for the strikes.
nya: A Muhumed atsimikizira VOA kuti zigawenga za Al-Shabab zinachokadi kumalowa. Iwo anenanso kuti panthawi yomwe zigawengazi zimachoka pamalopa, panali ndege zomwe zimawalondola koma sanatchule mwini wa ndegezo.
mt0: <pad> Muhumed confirmed to VOA that the Al-Shabab militants had left the camp. He also said that when the militants were leaving the camp, there were aircraft following them but did not name the aircraft's owner.</s>

en: El-Baraf, approximately 150 kilometers north of Mogadishu, is one of the forward operating bases of African Union forces from Burundi.
nya: El-Baraf, yomwe ili pafupifupi makilomita 150 kumpoto kwa Mogadishu, ndi limodzi la madera omwe asilikari a African Union ochokera ku Burundi amakhalako.
mt0: <pad> El-Baraf, which is about 150 kilometers north of Mogadishu, is one of the bases of the African Union forces from Burundi.</s>

en: The incident marked the first major al-Shabab attack on AU forces since the mission changed its name and operational structures last month.
nya: Aka kanali koyamba kuti Al-Shabab ichite zaupandu kwa asilikari a AU kuchokera nthawi yomwe AU inasintha dzina komanso magwiridwe ake a ntchito mwezi watha.
mt0: <pad> This is the first time that Al-Shabab has launched a terrorist attack on AU troops since the AU changed its name and mission last month.</s>

en: The U.N. Security Council, which authorized the new mission called the African Union Transition Mission in Somalia (ATMIS), gives it a mandate to reduce the threat posed by al-Shabab, support the capacity-building of Somali security forces, and conduct a phased handover of security responsibilities to Somalia. The mission has until the end of 2024 to operate in the country.
nya: Khonsolo ya chitetezo ya U.N, yomwe inapereka chilolezo kwa bungwe latsopano la African Union Transition Mission in Somalia (ATMIS), lapereka ulamuliro kwa bungweli kuti lichepetse ziopsezo za Al-Shabab, kuthandiza kuwonjezera chiwerengero cha asilikari a ku Somalia komanso kusiya udindo wachitetezo mmanja mwa dziko la Somalia. Bungweli likhala likugwira ntchito m'dzikomo mpaka kumapeto kwa chaka cha 2024.
mt0: <pad> The UN Security Council, which authorized the new African Union Transition Mission in Somalia (ATMIS), has given the mission the power to reduce the Al-Shabab threat, help boost the number of Somali troops and transfer security responsibility to the Somali people. The mission will stay in the country until the end of 2024.</s>

en: India’s Muslims Mark Eid al-Fitr Amid Community Violence
nya: Asilamu a ku India achita chikondwelero cha Eid al-Fitr nthawi ya ziwawa.
mt0: <pad> Muslims in India celebrated Eid al-Fitr during the riots.</s>

en: Muslims across India marked Eid al-Fitr on Tuesday by offering prayers outside mosques, even as the celebrations this year came in the backdrop of a series of recent attacks against the community during the month of Ramadan.
nya: Asilamu m'dziko la India amakondwelera Eid al-Fitr lachiwiri pochita mapemphero panja pa mizikiti yawo ngakhalekuti chikondwerelo cha chaka chino chinali ndi zovuta zake kutsatira zachiwembu zomwe zinachitika m'derali m'mwezi wa Ramadan.
mt0: <pad> Muslims in India celebrate Eid al-Fitr on Tuesday by praying outside their mosques despite the difficulty of this year's festival after the attacks that occurred in the region during Ramadan.</s>

en: "We will not have the same kind of festivity" this time, said Mohammad Habeeb ur Rehman, a civil engineer in Indias financial capital, Mumbai. "This is the most painful Eid with worst memories for Indian Muslims."
nya: "Sitidzakhalanso ndi chikondwelero cha mtundu wotere," a Mohammad Habeeb ur Rehman, omwe amagwira ntchito yoyang'anira mamangwidwe a zinthu ku Mumbai ndiwo ananena izi. "Eid imeneyi ndiyowawa chifukwa ikukumbutsa asilamu a ku India zomwe zinachitika."
mt0: <pad> "We will never have such a festival again," said Mohammad Habeeb ur Rehman, an administrator in Mumbai. "This Eid is sad because it reminds Indian Muslims what happened."</s>

en: Anti-Muslim sentiment and attacks have surged across the country in the last month, including stone throwing between Hindu and Muslim groups during religious processions and subsequent demolitions of a number of properties mostly belonging to Muslims by authorities.
nya: Kudana ndi asilamu komanso ziwembu zakhala zikuchitika m'dzikoli mwezi watha kuphatikizapo kugendana miyala pakati pa anthu a mtundu wa chi Hindu ndi magulu a asilamu mapemphero ali nkati komanso akuluakulu kugwetsa nyumba za asilamu
mt0: <pad> Islamic hatred and violence have been taking place in the country for the past month including stone-throwing between Hindus and Muslims inside mosques and officials destroying islamic houses.</s>

en: The community, which makes up 14% of Indias 1.4 billion population, is reeling from vilification by hard-line Hindu nationalists who have long espoused an anti-Muslim stance. Some leaders of Indias ruling Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party have tacitly supported the violence, while Prime Minister Narendra Modi has so far been silent about it. Eid al-Fitr is typically marked with communal prayers, celebratory gatherings around festive meals and new clothes, but celebrations in India for the past two years have been marred by COVID-19 restrictions.
nya: Anthu 14 pa 100 aliwonse mu chiwerengero cha anthu 1.4 billion a ku India amachokera m'derali. Anthu a mtundu wa chi Hindu akhala akuyipitsa mbiri ya derali kamba koti amadana ndi asilamu. Atsogoleri a chipani cholamula cha Bharatiya Janata, chomwe ndi cha anthu a mtundu wa chi Hindu, akuthandizira nawo ziwawazi mwakachetechete pamene pulezidenti Narendra Modi sanayankhulepo kanthu pankhaniyi. Pokondwerela Eid al-Fitr, pamakhala mapemphero, maphwando komanso zovala zatsopano koma mu zaka ziwiri zapitazi, mwambowu wakhala ukusokonekera kamba ka ziletso za COVID-19 ku India.
mt0: <pad> 14 per cent of India's 1.4 billion people come from the state of Uttar Pradesh. Hindus have always been negatively associated with the state for its history of anti-Islam.</s>

en: In Indian-controlled Kashmir, the Muslim festival has been subdued for the past three years because of an unprecedented military lockdown after India stripped the regions semi-autonomy in 2019, followed by the pandemic. The region also saw a rise in violence during Ramadan, with at least 20 militants, two civilians and five police and soldiers killed.
nya: Mwambo wa asilamu ku India wa Kashmir wakhala usakuchitika kwa zaka zitatu zapitazo kamba ka ziletso zomwe zinabwera pofuna kupewa mliri wa COVID-19. Ziwawa zambiri zinachitika panthawi ya Ramadan pomwe zigawenga makumi awiri, anthu awiri, apolisi asanu komanso asilikari anaphedwa.
mt0: <pad> The annual Muslim festival in Indian Kashmir has been cancelled for the last three years due to the bans imposed to prevent the COVID-19 pandemic. Most of the violence occurred during Ramadan when 20 militants, two civilians, five policemen and five soldiers were killed.</s>

en: "As we prepare to celebrate Eid, a strong sense of collective loss jars at us," said Bashir Ahmed, a businessman in Srinagar.
nya: "Pamene tikukonzekera kusangalala mwambo wa Eid, tikumakhala ndi chikumbumtima cha imfa," anatero a Bashir Ahmed wochita malonda ku Srinagar.
mt0: <pad> "When we prepare to celebrate Eid, we feel the memory of death," said Bashir Ahmed, a businessman in Srinagar.</s>

en: Kashmir is the Muslim-majority disputed region where a violent insurgency against Indian rule and New Delhis brutal crackdown has raged for over three decades. Tens of thousands of people have died in the conflict.
nya: Kashmir ndi chigawo chomwe chili ndi asilamu ochuluka, komwenso kwakhala kuli ziwawa zowukira ulamuliro wa ku India, komanso kuchitiridwa nkhanza kwa mzinda wa New Delhi kwa zaka zoposa makumi atatu.
mt0: <pad> Kashmir is a Muslim-majority region, where there have been riots against Indian rule, and the siege of New Delhi for over 30 years.</s>

en: Meanwhile in the capital, New Delhi, hundreds assembled in the Jama Masjid, one of Indias largest mosques, while offering Eid prayers there for the first time in over two years due to pandemic restrictions. Families came together early on Tuesday morning while many people shared hugs and wishes.
nya: Izi zili chomwechi, anthu mazana mazana anasonkhana ku umodzi mwa mizikiti yayikulu ku India, ku Jama ku New Delhi, kuchita mapemphero a Eid koyamba mu zaka ziwiri kamba ka ziletso za mliri wa COVID-19. Mabanja anabwera pamodzi lachiwiri mmawa ndipo kunali kukumbatirana ndi kuuzana zofuna.
mt0: <pad> However, hundreds of people gathered at one of the biggest mosques in India, Jama in New Delhi, for the first Eid prayers in two years because of the coronavirus restrictions. Families came together on Tuesday morning and there were hugging and wishing each other good luck.</s>

en: Beijing Residents Brace for COVID-19 Lockdown
nya: Anthu okhala ku Beijing akonzekera m'bidikiro wa COVID-19.
mt0: <pad> Beijing residents are preparing for the start of COVID-19.</s>

en: Unlike Shanghai, Beijing has yet to require that all its residents remain at home to contain the spread of COVID-19. Nevertheless, many people in its Chaoyang district and elsewhere are preparing for that possibility.
nya: Kusiyana ndi ku Shanghai, okhala ku Beijing akuyenera kukhala kunyumba kuti apewe kufala kwa COVID-19. Komabe anthu ambiri okhala m'boma la Chaoyang ndi kwina konse akukonzekera chiletsochi.
mt0: <pad> Unlike Shanghai, residents in Beijing are required to stay at home to prevent the spread of COVID-19. However many residents in Chaoyang and elsewhere are preparing for the protest.</s>

en: On Wednesday, city officials closed 60 subway stations, more than 10% of Beijing's vast system. They did not say when service would be resumed, according to ABC News.
nya: Lachitatu, adindo a mzindawu anatseka malo 60 okwelera sitima omwe amatenga 10% ya gawo ya zinthu zochitika ku Beijing. ABC News yati akuluakuluwa sananene nthawi yomwe malowa adzapitilire kugwira ntchito.
mt0: <pad> On Wednesday, Beijing officials closed 60 train stations that make up 10% of the city's transport system. ABC News reported that the officials did not specify when the stations will reopen.</s>

en: Beijing, a city of 21 million people, has been on high alert for the spread of COVID-19, as restaurants and bars pivot to takeout, gyms close and schools suspend classes indefinitely, according to CNBC.
nya: Beijing, mzinda womwe uli ndi anthu 21 miliyoni, uli tcheru pofuna kupewa kufala kwa COVID-19 pamene malo ogulitsa zakudya ndi malo omwera mowa sakulola ogula awo kudyera kapena kumwera mowa pamalo pomwepo. Malo olimbitsirako thupi komanso sukulu zatsekedwa kaye, CNBC yatero.
mt0: <pad> Beijing, a city of 21 million people, is taking measures to prevent the spread of COVID-19 as restaurants and bars don't allow customers to eat or drink on-site. Gyms and schools have been closed for a while.</s>

en: People who live in "controlled" areas, neighborhoods where cases have been discovered, have been told to stay in the city, and all residents must test for the virus three times throughout the week, according to ABC.
nya: Anthu amene akukhala malo amene kwapezeka odwala COVID-19 ndi malo ena ozungulira, awuzidwa kuti akhalebe mumzindawu ndipo akayezetse ngati ali ndi matendawa katatu msabatayi, ABC yatero.
mt0: <pad> People who live near a COVID-19 case and other nearby areas are being urged to stay in the city and get tests three times a week, ABC reported.</s>

en: Chinese authorities reported 5,489 cases nationwide on Wednesday, of which 4,982 were in Shanghai, which has been under a draconian lockdown for weeks.
nya: Akuluakulu a ku China ati pa anthu 5,489 omwe apezeka ndi COVID-19 m'dzikomo, anthu 4,982 anali ku Shanghai, dera lomwe anthu analetsedwa kuyenda kwa ma sabata angapo tsopano.
mt0: <pad> China officials said that of the 5,489 confirmed cases of COVID-19 in the country, 4,982 were in Shanghai, a city which has been under travel bans for several weeks.</s>

en: Beijing reported 46 symptomatic cases and five asymptomatic on Wednesday. The city's total since April 22, what it considers the start of its omicron outbreak, is 544.
nya: Anthu 46 a ku Beijing ndi amene amaonetsa zizindikiro za matendawa pamene anthu asanu samawonetsa zizindikiro zilizonse lachitatu. Kuchokera pa 22 April, kwa nthawi yoyamba mzindawu unapeza kuti anthu 544 akudwala mtundu wina wa COVID-19 wotchedwa omicron.
mt0: <pad> Beijing is the most affected city, with 46 people showing symptoms of the disease while five people showing no symptoms at all. As of 22 April, for the first time the city has identified 544 people with a different type of COVID-19 called omicron.</s>

en: Mr. Zhang, a Beijing resident, said he had bought extra food and water, even though he doesn't think Beijing will be locked down like Shanghai. He asked that VOA not use his full name because he was afraid of attracting official attention.
nya: Bambo Zhang omwe amakhala ku Beijing ati anaguliratu zakudya ndi madzi zoonjezera ngakhale sakuganiza kuti akhoza kuletsedwa kuyenda ngati ku Shanghai. Iwo anapempha VOA kuti isagwiritse ntchito dzina lawo lonse kuopa adindo a m'dzikoli.
mt0: <pad> Mr. Zhang, who lives in Beijing, said he had bought enough food and water to last himself a week, although he did not think he would be able to travel as freely as in Shanghai. They asked VOA not to use their full names for fear of the Chinese government.</s>

en: "I have six bags of rice, two bags of noodles, and several boxes of water, instant noodles and (nutritionally dense) biscuits, and I haven't stocked up too much," Zhang told VOA Mandarin in a phone interview last week. He said he bought his groceries online because the supermarket was crowded.
nya: "Ndili ndi matumba asanu ndi limodzi a mpunga, matumba awiri a ma noodles, mabotolo angapo a madzi ndi mabisiketi osapatsa nthanzi. Sindinasunge zinthu zambiri," a Zhang anawuza VOA Mandarin pa lamya sabata yatha. Iwo anati anagula katundu wawo kudzela pa intaneti chifukwa misika inali yodzadza.
mt0: <pad> "I have eight bags of rice, two bags of noodles, a few water bottles and some snacks," Zhang said on the radio last week.</s>

en: Ms. Yao, who lives in the Chaoyang district, told VOA Mandarin that she had been stocking up on necessities since the beginning of this year, after the Ministry of Commerce recommended that everyone do so. She asked that VOA Mandarin not use her full name because she wanted to avoid official retribution.
nya: A Yao omwe amakhala m'boma la Chaoyang, awuza VOA Mandarin kuti akhala akusunga zonse zofunika kuchokera kumayambiliro a chaka chino pamene unduna wa za kugula ndi kugulitsa unachejeza aliyense kutero. Iwo anapempha VOA Mandarin kuti isagwiritse ntchito dzina lawo lonse kuopa kulangidwa ndi adindo.
mt0: <pad> Yao, who lives in Chaoyang, told VOA Mandarin that they have been keeping all their documents since early this year when the ministry of trade and industry warned everyone not to do so.</s>

en: "I have always maintained a good habit of reserving food. So I have a lot of rice, noodles and oil at home," she said, adding that she figured her family would be fine even if Beijing locked down for a month.
nya: "Ndinazolowera kusunga chakudya, kotero ndili ndi mpunga wambiri, ma noodles ndi mafuta ophikira kunyumba," iwo anatero, kuwonjezera kuti atati aletsedwe kuyenda ku Beijing, banja lawo silingasowe kanthu kwa mwezi wathunthu.
mt0: <pad> "I'm used to keeping food, so I have plenty of rice, noodles and oil at home," they said, adding that after they were banned from traveling to Beijing, their family would not have had any food for a whole month.</s>

en: And while Beijing has not yet closed the city, citizens' lives have been disrupted.
nya: Ngakhale kuti mzinda wa Beijing sunatsekedwe, miyoyo ya anthu yasokonezeka.
mt0: <pad> Although Beijing wasn't closed down, people's lives were affected.</s>

en: On April 28, the Beijing Chaoyang District Maternal and Child Health Care Hospital issued a notice that the outpatient and emergency departments of the hospital would suspend the admission of patients.
nya: Pa 28 Epulo, chipatala cha amayi ndi ana ku Beijing, m'boma la Chaoyang chinalengeza kuti odwala mwadzidzidzi ndi omwe matenda awo ndi ochepa asiya kugonekedwa pachipatalapo.
mt0: <pad> On 28 April, the Beijing Maternity and Childbirth Hospital in Chaoyang County announced that emergency and minor illnesses were no longer admitted to the hospital.</s>

en: On the same day, Chaoyang Hospital, one of the largest hospitals in Beijing, announced on its official Weibo account that its emergency department would also suspend the admission of patients. Weibo is China's equivalent of Twitter.
nya: Pa tsiku lomwelo, chipatala cha Chaoyang chomwe ndi chimodzi mwa zipatala zazikulu ku Beijing, chinalengezanso pa tsamba lawo la Weibo kuti akhozanso kusiya kugoneka odwala  mwadzidzidzi. Weibo ili ngati tsamba la mchezo la Twitter ku China.
mt0: <pad> On the same day, Chaoyang Hospital, one of the biggest hospitals in Beijing, also announced on their Weibo page that they were closing emergency department. Weibo is like Twitter in China.</s>

en: Angry Chinese netizens left more than 800 messages under the official WeChat account "Beijing Headline."
nya: Anthu okwiya ogwiritsa ntchito intaneti ku China anasiya mauthenga oposa 800 pa tsamba la WeChat pa "zochitika ku Beijing."
mt0: <pad> China's angry internet users left over 800 comments on WeChat about "the Beijing events."</s>

en: "Why do you stop the emergency room as soon as there is a new COVID case, and how many people will be killed due to the secondary disaster caused by the COVID?" a netizen asked in a Weibo post.
nya: "Ndi chifukwa chani mukutseka malo othandizira odwala mwadzidzidzi pamene kwapezeka ena odwala COVID ndipo ndi anthu angati amene angamwalire kamba zotsatira za ngozi yoyambitsidwa ndi COVID?" wogwiritsa ntchito intaneti anafunsa pa tsamba la Weibo.
mt0: <pad> "Why are you closing hospitals when there are new COVID patients and how many people can die as a result of the COVID disaster?" an internet user asked on Weibo.</s>

en: Some Beijing residents said they were not worried about a Shanghai-like lockdown.
nya: Ena okhala ku Beijng ati sakudandaula ndi kuletsedwa kuyenda ngati ku Shanghai.
mt0: <pad> Some Beijing residents are not complaining about the same traffic restrictions as in Shanghai.</s>

en: "Basically, I'm not afraid," said Mr. Wang, who asked VOA Mandarin to not use his full name so he could avoid attracting authorities' attention. "The party, government and military are here, and the people are here."
nya: "Poyamba ine sindikuwopa," anatero bambo Wang omwe anapempha VOA Mandarin kuti isagwiritse ntchito dzina lawo lonse kuwopa akuluakulu. "Chipani, boma ndi asilikari ali pano, anthunso ali pompano."
mt0: <pad> "I wasn't afraid at first," said Mr Wang, who asked VOA Mandarin not to use his full name to scare the authorities. "But now I am afraid," he said.</s>

en: However, Wang told VOA Mandarin, in mid-October last year, after one person in his apartment building was diagnosed as positive, about 600 people from more than 200 families were forced into isolation at several hotels in the Changping district for 21 days.
nya: Komabe a Wang awuza VOA Mandarin kuti pakati pa mwezi wa October chaka chatha, munthu mmodzi atapezeka ndi COVID ku imodzi mwa nyumba zomwe amakhala, anthu 600 ochokera ku mabanja oposera 200, anakakamizidwa kudzipatula pokhala ku ma hotela m'boma la Changping kwa masiku 21.
mt0: <pad> But Wang told VOA Mandarin that in mid-October last year, after a COVID-19 case was confirmed in one of his housing units, 600 people from 200 families were forced to self-isolate in hotels in Changping County for 21 days.</s>

en: Wang and his wife were not allowed to share a room at their hotel.
nya: A Wang ndi akazi awo sanali ololedwa kugona chipinda chimodzi.
mt0: <pad> Wang and his wife were not allowed to sleep in the same room.</s>

en: What particularly puzzled and annoyed Wang was that on the last day of the mandatory hotel quarantine, in addition to routine nasal and oral swabs during testing, authorities added anal swabs to the regimen.
nya: Chomwe chinawadabwitsa ndi kukwiyitsa a Wang ndi choti pa tsiku lomaliza kukhala mokakamizidwa ku hotelayi, kupatula kuyezedwa m'phuno ndi mkamwa, akuluakulu analamula kuti ayezedwenso kudzera ku malo ochitira chimbudzi.
mt0: <pad> What surprised and angered Wang was that on the last day of his confinement at the hotel, in addition to a nose and mouth test, authorities also ordered him to be tested through the bathroom.</s>

en: Kasim Abdurehim contributed to this report.
nya: Kasim Abdurehim ndiye watipatsira lipotili.
mt0: <pad> Kasim Abdurehim is the one who provided this report.</s>

en: At US Urging, Fiji Seizes Russian Oligarch’s Yacht
nya: Mokakamizidwa ndi US, Fiji igwira bwato la mpondamatiki wa ku Russia.
mt0: <pad> Fiji has seized the ship of a Russian diplomat under US pressure.</s>

en: Another Russian oligarchs yacht was seized Thursday as part of efforts to punish Russia over its war in Ukraine.
nya: Bwato la mpondamatiki wina wa ku Russia aligwira lachinayi ngat njira imodzi yofuna kulanga dziko la Russia kamba kochita nkhondo ndi Ukraine.
mt0: <pad> A Russian diplomat's ship was seized on Thursday as a way to punish Russia for its role in the conflict in Ukraine.</s>

en: At the request of the United States, Fijian officials took a $300 million yacht belonging to Suleiman Kerimov, the Justice Department said. Officials say the yacht is in Lautoka, Fiji.
nya: Kutengera pempho la United States, adindo a ku Fiji anatenga bwato la a Suleiman Kerimov, la ndalama zokwana 300 miliyoni US Dollars, gawo loyendetsa za chilungamo latero. Adindo ati bwatoli lili ku Lautoka ku Fiji.
mt0: <pad> Based on the request of the United States, Fiji authorities seized the Suleiman Kerimov ship, worth 300 million US dollars, as part of the international criminal justice system. The officials and ship are in Lautoka in Fiji.</s>

en: Kerimovs yacht, the Cayman Island-flagged Amadea, reportedly has been in Fiji since last month, arriving from Mexico. Defense lawyers claimed the vessel belonged to another oligarch.
nya: Bwato la a Kerimov la ku chilumba cha Cayman lotchedwa Amadea, lakhala lili ku Fiji kuchoka mwezi watha pomwe linafika kuchokera ku Mexico. Maloya ati bwatoli ndi la mpondamatiki wina.
mt0: <pad> The Cayman Islands ship Amadea, owned by Kerimov, has been in Fiji since last month after arriving from Mexico. Police say the ship is another diplomat's.</s>

en: Kerimov had already been sanctioned by the U.S. in 2014 and 2018 for Russias activities in Syria and Ukraine. The European Union also sanctioned him.
nya: A Kerimov anachenjezedwapo ndi dziko la U.S mu chaka cha 2014 ndi 2018 kamba ka zomwe dziko la Russia limachitira mayiko a Syria ndi Ukraine. European Union inawachenjezanso.
mt0: <pad> Kerimov has been warned by the U.S. in 2014 and 2018 for Russia's actions in Syria and Ukraine. The European Union also warned them.</s>

en: In March, the U.S. government announced a comprehensive effort to identify and seize the assets of wealthy Russians who have supported the government of Russian President Vladmir Putin, as part of the response to Moscows February 24 invasion of Ukraine.
nya: M'mwezi wa March, boma la U.S linalengeza kuti liyesetsa kudziwa komanso kulanda katundu wa anthu a chuma a ku Russia omwe athandiza boma la pulezident Vladmir Putin, ngati gawo losonyeza kukhudzidwa chifukwa cha upandu womwe Moscow inachitira Ukraine pa 24 February.
mt0: <pad> In March, the U.S. government announced that it was trying to identify and seize assets of Russian businessmen who support the Putin administration, as part of a response to the Moscow's invasion of Ukraine on 24 February.</s>

en: The initiative, led by the Justice Department, is called Task Force KleptoCapture.
nya: Omwe ayambitsa izi ndi a Justice Department ndipo zochitikazi zikutchedwa Task Force KleptoCapture.
mt0: <pad> The Justice Department initiated this and the operation was called Task Force KleptoCapture.</s>

en: U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland said Thursday in a statement there is "no hiding place for the assets of criminals who enable the Russian regime." He also said, "The Justice Department will be relentless in our efforts to hold accountable those who facilitate the death and destruction we are witnessing in Ukraine."
nya: Loya wa ku U.S, a Merrick Garland, lachinayi anena kuti, "kulibe komwe katundu wa ophwanya lamulo angabisale omwenso amathandizira ulamuliro wa ku Russia." Iwo anatinso, "gawo loyendetsa chilungamo la Justice Department, silitopa kuyesetsa kuthana ndi onse otsogolera imfa komanso kuwononga komwe tikuona ku Ukraine."
mt0: <pad> U.S. attorney Merrick Garland said on Thursday that "there is no place for the illegal immigrants who support the Russian regime to flee." He also said, "The Department of Justice will not stop working to bring down those who are behind the death and destruction we see in Ukraine."</s>

en: In April, at the urging of the U.S., Spanish authorities seized a yacht belonging to Russian oligarch Viktor Vekselberg, the owner of the Russian conglomerate Renova Group.
nya: M'mwezo wa April, akuluakulu a chi Spanish mokakamizidwa ndi dziko la U.S, anagwira bwato la mpondamatiki wa ku Russia, a Viktor Vekselberg, yemwe ndi mwini wake wa makampani a Renova Group.
mt0: <pad> In late April, Spanish authorities under U.S. pressure seized the ship of Russian businessman Viktor Vekselberg, who owns Renova Group company.</s>

en: Last week, the U.S. House of Representatives passed a measure that would allow the U.S. government to sell forfeited Russian properties worth more than $2 million for the benefit of Ukraine. The measures next step is the Senate.
nya: Sabata yatha, paliyamenti ya ku U.S inalamula kuti boma la U.S ndi lololedwa kugulitsa katundu wa ku Russia yemwe ndi wandalama zoposa 2 miliyoni U.S Dollars, zomwe zitathandizire dziko la Ukraine. Cholinga cha ndondomekoyi ndi kukumana ndi alangizi a boma.
mt0: <pad> Last Saturday, the U.S. congress approved that the U.S. government may sell Russian goods worth more than 2 million U.S. dollars, to help Ukraine. The purpose of this program is to meet with government advisers.</s>

en: (Some information in this report comes from Reuters.)
nya: (Uthenga wina mu lipotili wachoka ku Reuters).
mt0: <pad> (Some of the information in the report was taken from Reuters.)</s>

en: WHO Report Says COVID Cases Decline, Except in Americas, Africa
nya: Lipoti la WHO lati chiwerengero cha matenda a COVID chikutsika kupatula ku America ndi ku Africa.
mt0: <pad> The WHO report said the number of COVID cases had declined except in America and Africa.</s>

en: The World Health Organization said Wednesday that the number of newly reported coronavirus cases and deaths globally continued to fall in the last week, continuing a decline that began in March.
nya: World Health Organization, lachitatu yanena kuti nambala ya anthu omwe akupezeka ndi corona virus komanso kumwalira padziko lonse ikupitilira kutsika msabata yatha, kupitiliza kutsika komwe kunayamba March.
mt0: <pad> The World Health Organization, on Wednesday said that the number of coronavirus cases and deaths worldwide has continued to fall in the past week, continuing the decline that began in March.</s>

en: In its weekly report on the pandemic, the U.N. health agency said there were about 3.8 million new infections and more than 15,000 deaths last week, a 17% and 3% drop on the week respectively. But those figures are believed to be a significant underestimate of COVID-19's true toll as increasing numbers of countries abandon widespread testing and surveillance.
nya: Mu lipoti lake la sabata iliyonse la mliriwu, nthambi ya U.N yoyang'anira umoyo yati pali anthu pafupifupi 3.8 miliyoni omwe apatsirana matendawa komanso anthu oposa 15,000 amwalira sabata yatha zomwe zapangitsa chiwerengerochi kutsika ndi 17% komanso 3%. Koma nambalayi ikuoneka kuti yachepetsedwa poyendera ndi zotsatira za COVID-19 pamene mayiko ochuluka anasiya kuyesa matendawa komanso kuyang'anira mayiko awo.
mt0: <pad> In its weekly report on the pandemic, the UN's health agency said there were nearly 3.8 million cases and over 15,000 deaths last week which made the number of infections and deaths drop by almost 17% and 3%. But this number seems to be downplayed because many countries have abandoned testing and monitoring their citizens for COVID-19 as many countries have abandoned testing and monitoring their citizens for the disease.</s>

en: Still, WHO noted that cases rose by about a third in Africa and 13% in the Americas. There was also a nearly 70% jump in deaths reported in India, although that was attributed to delayed reporting rather than a recent surge of disease.
nya: Komabe WHO yapeza kuti chiwerengero cha odwala chakwera ndi magawo atatu pamene anthu 13 mwa 100 aliwonse ku America ali ndi matendawa. Pafupifupi anthu 70 pa 100 aliwonse amwaliraku India ngakhale akuti izi zili chomwechi kamba kotulutsa lipotili mochedwa osati kufala kwa matenda komwe kwachitika pompano.
mt0: <pad> But the WHO found that the number of patients had increased by three-quarters while 13 per cent of Americans were infected. About 70 per cent of the deaths occurred in India although this is said to be due to the report's delayed release not the recent outbreak.</s>

en: Last week, authorities in South Africa said they had noted an uptick in COVID-19 cases attributable to the BA.4 mutant of omicron, although they said it was too early to tell if that would result in a significant new wave of disease. Although the BA.4 version of COVID-19's omicron variant appears more infectious than omicron, WHO said there was no evidence yet that it was leading to substantially higher rates of hospitalization or death.
nya: Sabata yatha, adindo a ku South Africa ati apeza kuti pali kukwera kwa chiwerengero cha anthu odwala mtundu wina wa COVID-19 wotchedwa BA.4 omicron ngakhale kuti pakali pano sangathe kunena ngati iyi ingakhale nyengo ina ya mliriwu. Ngakhale kuti BA.4 omicron COVID-19 ndiyosiyana komanso yofala kwambiri kuposa omicron, WHO yati palibe umboni woti mthendayi ndi yomwe ikuchititsa anthu ambiri kugonekedwa kuchipatala kapena kumwalira.
mt0: <pad> Last Saturday, South African officials said they had found a rise in the number of people with BA.4 omicron COVID-19 cases, although they can't yet confirm whether this could be another season of the virus. WHO said there is no evidence that on Wednesday it was causing a significant increase in hospitalization or deaths.</s>

en: Salim Abdool Karim, a public health expert at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, said that while only a "modest" rise in cases had been noted, South Africa was also in the middle of a holiday period and testing had dropped significantly. He said the cases were slowing and were "not following a rocket-like upward trajectory we would expect" in another spike of disease.
nya: Salim Abdool Karim, katswiri wa zaumoyo ku sukulu ya ukachenjede ya KwaZulu-Natal, wati ngakhale pali chiwerengero chochepa cha odwala COVID, South Africa inali pakati pa tchuthi ndipo chiwerengero cha oyezetsa matendawa chinatsika. Iwo ati chiwerengerochi chimachepa ndipo, "sichimakwera ngati mmene timayembekezera," pa matendawa.
mt0: <pad> Salim Abdool Karim, a medical expert at the University of KwaZulu-Natal, said that although there are fewer COVID-19 cases, South Africa was in lockdown and the number of tests fell. They said the number of cases is lower and, "doesn't rise as we expect," on the virus.</s>

en: At a press briefing on Wednesday, WHO emergencies chief Dr. Michael Ryan said it was too soon to tell if COVID-19 was entering a seasonal pattern and warned against countries dropping all of their restrictions too quickly — as many in the West have done.
nya: Pa msonkhano wa atolankhani womwe unachitika lachitatu, mkulu WHO woona za ngozi zadzidzidzi, Dr. Michael Ryan, ati osafulumira kunena kuti COVID-19 ikusintha kamba ka kusintha kwa nyengo ndipo achenjeza mayiko omwe asiya kutsata njira zopewera mnthendayi mwansanga monga mmene achitira mayiko a azungu.
mt0: <pad> At a press conference on Wednesday, the WHO's director of emergency diseases Dr. Michael Ryan said he was not yet ready to conclude that COVID-19 is changing due to climate change and warned countries that have abandoned measures to prevent the outbreak as quickly as Western countries have done on Tuesday.</s>

en: "The jury is still out as to how seasonal this virus will become," he said, explaining that it wasn't proven yet that COVID-19 would naturally drop off in the summer and that the world could yet face more unsettling variants. "If people are crowded together in conditions where a new variant is spreading, you will see high levels of transmission," he said.
nya: "Oweruza akufufuzabe ngati kachilombo koyambitsa matendawa kamasintha ndi nyengo," Iwo anatero kufotokoza kuti sizinatsimikidwe ngati chiwerengero cha odwala COVID-19 chingatsike m'nyengo yotentha kapena ngati tingawonenso kusintha. "Ngati anthu angamachulukane mmalo omwe matenda atsopanowa akufala ndiye kuti chiwerengero chopatsirana chikhoza kukweranso," iwo anatero.
mt0: <pad> "Scientists are still investigating whether the virus can change with the season," they said, explaining that it is not yet clear if the number of COVID-19 cases will drop in the summer or if we will see a rebound.</s>

en: Meanwhile in China, authorities continued to crack down on cities, including Beijing, where more than 10% of the subway system was shut down in an effort to curb the virus' spread, after authorities in the capital already closed down indoor dining, gyms and school classes.
nya: Izi zili chomwechi, akuluakulu a ku China akupitilia kutseka mizinda kuphatikizapo Beijing komwe malo okwelera sitima 10 pa 100 aliwonse anatsekedwa pofuna kuchepetsa kufala kwa mthendayi komanso akuluakulu anatseka kale malo odyera, malo olimbitsira thupi komanso sukulu.
mt0: <pad> However, Chinese authorities are continuing to close cities including Beijing where 10 percent of the 100 train stations have been closed to prevent the Friday surge and officials have already closed restaurants, gyms and schools.</s>

en: In Shanghai, rigid and widely derided restrictions have led to shortages of food and medical aid along with a wider — though likely temporary — impact on the national economy. Desperate, outraged citizens have confronted authorities at barricades and online, screamed out of their windows and banged pots and pans in a sign of frustration and anger.
nya: Ziletso zokhwima komanso zonyoza ku Shanghai zapangitsa kuti pakhale kuchepa kwa chakudya ndi thandizo la mankhwala komanso zili ndi zotsatira pa chuma cha dziko. Mzika zokwiya zafunsa akuluakulu kochoka mnyumba zawo komanso pa intaneti. Anthuwa amakuwa kuchoka m'mazenera  awo komanso kumenyetsa mapoto ngati chizindikiro chosonyeza kukwiya ndi kukhumudwa.
mt0: <pad> The persistent and violent protests in Shanghai have caused shortages of food and medical care and affected the economy. Upset citizens have asked their officials to leave their homes and online. People jump from their windows and bang on their doors as a sign of anger and discontent.</s>

en: Myanmar Supreme Court Rejects Aung San Suu Kyi Appeal on Corruption Charges
nya: Khothi la Supreme la Myanmar yakana dandaulo la a Aung San Suu Kyi pa milandu ya katangale.
mt0: <pad> The Supreme Court of Myanmar has refused to free Aung San Suu Kyi on charges of political oppression.</s>

en: An appeal of a five-year jail sentence against ousted Myanmar leader Aung San Suu Kyi was rejected Wednesday by the country's supreme court.
nya: Khothi la Supreme m'dzikomo, lachitatu lanakiza yemwe anali mtsogoleri wa Myanmar kukadandaula kamba kosakhutitsidwa ndi chigamulo pa zaka zisanu zomwe anagamulidwa kuti akakhale kundende.
mt0: <pad> The Supreme Court of Myanmar on Wednesday refused to allow the former leader of Myanmar to appeal against his conviction for five years in jail.</s>

en: The decision reportedly came as soon as the claim for an appeal was lodged, and the court didn't entertain arguments from either side in the case.
nya: Ganizoli linabwera panthawi yomwe zinadziwika kuti akufuna kukadandaula ndipo khothi linakana kumvera mbali zonse zokhudziwa pa nkhaniyi.
mt0: <pad> The decision came after it became known that they were planning to sue and the court refused to hear all sides of the case.</s>

en: Suu Kyi, 76, was sentenced last week after being found guilty of 11 counts of corruption, including taking a bribe of cash and gold bars worth $600,000.
nya: Sabata latha, a Suu Kyi omwe ali ndi zaka 76, anagamulidwa kukakhala kundende kamba kopezeka olakwa pa milandu 11 ya chinyengo kuphatikizapo kulandila ndalama zakatangale ndi golide wa ndalama zokwana 600,000 U.S Dollars.
mt0: <pad> Last Saturday, the 76-year-old Aung San Suu Kyi was sentenced to a year in jail for 11 fraud charges including money laundering and gold of 600,000 U.S. dollars.</s>

en: Her lawyer called the charge absurd.
nya: Loya wawo wati chigamulochi ndi chosagwirizana ndi mlanduwu.
mt0: <pad> Their lawyer said the decision was unreasonable and inconsistent with the case.</s>

en: Suu Kyi had already been sentenced to six years for actions against the military, breaking COVID-19 rules and breaking a telecommunications law.
nya: A Suu Kyi anali atagamulidwa kale kukakhala kundende kwa zaka zisanu ndi chimodzi kamba kochita zinthu zotsutsana ndi asilikari, kuphwanya malamulo a COVID-19 komanso kuphwanya malamulo a mauthenga odzera pa lamya.
mt0: <pad> Aung San Suu Kyi was previously jailed for eight years for anti-military protests, Covid-19 restrictions and the violation of the phone communications law.</s>

en: She faces many more charges, and if found guilty could be sentenced to more than 150 years in jail.
nya: Iwo ali ndi milandu yambiri ndipo akapezeka olakwa, akhoza kukakhala kundende kwa zaka zoposera 150.
mt0: <pad> They have been charged with many crimes and if convicted, they can be in jail for over 150 years.</s>

en: Suu Kyi has been under house arrest since a military coup took over the country last year.
nya: A Suu Kyi akhala atamangidwa ndipo saloledwa kuchoka kunyumba kwawo kuchokera pomwe asilikari analanda dzikolo mwaupandu chaka chatha.
mt0: <pad> Aung San Suu Kyi has been imprisoned and barred from her home since the military coup d'etat last year.</s>

en: Since the coup, on Feb. 1, 2021, there have been widespread protests against the military regime. The regime cracked down violently in many cases, leaving more than 1,800 civilians dead and more than 10,000 arrested, charged or sentenced, according to the Assistance Association for Political Prisoners (Burma).
nya: Kuchokera pa 1 February, 2021, pomwe dziko linalandidwa mwaupandu, kwakhala kukuchitika ziwonetsero zotsutsana ndi ulamuliro wa asilikariwu. Bungwe la Assistance Association for Political Prisoners ku Burma, lati ulamuliro wa asilikariwu wachita ziwawa zambiri pomwe anthu 1,800 anamwalira ndipo ena oposera 10,000 anamangidwa, kupezeka olakwa kapena kugamulidwa.
mt0: <pad> From 1 February 2021, when the country was seized by the military, protests have been taking place against the military regime. The Assistance Association for Political Prisoners in Burma, says the military regime has committed a wide range of atrocities during which 1,800 people have been killed and over 10,000 people have been arrested, convicted or tortured.</s>

en: Some information in this report comes from Reuters and Agence France-Presse.
nya: Wina mwa uthenga mu lipotili wachokera ku Reuters ndi Agence France-Presse.
mt0: <pad> Some of the information in the report comes from Reuters and Agence France-Presse.</s>

en: Foreign Tourists Begin Arriving in New Zealand After COVID Restrictions Lifted.
nya: Alendo ochoka kunja ayamba kufika ku New Zealand pamene ziletso za COVID zachotsedwa.
mt0: <pad> Foreign tourists have begun arriving in New Zealand as COVID-19 restrictions have been lifted.</s>

en: For the first time in over two years, overseas tourists have been allowed to enter New Zealand starting Monday.
nya: Kwa nthawi yoyamba patatha zaka ziwiri, alendo ochoka m'mayiko ena ali ololedwa kulowa m'dziko la New Zealand kuyambira lolemba.
mt0: <pad> For the first time in two years, visitors from other countries will be allowed to enter New Zealand on Monday.</s>

en: The island nation known for its natural beauty enacted some of the strictest lockdown measures during the COVID-19 pandemic, including very restrictive travel limitations.
nya: Dzikoli lomwe lili pa chilumba, lomwenso limadziwika ndi kukongola kwake kwa chilengedwe, linakhazikitsa njira zokhwima zotsekera dzikolo mu nthawi ya mliri wa COVID-19 kuphatikizapo kuletsa kuyenda mwachisawawa.
mt0: <pad> The island-based country, also known for its natural beauty, has adopted strict measures to contain the country during the COVID-19 pandemic including a ban on unauthorized movement.</s>

en: The country had reopened for tourists from Australia weeks ago, but the new relaxation of restrictions now allows tourists from over 60 countries to visit, including most European countries and the U.S.
nya: Dzikoli linatsegulira zipata alendo ochoka ku Australia masabata apitawo ndipo kufewetsa malamuloku kukulola alendo ochoka m'mayiko 60 kuphatikizapo mayiko ambiri omwe ali ku Europe ndi U.S.
mt0: <pad> The country opened its borders to Australia a few weeks ago and relaxed rules for visitors from 60 countries including many European and U.S.</s>

en: "Today is a day to celebrate and is a big moment in our reconnection with the world," said Tourism Minister Stuart Nash.
nya: "Lero ndi tsiku lachisangalalo komanso nyengo yayikulu yomwe tikulumikizananso ndi dziko," anatero nduna yoona za alendo, a StuartNash.
mt0: <pad> "Today is a day of joy and a great moment for the country," said Tourism Minister Stuart Nash.</s>

en: Tourists must show they are fully vaccinated and test negative for the virus.
nya: Alendo onse akuyenera kuwonetsa kuti anabayitsa katemera komanso asapezeke ndi kachilomboka akayesedwa.
mt0: <pad> All visitors must show that they have received the vaccine and are negative for the virus when tested.</s>

en: Citizens of China, India and other countries not given a waiver Monday are still not allowed to visit.
nya: Mzika za ku China, India ndi mayiko ena omwe sanamasulidwe Monday sali ololedwa kulowa m'dzikomo.
mt0: <pad> Chinese, Indian and other citizens of countries that were not allowed to enter the country on Monday are not allowed to enter the country.</s>

en: Before the pandemic, tourism accounted for 5% of the countrys economic activity and 20% of its foreign income.
nya: Usanabwere mliriwu, alendo amapanga 5% ya chuma cha dzikolo komanso 20% ya chuma chochoka kunja.
mt0: <pad> Before the pandemic, tourists made up 5% of the country's economy and 20% of its export income.</s>

en: On Monday, 43 international flights carrying around 9,000 passengers were scheduled to leave or arrive at Auckland International Airport, Reuters reported.
nya: Lolemba, ndege za kunja 43 zomwe zinanyamula anthu 9,000 omwe amayenera kufika kapena kuchoka ku bwalo la ndege la Auckland, Reuters yapereka lipotili.
mt0: <pad> On Monday, 43 foreign aircraft carrying 9,000 people were due to land or depart from the Auckland airport, Reuters reported.</s>

en: Some information in this report comes from The Associated Press and Reuters.
nya: Uthenga wina mu lipotili wachoka mu The Associated Press and Reuterss.
mt0: <pad> Some of the reports were published by the Associated Press and Reuters.</s>

en: Report: Iran to Execute Swedish-Iranian National by May 21.
nya: Lipoti: Iran ikufuna kupha munthu wa chi Swedish wokhala ku Iran pasanafike pa 21 May.
mt0: <pad> Report: Iran wants to kill a Swedish resident in Iran before May 21</s>

en: Iran will later this month execute a Swedish-Iranian national whom it has imprisoned since 2016 and convicted of spying for Israel, media reported.
