nya: Wofalitsa nkhani ati dziko la Iran kumapeto kwa mwezi uno lipha munthu wa chi Swedish yemwe ali mzika ya ku Iran, yemwe wakhala kundende kochoka mu 2016 kamba kopezeka wolakwa pokhala mzondi wa Israel.
mt0: <pad> The Swedish national, who was imprisoned in Iran since 2016 for being a spy for Israel, was executed in the end of this month.</s>

en: Irans semiofficial ISNA news agency on Wednesday released a report in which Iranian officials stated that Tehran will implement the death penalty against Ahmad Reza Jalali by May 21.
nya: Nthambi yofalitsa nkhani ya ku Iran ya ISNA, yatulutsa lipoti lachitatu loti mzinda wa Tehran upereka chilango chokupha a Ahmed Reza Jalali pasanafike pa 21 May.
mt0: <pad> The Iranian news agency ISNA, on Wednesday reported that Tehran has sentenced Ahmed Reza Jalali to death before May 21.</s>

en: Jalali, a researcher and physician who specializes in disaster relief, was arrested during a visit to Iran in April 2016. In 2017, Jalali was sentenced to death in Iran after he had been found guilty of passing information about two Iranian nuclear scientists to Israel to help it assassinate several nuclear scientists.
nya: A Jalali omwe ndi wofufuza komanso dokotala wothandiza pa ngozi zadzidzidzi, anamangidwa pamene anakayendera dziko la Iran mu April, 2016. Mu 2017, a Jalali anagamulidwa kuti akuyenera kuphedwa ku Iran atapezeka olakwa pa mlandu wopereka uthenga wokhudzana ndi a sayansi awiri ochita za nukiliya ku Iran pofuna kuthandiza dziko la Israel kupha ochita sayansi ya nukiliya angapo.
mt0: <pad> Jalali, a research and clinical doctor, was arrested when he visited Iran in April 2016. In 2017, he was sentenced to death in Iran after being convicted of giving information about two Iranian nuclear scientists to Israel to help Israel kill several Iranian nuclear scientists.</s>

en: Rights groups have condemned Jalalis detention, citing Irans pattern of detaining dual nationals and expatriates without due process.
nya: Magulu a maufulu adzudzula kusungidwa kwa a Jalali ponena kuti dziko la Iran lilibe njira zoyenera zosungira kundende anthu omwe ndi mzika za m'mayiko awiri komanso anthu okhala kunja kwa dzikolo.
mt0: <pad> Human rights groups have condemned the detainment of Jalali, saying that Iran does not have proper procedures for detaining dual nationals and foreigners.</s>

en: Iran does not recognize dual nationals.
nya: Anthu omwe ndi mzika za mayiko awiri samatengedwa ngati mzika za ku Iran.
mt0: <pad> citizens of both countries are not considered Iranians.</s>

en: The announcement came as authorities in Stockholm wrapped up the trial of Hamid Nouri, a former Iranian prosecution official whom Swedish officials arrested in November 2019.
nya: Chidziwotsochi chabwera pamene akuluakulu a ku Stockholm amamalizitsa kumvera mlandu wa a Hamid Nouri, omwe anali m'dindo wozenga milandu, ndipo anamangidwa ndi adindo a chi Swedish mu November, 2019.
mt0: <pad> The announcement comes after Stockholm authorities finished hearing the case of Hamid Nouri, a former prosecutor, who was arrested by Swedish police in November, 2019.</s>

en: Authorities say Nouri played a role in the deaths of political prisoners executed on Iranian government orders at Irans Gohardasht prison during the final phase of the Iran-Iraq war in 1988. Nouri has been held in custody in Sweden since his arrest.
nya: Akuluakulu ati a Nouri anatengapo gawo pa imfa za akaidi omangidwa kamba ka ndale pomwe boma la Iran linalamula kuti aphedwe ku ndende ya ku Iran ya Gohardasht kumapeto kwa nkhondo ya Iran ndi Iraq m'chaka cha 1988. A Nouri akhala akusungidwa ku Sweden kuchoka nthawi yomwe anamangidwa.
mt0: <pad> Authorities said Nouri was involved in the executions of political prisoners when Iran's government ordered them to be executed at the Iran prison of Gohardasht at the end of the Iran-Iraq war in 1988. Nouri has been held in Sweden since his arrest in 1988.</s>

en: On Wednesday, the final day of Nouri's trial, a Stockholm district court judge set the date of the verdict for July 14.
nya: Lachitatu lomwe linali tsiku lomaliza kumvera mlandu wa a Nouri, woweluza milandu wa ku khothi la m'boma la Stockholm, wasankha 14 July ngati tsiku lopereka chigamulo.
mt0: <pad> On Wednesday, the last day of the hearing for Nouri, a judge at the Stockholm City Court appointed 14 July as the date of the verdict.</s>

en: Amnesty International put the number of those executed at the prison at 5,000 but said in a 2018 report that the number could be higher.
nya: Amnesty International yati omwe anaphedwa kundende ndi anthu 5,000 koma mu lipoti la 2018, nambalayi ikhoza kukhala yokwera.
mt0: <pad> Amnesty International says the number of prisoners killed in jail is 5,000 but in its 2018 report, the number may be higher.</s>

en: Human Rights Watch, in a recent report, said, "Iran continues to be one of the worlds leading implementers of the death penalty."
nya: Mu lipoti lomwe latulutsidwa kumene, bungwe loona za ufulu la Human Rights Watch lati, "dziko la Iran ndilo lili patsogolo ndipo likupitilira kukhala limodzi mwa mayiko omwe akuperekabe chilango chakupha pa dziko lonse."
mt0: <pad> In a recent report, Human Rights Watch said, "Iran is the frontrunner and continues to be one of the only countries that still impose death sentences around the world."</s>

en: If Nouri is convicted, he will face a maximum life sentence on charges of international war crimes and human rights abuses. Iran recently summoned the Swedish envoy in protest over Nouris case.
nya: Ngati a Nouri angapezeke olakwa, akhoza kukakhala kundende moyo wawo onse chifukwa cha milandu ya nkhondo ya pakati pa mayiko komanso kuphwanya ufulu. Posachedwapa, dziko la Iran lagwira nthumwi za chi Swedish ngati gawo la zionetsero zosonyeza kusakondwa ndi kumangidwa kwa a Nouri.
mt0: <pad> If convicted, Nouri could be imprisoned for life for international war crimes and human rights abuses. Recently, Iran detained Swedish diplomats as part of protests against the arrest of Nouri.</s>

en: Maja Aberg, senior policy adviser with Amnesty International Sweden, says it is no coincidence that Iran announced Jalalis pending execution just after Swedish prosecutors moved on Nouris trial.
nya: Maja Aberg, mlangizi wa za malamulo pamodzi ndi Amnesty International ya ku Sweden, wati sikuti zangochitika kuti dziko la Iran lalengeza za kuphedwa kwa a Jalali panthawi yomwe oweruza milandu a chi Swedish anayamba kumvera mlandu wa a Nouri.
mt0: <pad> Maja Aberg, a legal counsel with Amnesty International in Sweden, said it was not coincidence that Iran announced the death of Jalali at the same time that Swedish prosecutors began to hear the case of Nouri.</s>

en: "It indicates that (Iran) sees him as a kind of piece in the jigsaw puzzle, which is very worrying," Aberg told Sweden's TT news agency.
nya: "Zikusonyeza kuti dziko la Iran limawasunga pokonzekera nthawi ngati ino zomwe zili zodandaulitsa kwambiri," Aberg anawuza nyuzi ya ku Sweden ya TT.
mt0: <pad> "This shows that Iran is keeping them in reserve for such a time which is very sad," Aberg told the Swedish news agency TT.</s>

en: Swedish law allows for the prosecution of Swedish citizens and other nationals for crimes against international law committed abroad.
nya: Malamulo a chi Swedish amalola kuzenga milandu mzika za chi Swedish ndi ena okhala m'dzikomo pa milandu yolakwira malamulo a pakati pa mayiko, yomwe imachitika kunja kwa dzikolo.
mt0: <pad> Swedish law permits prosecution of citizens and other residents of Sweden for international criminal offences committed outside the country.</s>

en: Some information for this report came from The Associated Press, Reuters and Agence France-Presse.
nya: Uthenga wina mu lipotili unachokera ku The Associated Press, Reuters ndi Agence France-Presse.
mt0: <pad> Other reports were from the Associated Press, Reuters and Agence France-Presse.</s>

en: Erdogan Goes to Riyadh to Seal Rapprochement
nya: Erdogan apita ku Riyagh kukabwezeretsa ubale.
mt0: <pad> Erdogan is in Riyadh to strengthen relations.</s>

en: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan heads to Saudi Arabia Thursday for a two-day visit aimed at easing old tensions between Ankara and Riyadh.
nya: Pulezidenti wa chi Turkish, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, wapita ku Saudi Arabia lachinayi, pa ulendo wake wa masiku awiri womwe cholinga chake ndi kuthetsa udani womwe unali pakati pa Ankara ndi Riyadh.
mt0: <pad> Turkish President, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, has arrived in Saudi Arabia on Thursday, on a two-day visit aimed at resolving the tension between Ankara and Riyadh.</s>

en: The Turkish leaders visit with the Saudi king comes after years of rivalry between their once-close countries.
nya: Atsogoleri a chi Turkish ayendera mfumu ya ku Saudi patadutsa zaka mayikowa ali pa udani ngakhale anali pa ubwenzi kale.
mt0: <pad> Turkish leaders have been visiting the Saudi king for years although the two countries have been in conflict for years.</s>

en: Mehmet Ogutcu is the head of the London Energy Club, a grouping of government and energy sector leaders. Ogutcu says the visit is the culmination of intense international diplomacy.
nya: Mehmet Ogutchu ndi mkulu wa gulu la London Energy Club, lomwe ndi gulu la boma ndi atsogoleri a chigawo choyang'anira mphamvu. A Ogutcu ati ulendowu ulimbikitsa ubale wa pakati pa mayiko.
mt0: <pad> Mehmet Ogutchu is the president of the London Energy Club, a group of government and industry leaders. Mr Ogutcu said the tour encourages international ties.</s>

en: "President Erdogan has good relations with the king; with the crown prince Muhammad Bin Salman, we had serious difficulties," said Ogutcu. "Now it looks that I believe the*(Britons), and Americans, and the Qataris of course played some role, even the Azeris might have done this. And things are changing and relaxing a bit more, and now at the presidential level, it's going to be sealed."
nya: "Pulezidenti Erdogan ali pa ubale wabwino ndi a mfumu; tinali ndi mavuto aakulu ndi mwana wa mfumu, Muhammad Bin Salman," atero a Ogutcu. Tsopano zikuoneka kuti ndikukhulupilira kuti anthu a ku Briton, America ndi ku Qatar anatengapo gawo ngakhale anthu a ku Azeris akhoza kukhala kuti anachita izi. Zinthu zikusintha komanso kusiya kuvuta, tsopano chifukwa cha a pulezidenti izi zisindikizidwa.
mt0: <pad> "President Erdogan has a good relationship with the king; we had difficulties with the son of the king, Muhammad Bin Salman," said Ogutcu. "But now things are changing and getting better, now thanks to the president this is being published."</s>

en: Erdogan and the crown prince have been bitter rivals. The Turkish president led international condemnation over the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi, who was killed inside Saudi Arabias consulate in Istanbul.
nya: A Erdogan ndi mwana wa mfumu akhala pa udani woopsa. Pulezidenti wa chi Turkish ndi yemwe anatsogolera mayiko kudzudzula dziko la Saudi Arabia pa kuphedwa kwa mtolankhani wa ku Saudi, a Jamal Khaashoggi, yemwe anaphedwa mu ofesi ya ku Istanbul ku Saudi Arabia.
mt0: <pad> Erdogan and the prince of Saudi Arabia have been in a fierce war. The Turkish president was the first to condemn Saudi Arabia for the murder of the Saudi journalist, Jamal Khaashoggi, who was killed in Istanbul's consulate in Saudi Arabia.</s>

en: The killing was linked to the crown prince, a charge he denied. But the decision earlier this month to move the Khashoggi murder trial from Istanbul to Riyadh is seen as a gesture by Ankara, opening the way for Erdogan's visit.
nya: Mwana wa mfumuyi amakhudzidwa ndi imfayi koma iye anakana mlanduwu. Koma ganizo loti mlandu wa kuphedwa kwa Khashoggi ukazengedwe ku Istanbul kuchoka ku Riyadh ndi chisonyezo choti Ankara ikuwalandira a Erdogan pa ulendo wawo.
mt0: <pad> The king's son is linked to the death but he denies the charges. But the suggestion that the trial of Khashoggi will be transferred to Istanbul from Riyadh is a sign that Ankara is welcoming Erdogan on his trip to the kingdom.</s>

en: Ogutcu says with presidential elections due next year, Erdogan is looking for Saudi help to bail out the ailing Turkish economy.
nya: A Ogutcu ati pamene zisankho za pulezidenti zili chaka cha mawa, a Erdogan akufuna Saudi iwathandize kukweza chuma cha Turkish.
mt0: <pad> Ogutcu and when the presidential election is next year, Erdogan wants Saudi Arabia to help boost the Turkish economy.</s>

en: "Turkey has an interest in reviving relations with Riyadh because Turkey needs financial support," said Ogutcu. "The Turkish economy is not attracting any significant portfolio investments nor sovereign wealth funds coming to invest Turkey. But this will be a give-and-take package deal involving these countries. So, there are real economic and political security interests involved."
nya: "Turkey ikufuna kuyambitsanso ubale wake ndi Riyadh chifukwa dziko la Turkey likufuna thandizo la ndalama," anatero a Ogutcu. "Chuma cha ku Turkish sichikukopa magulu ambiri  kapena anthu a chuma chawo kudzachita malonda m'dzikomo. Koma tsopano pakhala mgwirizano wopereka ndi kulandila pakati pa mayikowa. Kotero pali chuma komanso ndale zofunika chitetezo."
mt0: <pad> "Turkey wants to re-establish its ties with Riyadh because Turkey needs financial support," said Mr Ogutcu. "But now there is a deal of give and take between the two countries. So there is a political and economic need for security."</s>

en: Shared concerns over Iran's growing influence in the region -- along with its nuclear energy program -- provide important common ground between Riyadh and Ankara, says international relations professor Soli Ozel of Istanbul's Kadir Has University, especially as American attention is expected to pivot away from the Middle East and toward China.
nya: Pali kudandaula kuti ganizo la dziko la Iran lofuna kupitilira ndi kukhazikitsidwa kwa mphamvu ya nukiliya ndi komwe kukuyanjanitsa Riyadh ndi Ankara, a polofesa Soli Ozel a ku sukulu ya ukachenjede ya Kadir yomwe ili ku Istanbul ndiwo ananena izi. Iwo anatinso, izi zili chomwechi makamaka pamene chidwi cha America chikuyembekezeka kuchoka ku mayiko a aluya kupita ku China.
mt0: <pad> There are concerns that Iran's decision to pursue its nuclear program is making Riyadh and Ankara separate, Prof. Soli Ozel of Kadir University in Istanbul said. He added, this is especially true when American interests are expected to be shifted from the Arab world to China.</s>

en: "Turkey does propose itself as a counterweight to Iran. Both countries have an interest along with all the western countries for Iran not to be as influential throughout the region as it is today," said Ozel. "And the Iranians are also constantly sending signals that they are not going to let others draw them away from those countries - Iraq, Lebanon and Syria - where they have quite a lot of influence."
nya: "Dziko la Turkey limadziona ngati lili ndi mphamvu zambiri zoposera dziko la Iran. Mayiko onsewa pamodzi ndi mayiko onse a kwa azungu amafuna kuti dziko la Iran lisakhale ndi mphamvu m'chigawo chonse monga mmene zilili lero," anatero a Ozel. "Anthu a ku Iran nawo akuwonetsa zizindikiro zosonyeza kuti salola kuti ena awachotse ku mayiko a Iraq, Lebanon ndi Syria, komwe ali ndi mphamvu."
mt0: <pad> "Turkey is a country that sees itself as more powerful than Iran. All of these countries, along with the United States, want to keep Iran out of the region," he said.</s>

en: Erdogan's Saudi visit is part of a wider policy of seeking to repair relations across the region in a bid to end its isolation. The Turkish president has recently visited the United Arab Emirates and earlier this month hosted the Israeli president, Isaac Herzog.
nya: Ulendo wa a Erdgan wopita ku Saudi ndi gawo la lamulo lalikulu lofuna kukonzanso maubale m'chigawochi pofuna kuthetsa kudzipatula. Pulezidenti wa chi Turkish anayenderanso United Arab Emirates posachedwapa komanso kumayambiliro a mwezi uno analandira pulezident wa ku Israel, a Isaac Herzog.
mt0: <pad> The trip to Saudi Arabia is part of a broader policy to rebuild relations with the region to end its isolation. The Turkish president has recently visited the United Arab Emirates and in the beginning of this month he met with the Israeli president, Isaac Herzog.</s>

en: But analyst Ozel warns Ankara is in a vulnerable position.
nya: Koma akatswiri Ozel wachenjeza kuti Ankara ili pachiopsezo.
mt0: <pad> But expert Ozel warned that Ankara is in danger.</s>

en: "Turkey alienated, insulted, offended a lot of countries with which it had at least decent relations. And they all recognize that this burst of diplomacy is coming out of weakness rather than strength," said Ozel.
nya: "Dziko la Turkey linadzipatula, kunyoza komanso kukhumudwitsa mayiko ambiri omwe linali nawo pa ubale wabwino. Ndipo onsewa akuzindikira kuti mgwirizano wadzidzidziwu ukubwera kamba ka kufooka osati kulimbika kwa Turkey," anatero a Ozel.
mt0: <pad> "Turkey isolated, insulted and disappointed many of the countries it had a good relationship with. And now everyone realizes that this current coalition is coming because of its weakness not its strength," said Ozel.</s>

en: But analysts say Ankara is banking on its importance as a potential bulwark to Iranian ambitions, a factor that may help overcome any remaining hostility among the neighbors it is trying to win back.
nya: Koma akastwiri ati Ankara ikutenga ubwino wake ngati kuthekera kodzimangira linga pofuna kudziteteza ku zofuna za Iran, njira yomwe ingathandize kuthana ndi udani pakati pa omwe ayandikana nawo kuti ubale ubwelere.
mt0: <pad> But analysts say Ankara sees its strength as the possibility of a shield to protect itself from Iran's intentions, a move that could help overcome hostility between neighbors to rebuild ties.</s>

en: Executions, Detentions Hang Over Saudi Legal Reforms
nya: Kupha, komanso kumanga kutsalira kusintha kwa malamulo ku Saudi.
mt0: <pad> The killing, and the imprisonment of dissidents have sparked a change in Saudi Arabia's law.</s>

en: Saudi Arabia is pushing to revamp its harsh justice system but reforms are overshadowed by executions and tough treatment of dissidents, raising questions about how much will change.
nya: Saudi Arabia ikufuna kukonza malamulo ake a nkhanza koma kusinthaku kukutsekerezedwa ndi kupha komanso kuzunza otsutsa zomwe zikubweretsa mafunso odabwa kuti ndi zinthu ziti zomwe zitasinthe.
mt0: <pad> Saudi Arabia wants to reform its cruel laws but this change is being hampered by the killing and torture of dissidents which raises questions about what has changed.</s>

en: The kingdom is known for its strict interpretation of Islamic sharia law, which forms the basis of its judicial system.
nya: Ufumuwu umadziwika ndi kutanthauzira kwake kwa lamulo la chisilamu la sharia lomwe ndi gwero la malamulo okhudzana ndi milandu.
mt0: <pad> The kingdom is known for its interpreting of the Islamic law sharia which is the source of criminal law.</s>

en: But in recent months it has moved ahead with reforms that analysts say could make its courts function more like others in the Middle East.
nya: Koma m'miyezi yapitayi, dzikoli lapitilira ndi kusintha malamulo zomwe akatswiri ati zikhoza kupangitsa kuti makhothi awo azigwira ntchito ngati ena onse ku mayiko a aluya.
mt0: <pad> But in recent months, the country has gone through a series of legislative changes that some experts say may make their courts more like other developed countries.</s>

en: That effort hinges on a series of new laws for sensitive issues like women's divorce rights and judges' power to determine criminal sentences.
nya: Izi zagwirizana ndi m'ndandanda wa malamulo atsopano okhudza ufulu wa azimayi banja likatha komanso mphamvu ya oweruza milandu kupereka chigamulo kwa olakwa.
mt0: <pad> This was linked to a series of new laws on women's rights after divorce and the power of prosecutors to prosecute those who are guilty.</s>

en: Announced last year by de facto ruler Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, the measures, including the first written penal code, appear to align with Saudi Arabia's goal of opening up to the world and softening its extremist image.
nya: Chaka chatha, mwana wa mfumu, Prince Mohammed bin Salman yemwe anadziika yekha pampando analengeza kuti njira zimenezi kuphatikizapo malamulo omwe analembedwa koyamba okhudzana ndi milandu komanso zilango zake, akufanana ndi cholinga cha Saudi Arabia chofuna kumasukira dziko ndi kuchotsa chithunzithunzi choyipa.
mt0: <pad> Last year, the king's son Prince Mohammed bin Salman announced that these measures, including the first draft law on criminality and punishment, were in line with Saudi Arabia's goal of opening up the country and removing its bad image.</s>

en: Even critics concede the changes could make Saudi courts more predictable, in some cases.
nya: Ngakhale otsutsa avomereza kuti kusinthaku kupangitsa zochitika ku ma Khothi a ku Saudi zizidziwika pena.
mt0: <pad> Even those who oppose the change agree that it will make Saudi courts more transparent.</s>

en: But there is no expectation that restrictions on free speech will ease, or that the legal system will treat more favorably perceived opponents of the government.
nya: Koma palibe chiyembekezo choti pakhala kufewetsa malamulo okhwima oletsa kuyankhula zakukhosi kapena ngati makhothi asiye kuwonetsa tsankho kwa omwe akuoneka kuti ndi otsutsa boma.
mt0: <pad> But there is no hope that harsh laws on dissent will be relaxed or that the courts will stop showing bias against people who are clearly government critics.</s>

en: And despite the reforms, authorities have simultaneously provided reminders of what gave Saudi Arabia its ruthless reputation in the first place, notably the mass execution of 81 men in a single day in March for offenses related to "terrorism."
nya: Pamene pali kusintha, pa nthawi yomweyo akuluakulu akukumbutsa zomwe zinachititsa kuti Saud Arabia ikhale ndi mbiri yankhanza, ndipo ati izi zili chomcho kamba ka kuphedwa kwa anthu 81 pa tsiku limodzi m'mwezi wa March pa milandu yokhudzana ndi ziwawa.
mt0: <pad> When there is a change, at the same time officials remind what made Saudi Arabia known as a brutal state, and say this is so because 81 people were executed in March on charges of sexual abuse.</s>

en: 'Notorious' system
nya: Kachitidwe koyipa ka zinthu
mt0: <pad> The bad economy</s>

en: Two new laws have already been approved by the Saudi Cabinet. One governs the admissibility of evidence, previously at the judges' discretion.
nya: Malamulo awiri atsopano avomerezedwa ndi boma la ku Saudi. Lamulo loyamba ndi lolola kupereka umboni wovomerezedwa ndi woweruza milandu.
mt0: <pad> Two new laws have been adopted by the Saudi government. The first law is to allow for the presentation of a witness who has been approved by a court.</s>

en: The second, a family law, is to take effect in June. In a traditionally male-dominated system, it expands the rights of divorced women to alimony and custody of their children.
nya: Lamulo lachiwiri ndi lokhudza mabanja lomwe liyambe kugwira ntchito mu June. Kutengera pachikhalidwe chomwe abambo amalamula, lamuloli likutambasula ufulu wa amayi wolandila malipiro komanso kusunga ana banja likatha.
mt0: <pad> The second law is the Family Law that started in June. Depending on the patriarchal culture, the law extends the rights of mothers to receive benefits and keep children after divorce.</s>

en: Announcing the new law in March, Prince Mohammed said it represented "a major qualitative leap" for women's rights and "family stability."
nya: Polengeza za lamulo latsopano m'mwezi wa March, Prince Mohammed ati lamuloli likusonyeza "kusintha kwakukulu" pa ufulu wa amayi  ndi "kulimba kwa mabanja."
mt0: <pad> When Prince Mohammed announced the new law in March, he said it represented a "significant change" in women's rights and "the strengthening of families."</s>

en: The reforms seem partly to cater to foreign firms whose investment the kingdom is courting, said Adel al-Saeed, vice president of the European Saudi Organization for Human Rights.
nya: Wachiwiri kwa mtsogoleri wa bungwe la European Saudi Organization for Human Rights, a Adel al-Saeed, ati  kusinthaku mbali ina kupereka mpata kwa ochita malonda a m'mayiko ena omwe zotsatira zake ndi zomwe ufumuwu ukufuna.
mt0: <pad> Adel al-Saeed, deputy director of the European Saudi Organization for Human Rights, said the change was partly to give foreign businessmen an opportunity to invest in the country, which is what the kingdom wants.</s>

en: "The owners of capital are afraid of investing in this country, which is notorious in the legal aspect, so these laws are intended to change the image," he said.
nya: "Eni ake a mpamba amachita mantha kudzachita malonda m'dziko lino lomwe lili ndi malamulo ankhanza, kotero malamulowa akufuna kusintha zimenezi," iwo anatero.
mt0: <pad> "The owners of the tobacco companies are afraid to do business in this country with harsh laws, so the bill is meant to change that," they said.</s>

en: The new penal code, yet to be unveiled, could bring further dramatic changes.
nya: Malamulo atsopano okhudza milandu ndi zilango zake, omwe pakalipano sanadziwike, akhoza kupitiliza kubweretsa kusintha.
mt0: <pad> New laws on crimes and punishments, which are not yet known, may continue to bring about change.</s>

en: Under sharia, only apostasy, theft, revolt, armed robbery, adultery, drinking alcohol and slander carry prescribed sentences. Judges are left to determine punishment in other cases.
nya: Pansi pa lamulo la sharia, milandu ya mpakuto pa chipembedzo, kuba, kuwukira, kuba ndi mfuti, chigololo, kumwa mowa ndi kunyozana ndi yomwe ili zigamulo zake zodziwikiratu. Milandu ina yonse woweruza milandu ndi omwe amasankha zilango zake.
mt0: <pad> Under the sharia law, only those crimes that are against religion, stealing, robbery, armed robbery, prostitution, drinking and threatening have clearly stated punishments. For all other crimes the judge is free to decide his own punishments.</s>

en: With a penal code in place, "the state will expect judges to rely not on their own training in sharia but instead on the legal rules (based on sharia) approved by the state," said Nathan Brown, an academic at George Washington University.
nya: Pamene pali malamulo a milandu ndi zilango zake, "boma likuyembekeza kuti woweruza milandu sazidalira kuphunzira kwawo kwa lamulo la sharia, koma malamulo (omwe gwero lake ndi lamulo la sharia) ovomerezedwa ndi boma," anatero a Nathan Brown, wophunzira ku sukulu ya ukachenjede ya George Washington.
mt0: <pad> Nathan Brown, a student at George Washington University School of the Arts and Sciences, said that "the government expects that judges will not be dependent on their own study of sharia law, but on the law (which is sourced from sharia law) approved by the government."</s>

en: "As a result, Saudi Arabia will look much more like a civil law system, much like most states in the region," said Brown, who has studied the Saudi reforms.
nya: "Zotsatira zake ndi zoti Saudi Arabia iwoneka ngati dziko la malamulo okhudza anthu, monga maboma ena onse m'chigawochi," atero a Brown omwe anaphunzira za malamulo atsopano a ku Saudi.
mt0: <pad> "The result is that Saudi Arabia looks like a state of law, like all other governments in the region," said Brown, who studied the new Saudi law.</s>

en: The result should be more "predictability," said Abdullah Alaoudh, a U.S.-based legal expert and government critic, as new rules "take away from the leeway ... that the judges used to have."
nya: Zotsatira zake zikhale "zodziwika," anatero a Abdullah Alaoudh, katswiri wa malamulo komanso otsutsa boma omwe amakhala ku U.S, pamene malamulo atsopano "akutenga ufulu umene woweruza milandu anali nawo."
mt0: <pad> The result was "predictable," says Abdullah Alaoudh, a legal expert and opposition leader who lives in the U.S., as the new law "cut off the freedom of the judge."</s>

en: But tighter regulation by the monarchy also "creates a larger problem: lack of independence," he added.
nya: Koma malamulo okhwima opangidwa ndi mafumu "amabweretsa vuto lalikulu: kusadziyimira panokha," iwo anawonjezera.
mt0: <pad> But the strict monarchy laws "bring a big problem: inequality," they added.</s>

en: The king is the head of the Saudi judiciary and acts as the final court of appeal.
nya: Mfumu ndiye mtsogoleri wa makhothi a ku Saudi ndipo amakhala ngati khothi lalikulu lochitila apilu.
mt0: <pad> The king is the head of the Saudi courts and acts as the supreme court of emergency.</s>

en: Alaoudh's own father, prominent cleric Salman al-Awdah, has been held since 2017, seemingly in retaliation for a Twitter post that clashed with Saudi Arabia's policy at the time of isolating Qatar.
nya: Bambo awo a Alaoudh, a Salman al-Awdah, womwe ndi wansembe wodziwika, akhala atamangidwa kuchoka mu 2017 kamba koyankha zosagwirizana ndi lamulo la Saudii Arabia pa tsamba la mchezo la Twitter, panthawi yomwe dzikoli limadzipatula ku dziko la Qatar.
mt0: <pad> The father of Alaoudh, Salman al-Awdah, a prominent preacher, has been detained since 2017 for his anti-Saudi comment on the Saudi Arabian social network Twitter, during the country's isolation from Qatar.</s>

en: He is one of many detained in an apparent crackdown on dissent and those who could challenge Prince Mohammed's power.
nya: Iwo ndi mmodzi mwa ambiri omwe anamangidwa mwankhanza kamba kotsutsa pamodzi ndi  omwe amapikisana ndi mphamvu za mwana wa mfumu, Mohammed.
mt0: <pad> He is one of many who were brutally imprisoned for their dissent along with others who challenged the power of the son of the king, Mohammed.</s>

en: One of the most prominent examples is former crown prince Mohammed bin Nayef, the CIA ally respected in the West for his efforts to counter violent extremism, but who King Salman ousted from the line of succession.
nya: Chimodzi mwa zitsanzo zodziwika bwino ndi mwana wamfumu Mohammed bin Nayef yemwe anagwirizanitsa CIA, komanso amalemekezedwa ndi mayiko a azungu chifukwa choyesetsa kuthana ndi nkhanza ngakhale mfumu Salman anamuchotsa pa ndandanda wa anthu otenga ufumu.
mt0: <pad> One of the most famous examples is Prince Mohammed bin Nayef who collaborated with the CIA, and is admired by Western countries for his efforts to fight terrorism even though King Salman removed him from the list of heirs to the throne.</s>

en: Prince Nayef has not been seen in public since reports of his arrest in March 2020. His detention was never officially confirmed.

mt0: <pad> "I told them that taking a lot of stories from a woman writer about the greater part of the country could have other results," they said. "I could have written this book by myself, but it wouldn't sound the same."</s>

en: Originally from Andalusia in southern Spain, Sancha spent the past 14 years in the Middle East covering conflicts in Iraq, Syria and Yemen, and reporting from Egypt, Lebanon and Tunisia.
nya: A Sancha omwe kwawo ndi ku Andalusia, ku m'mwera kwa Spain, akhala ku mayiko a aluya kwa zaka 14 zapitazo, kulemba nkhani zokhudza kusamvana ku Iraq, Syria ndi Yemen komanso kuchita lipoti kuchokera ku Egypt, Lebanon ndi Tunisia.
mt0: <pad> Sancha, who is from Andalusia, south of Spain, has lived in Arab countries for the past 14 years, writing about conflicts in Iraq, Syria and Yemen and reporting from Egypt, Lebanon and Tunisia.</s>

en: She has been working more recently with the European Union communications department, after leaving Beirut for health reasons following a mass explosion that rocked the city in 2020.
nya: Masiku apitawa, iwo akhala akugwira ntchito kwambiri ndi chigawo cha mauthega ku European Union, atachoka ku Beirut kamba ka mavuto a zaumoyo omwe anayambika chifukwa cha mabomba omwe anaphulitsidwa mu mzindawu m'chaka cha 2020.
mt0: <pad> They have been working closely with the European Union's refugee department, after leaving Beirut because of health problems that started after bomb blasts in the city in 2020.</s>

en: Women "have a different experience because we would go to places that our male colleagues were not used to. Not because we're smarter, but just because the majority of the region is still Arab, Muslim and gender-segregated," Sancha told VOA.
nya: Akazi "akudziwa zambiri chifukwa timatha kupita malo omwe abambo ogwira nawo ntchito sanazolowele. Osati chifukwa ndife anzeru koma chifukwa anthu ambiri m'chigawochi akanali a mtundu wa chi Arab, asilamu komanso amasiyanitsa amayi ndi abambo," a Sancho anawuza VOA.
mt0: <pad> "The women are more knowledgeable because they can go places where men would not be allowed. Not because we are smart but because the people in this region are still Arab, Muslim and they still distinguish women from men," Sancho told VOA.</s>

en: Having women reporters has an impact, she noted.
nya: Iwo anazindikira kuti kukhala ndi atolankhani aakazi kuli ndi ubwino.
mt0: <pad> They realized that having women journalists had a positive effect on the organization.</s>

en: "If I put myself in the position of the reader, I would prefer to have a woman telling me the story because it is going to be about 100 percent of the population, which means you are going to have a more inclusive narrative on the conflict."
nya: "Nditakhala wowerenga nkhani, ndikhoza kukonda kuti wofotokoza nkhaniyo akhale mzimayi chifukwa ikhala yokhudzana ndi chiwerengero chonse, zomwe zikutanthauza kuti mu nkhaniyi mukhala zonse zokhudzana ndi kusamvana."
mt0: <pad> "If I were a reader, I might like the narrator to be a woman because it is about the whole population, which means that the story is all about diversity.</s>

en: For her book, Sancha reached out to other women who cover the Middle East, to ensure diverse perspectives from foreign and local reporters.
nya: Mu bukhu lawo, a Sancha anafikira amayi ena omwe amalemba nkhani ku mayiko aluya, pofuna kuwonetsetsa kuti pali maganizo osiyanasiyana kuchoka kwa atolankhani akunja ndi apafupi.
mt0: <pad> In their book, Sancha contacted other women journalists in rich countries, to ensure that there were different perspectives from both international and local journalists.</s>

en: The result of the nearly two-year collaboration is Bullets for All, released in Spanish in April.
nya: Zotsatira za mgwirizano wa pafupifupi zaka ziwiri ndi Bullets for All, yomwe inatulutsidwa m'mwezi wa April ku Spain.
mt0: <pad> The result of a two-year partnership with Bullets for All, which was launched in April in Spain.</s>

en: In the book, "we tell one story with different voices that represent all the women" from the region, Sancha said.
nya: Mu bukhuli, "anthu osiyanasiyana akufotokoza nkhani imodzi yomwe ikuyimira amayi onse," a m'chigawochi, anatero a Sancho.
mt0: <pad> In the book, "different people are telling a story that represents all mothers," of the region, said Sancho.</s>

en: Each offers a personal perspective on covering historic moments, including the collapse of autocratic governments, popular protest movements and war. It also examines the discrimination and harassment women face in the newsroom and on assignment.
nya: Aliyense amapereka maganizo ake pa kulemba nkhani za mbiri yakale kuphatikizapo kugwa kwa ulamuliro wa chipani chimodzi, ziwonetsero ndi nkhondo. Bukhuli likuwunikanso kusalidwa ndi nkhanza zomwe amayi amakumana nazo ku ma ofesi olemba nkhani komanso pogwira ntchito.
mt0: <pad> Everyone gives their opinion on writing about the history of the country including the fall of one-party rule, protests and war. This book also explores the abuse and harassment that women experience in news agencies and while working.</s>

en: Making connections
nya: Kuchita mgwirizano.
mt0: <pad> Making a deal</s>

en: Understanding language and culture goes a long way toward making progress in the region, says Maya Gebeily. The Reuters bureau chief for Lebanon, Syria and Jordan is one of the contributors to the book.
nya: Kumvetsa chiyankhulo ndi chikhalidwe kumathandiza kupita chitsogolo m'chigawochi," anatero a Maya Gebeily. Iwo monga mkulu wa ofesi ya The Reuters ku Lebanon, Syria ndi Jordan anathandiza nawo pa bukhuli.
mt0: <pad> "Understanding the language and culture helps to move forward in this region," said Maya Gebeily, the head of the Reuters office in Lebanon, Syria and Jordan.</s>

en: "There's a lot to say and show from the perspective of women reporters who were also then influenced by the women that they met as they were doing their reporting," she said.
nya: "Pali zambiri zofuna kunena ndi kuwonetsa kuchoka ku mbali ya atolankhani aakazi omwe anasintha chifukwa cha amayi omwe amakumana nawo pamene amachita utolankhani," iwo anatero.
mt0: <pad> "There are a lot of things to say and show about the transitions of women journalists who have changed because of the mothers they meet while they work," they said.</s>

en: Born in the U.S. to Lebanese parents, Gebeily started her journalism career in 2013 with a local news site in Beirut, Lebanon. She went on to cover the region for Agence France-Presse before joining Reuters.
nya: A Gebeily, omwe anabadwa kwa makolo a chi Lebanise ku U.S, anayamba ntchito yawo yolemba nkhani mu 2013 ku ma ofesi olemba nkhani ku Beirut ku Lebanon. Iwo anapita m'chigawochi kukagwilira ntchito Agence France-Presse asapite ku Reuters.
mt0: <pad> Gebeily, who was born in the U.S. of Lebanese parents, began their journalistic career in 2013 at the news offices in Beirut in Lebanon. They moved to the region to work for Agence France-Presse before moving to Reuters.</s>

en: Gebeily said her American and Lebanese background helped her understand the region better, which in turn has shaped her reporting. Knowing the local language is an important part of that.
nya: A Gebeily ati kukhala wa mtundu wa chi American ndi Lebanese kwawathandiza kumvetsa bwino chigawochi komanso kwasintha utolankhani wawo. Kudziwa chiyankhulo ndi gawo lofunikira la zimenezi.
mt0: <pad> A Gebeily and being American and Lebanese helped them understand the region better and changed their reporting. Knowing the language is an important part of that.</s>

en: "When interviewing a minister or a displaced person or an activist, the most important element is getting their trust," she said. "If you're able to speak the language and make them feel comfortable from the beginning, it changes everything. It grants you a very beautiful kind of access."
nya: "Pofunsa mafunso nduna, munthu wothawa kwawo kapena wofuna kusintha zinthu, chinthu chofunika kwambiri ndi kupeza chikhulipliro chawo," iwo anatero. "Kutha kuyankhula chiyankhulo chawo ndi kuwapangitsa kuti akhale omasuka, kumasintha kalikonse. Izi zimapereka mwayi wabwino.
mt0: <pad> "When asking questions to a politician, refugee or change-maker, the most important thing is to get their trust," they said. "Being able to speak their language and make them feel comfortable changes everything. This gives a good chance.</s>

en: In addition to Iraq and Lebanon, Gebeily, 30, has also traveled to Syria to cover the war against the Islamic State (IS) militant group.
nya: Kuwonjezera Iraq ndi Lebanon, a Gebeily a zaka 30, anapitako ku Syria kukalemba nkhani zokhudza nkhondo yolimbana ndi gulu la zigawenga la Islamic State (IS)
mt0: <pad> Beyond Iraq and Lebanon, Gebeily, 30, has been to Syria to report on the war against the Islamic State (IS) terror group.</s>

en: "Ive been very privileged to access some communities directly without having to work with a translator or a fixer, which also shapes the way that the stories come out," she said.
nya: "Ndakhala ndi mwayi woyankhula ndi anthu mwachindunji m'madera ena popanda wotanthauzira kapena wothandizira,zomwenso zimathandiza mmene nkhani zitulukire," iwo anatero.
mt0: <pad> "I've had the opportunity to talk to people directly in some areas without a translator or assistant, which also helps with the spread of information," they said.</s>

en: Syrian-Kurdish journalist Khabat Abbas, who has covered the war in Syria, attests to the importance of that.
nya: Wolemba nkhani wa mtundu wa chi Syrian-Kurdish, a Khabat Abbas, omwe analemba nkhani za nkhondo ya ku Syria, akuvomereza za kufunika kwa izi.
mt0: <pad> The Syrian-Kurdish writer Khabat Abbas, who has covered the war in Syria, agrees with the importance of this.</s>

en: "Its knowing the language and the culture that gives people a sense of comfort to open up to you," she told VOA from Qamishli, Syria.
nya: "Kudziwa chiyankhulo ndi chikhalidwe ndi komwe kumapangitsa anthu kuti akumasukire ndi kukuuza zinthu," iwo anawuza VOA kuchoka ku Qamishli, ku Syria.
mt0: <pad> "Knowing the language and culture makes people more approachable and open to you," they told VOA from Qamishli, Syria.</s>

en: That knowledge helped when Abbas, 34, was on assignment with Sancha in March 2021. They traveled to a Kurdish-run detention camp in northeast Syria and interviewed female jihadists affiliated with IS, for a story in El Pais.
nya: Kudziwa kumeneku kunathandiza pamene a Abbas a zaka 34, anakagwira ntchito ndi a Sancha mu March, 2021. Iwo anapita ku malo osungira anthu ku Kurdish, kumpoto kwa Syria, kukafunsa mafunso akazi omwe amamenya nawo nkhondo yoyera (yachilungamo) yokhudzana ndi IS, kuti alembe nkhani mu El Pais.
mt0: <pad> This knowledge helped Abbas, 34, and Sancha, 29, work together in March 2021. They went to Kurdish refugee camps in north of Syria, to interview women who were fighting the white war (the righteous war) against IS, to write a story for El Pais.</s>

en: "While in Qamishli [in northeast Syria], I ran into two British journalists, very good colleagues of mine, who were disappointed after Shamima Begum and other women at the camp refused to talk to them," Sancha said, referring to a young woman who left her home in Britain aged 15 to join IS.
nya: "Pamene ndinali ku Qamashli (kumpoto kwa Syria), ndinakumana ndi wolemba nkhani komanso anzanga a chi British awiri, omwe anali okhumudwa kuti Shamima Begum ndi akazi ena kumaloku anakana kuyankhula nawo," anatero a Sancha kutanthauza mtsikana yemwe anachoka kwawo ku Britain ali ndi zaka 15 kukalowa gulu la IS.
mt0: <pad> "While I was in Qamashli (north of Syria), I met with a journalist and two British friends, who were upset that Shamima Begum and other women in the area refused to talk to them," said Sancha.</s>

en: "Their fixer was a man, so the jihadist women didnt talk to them because they are radical, and they dont talk to men. But then I was able to sit with Shamima and other women, who gave fantastic interviews from inside their tents," Sancha said.
nya: "Yemwe amawathandiza anali munthu wabambo kotero akazi omenya nkhondowa sanayankhule nawo chifukwa anasintha ndipo sayankhula ndi anthu aamuna. Koma ine ndinakhala pansi ndi Shamima komanso akazi ena omwe anayankha bwino mafunso mkati mwa hema wawo," anatero a Sancha.
mt0: <pad> "The aide was a man so the women fighters didn't talk to them because they were changing and didn't want to talk to men. But I sat down with Shamima and other women who answered questions well in their tent," said Sancha.</s>

en: Abbas had a role in getting to talk to those women, she added.
nya: A Abbas anali ndi gawo kuti ayankhule ndi amayiwa, iwo anawonjezera.
mt0: <pad> Abbas had a chance to talk with the mother, he added.</s>

en: Unlike Sancha and Gebeily, Abbas grew up in the marginalized Kurdish region of Syria, where until the war began in 2011, journalism effectively didnt exist.
nya: Kusiyana ndi a Sancha ndi a Gebeily, a Abbas anakulira ku chigawo chaching'ono cha Kurdish komwe kunalibe kulemba nkhani kufikira nthawi yomwe nkhondo inayamba mu 2011.
mt0: <pad> Unlike Sancha and Gebeily, Abbas grew up in a small Kurdish region where there was no recording of the conflict until the start of the 2011 war.</s>

en: "Ordinary people in our region were used to seeing women pick up arms and fight, but they werent used to seeing a woman hold a camera on the streets and on front lines," Abbas said. "It took a lot of sacrificing for me to convince my family and society that Im as good, if not better, as my male colleagues."
nya: "Anthu m'chigawochi anazolowera kuwona amayi akutenga zida ndi kumenya nkhondo osati kuwona amayi atatenga chojambulira munsewu kapena akuyima patsogolo, " anatero Abbas. "Zinatengera kudzipereka kuti banja ndi dera langa atsimikize kuti ndimachita zinthu bwino mwinanso kuposera anzanga achimuna omwe ndimagwira nawo ntchito.
mt0: <pad> "People in this region were accustomed to seeing women taking arms and fighting, not seeing women standing in the street or standing in front," Abbas said. "It took dedication to my family and community to ensure that I was doing well, even better than my male colleagues who worked with me."</s>

en: Journalism appealed to her because the story of the Middle East has often been told by male journalists, both local and foreign.
nya: Kulemba nkhani kunawasangalatsa chifukwa nkhani za mayiko aluya zimakambidwa ndi wolemba nkhani achimuna, pafupi ngakhalenso kunja.
mt0: <pad> The writing was interesting to them because the world of foreign affairs was discussed by male journalists, both locally and abroad.</s>

en: "The narrative hasnt changed because of that, but if local and international women journalists get a real chance to tell the story of the Middle East, that narrative could change, which would affect the way others see this region," Abbas said.
nya: "Kulemba nkhani sikunasinthe chifukwa cha izi, ngati amayi olemba nkhani a konkuno komanso kunja angapatsidwe mwayi wolemba nkhani za mayiko aluya, kalembedwe ka nkhani kakhoza kusintha, zomwenso zingasinthe mmene anthu ena amawonera chigawo chino," anatero a Abbas.
mt0: <pad> "Writing has not changed because of this, if women journalists from the region and abroad are allowed to write about the Middle East, the writing style can change, which can also change the perception of the region," Abbas said.</s>

en: Sancha also believes women in journalism have an impact on the way issues are viewed in the region, including post-traumatic stress disorder and the effect it has on female health, and subjects such as violence and alcohol.
nya: A Sancha akukhulupilira kuti amayi olemba nkhani ndiwokhudzidwa ndi mmene anthu amaonera zinthu m'chigawochi, kuphatikizapo kukhala ndi maganizo oopsa kamba ka zomwe zinachitika ndi zotsatira zake pa umoyo wa amayi komanso pa ziwawa ndi mowa.
mt0: <pad> Sancha believes that the author's mother is affected by the perceptions of the community, including having negative attitudes towards the incident and its effects on her health and on violence and alcohol.</s>

en: "We talk about all these issues that men normally wouldnt not speak about," she said.
nya: "Timakamba zinthu zomwe abambo samayankhulapo," iwo anatero.
mt0: <pad> "We talked about things that our father doesn't talk about," they said.</s>

en: Iran's Guards Commander Says Israel Creating Conditions for Own Destruction
nya: Mkulu wa asilikari ku Iran wati Israel ikuchita zinthu zowononga dziko lake.
mt0: <pad> Iran's military chief said Israel is trying to destabilize his country.</s>

en: Israel's actions are creating conditions for its own destruction, Irans Revolutionary Guards commander on Friday told a Jerusalem Day rally at which the countrys new domestically-made Kheibar Buster missile was displayed.
nya: Zochita za Israel zipangitsa kuti dzikoli liwonongeke, mkulu wolamula asillikari ku Iran wanena izi pa msonkhano wa pa tsiku la Yerusalemu pa mwambo woonetsa bomba lomwe dzikolo lapanga lokha, lotchedwa Kheibar Buster
mt0: <pad> Israel's actions will lead to the destruction of the country, the top nuclear official of Iran said at a press conference in Jerusalem on Tuesday during the launch of the country's first self-made bomb, the Kheibar Buster.</s>

en: State television said millions of Iranians joined rallies marking Quds Day, the Arabic name for Jerusalem, in state-organized marches across the country.
nya: Kanema wa boma wati anthu okwana ma miliyoni anapita ku misonkhano ya tsiku la Yerusalemu lomwe ndi Quds Day mu chi Arabic, kukaonera kuguba komwe kunakonzedwa ndi boma m'dzikomo.
mt0: <pad> The state television reported that up to a million people attended the Jerusalem Day gatherings, or Quds Day in Arabic, to watch the government's demonstrations in the city.</s>

en: It showed the Israeli flag being set on fire and groups of people around the country shouting choreographed "Death to America, Death to Israel" slogans.
nya: Kanemayu amawonetsa mbendera ya Israel ikuwotchedwa komanso magulu a anthu m'dzikolo akukuwa mawu olembedwa kuti "imfa ku America, imfa ku Israel."
mt0: <pad> The video shows the Israeli flag burned and a crowd of people in Israel chanting "death to America, death to Israel."</s>

en: Supreme leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said in a televised speech that anti-Israeli protests and attacks showed that Palestinians rejected compromises by Arab authorities with Israel.
nya: Poyankhula pa kanema, mtsogoleri Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, wati ziwonetsero zodana ndi Israel zikuwonetsa kuti anthu a ku Palestine anakana pempho la akuluakulu a ku Arab kuti amvane ndi Israel.
mt0: <pad> Speaking via video, the leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei said the protests against Israel show that the Palestinian people refused the Arab calls for peace with Israel.</s>

en: Opposition to Israel is a touchstone of belief for Iran, which backs Palestinian and Lebanese Islamist militant groups opposed to peace with Israel, which Tehran does not recognize.
nya: Kutsutsana ndi Israel ndi chimodzi mwa zikhulupiliro za ku Iran, zomwe zimapangitsa kuyikira kumbuyo magulu a zigawenga a ku Palestine ndi ku Lebanon omwe amatsutsana ndi mtendere wa ku Israel, zinthu zomwe mzinda wa Tehran sumazindikira.
mt0: <pad> Anti-Israelism is one of Iran's core beliefs, which leads to its backing of Palestinian and Lebanese terrorist groups that oppose Israel peace, something Tehran does not recognize.</s>

en: "What has happened in Palestine in recent years annuls all plans for compromise with the Zionist enemy (Israel) because no plan for Palestine can be implemented in the absence or contrary to the opinions of its owners, the Palestinians," Khamenei said, speaking in Arabic and addressing Palestinians and other Arabs.
nya: "Zomwe zachitika ku Palestine mu zaka zapitazi, zithetsa chikonzero cha mgwirizano ndi adani a Ziyoni (Israel) chifukwa palibe chikonzero cha Palestine chomwe chingatike eni ake palibe kapena ngati pali kuchita zosemphana ndi maganizo a anthu a ku Palestine," anatero a Khamenei, kuyankhula chi Arabic ndi anthu a ku Palestine komanso anthu a chi Arab.
mt0: <pad> "The events in Palestine over the past years have ended the possibility of a coalition with the Zionist enemies because there is no Palestinian solution that can be achieved if its own people are not present or if it is acted against the will of the Palestinian people," said Ayatollah Khamenei, speaking in Arabic with Palestinians and Arabs.</s>

en: Thus, Khamenei said, all previous peace agreements -- such as the 1993 Oslo Accords, the two-state solution to resolve the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, and former U.S. President Donald Trump's plan dubbed the Deal of the Century "are null and void".
nya: A Khamenei ati, mgwirizano wokhazikitsa mtendere womwe unachitika kale--monga Oslo Accords mu 1993 womwe umatanthauza kugawa mayiko a Israel ndi Palestne kuti akhale oyima pawokha pofuna kuthetsa kusamvana komwe kuli pakati pawo komanso chikonzero cha mtsogoreli wakale wa ku U.S a Donald Trump chotchedwa Deal of the Century, tsopano zilibe ntchito.
mt0: <pad> The Supreme Leader said that the previous peace accords, such as the Oslo Accords in 1993 that aimed at dividing Israel and Palestine into two independent states to end the conflict, and Donald Trump's Deal of the Century, are now obsolete.</s>

en: President Ebrahim Raisi, Irans military commanders and senior officials also attended the rallies in which people were allowed to march through the streets, the first time since the outbreak of the coronavirus pandemic two years ago.
nya: Pulezidenti Ebrahim Raisi, akuluakulu a asilikari ku Iran ndi adindo ena anapita nawo ku misonkhanoyi komwe anthu analoledwa kuyenda mmisewu koyamba kuchokera pomwe mliri wa coronavirus unafala, zaka ziwiri zapitazo.
mt0: <pad> President Ebrahim Raisi, military commanders and other senior officials attended the meetings where people were allowed to walk on the streets for the first time since the coronavirus outbreak began two years ago.</s>

en: Iran's Jerusalem Day rallies are held annually in support of Palestinians, who want East Jerusalem as the capital of a future state in territories captured by Israel in a 1967 war, on the last Friday of the Muslim fasting month of Ramadan.
nya: Dziko la Iran limachita misonkhano ya tsiku la Yerusalemu chaka chilichonse pofuna kuthandiza anthu a ku Palestine  omwe akufuna kuti kum'mawa kwa Yerusalemu kukhale mzinda wa boma lakutsogolo mzigawo zomwe Israel inatenga pa nkhondo ya 1967, lachisanu lotsiriza la mwezi wosala kudya asilamu wa Ramadan.
mt0: <pad> Iran holds the Jerusalem Day Conferences every year to support the Palestinian people who want east Jerusalem to be the capital of the future state in the territories Israel occupied in the 1967 war, on the last Friday of Ramadan, the last day of the Muslim fasting month.</s>

en: "Stop your vicious deeds. You know well that we are people of action and reaction," Revolutionary Guards commander Hossein Salami, addressing Israel, told demonstrators in Tehran.
nya: "Siyani kuchita zinthu zankhanza. Mukudziwa bwino kuti ndife anthu ochita komanso obwezera," mkulu wa asilikari, HosseinSalami, ananena izi poyankhula ndi Israel komanso kuuza omwe akuchita ziwonetsero ku Tehran.
mt0: <pad> "Stop acting cruelly. You know well that we are people of action and revenge," the commander of the armed forces, HosseinSalami, said in a statement to Israel and to demonstrators in Tehran.</s>

en: "Our responses are painful. You create conditions for your own destruction. We will not leave you alone ...You know better than me what will befall you if you take evil action."
nya: "Mayankho athu ndi opweteka. Mukupanga zinthu zodziwononga nokha. Sitikusiyani..mukudziwa kuposa ine zomwe zitakuchitikireni mukapanga zinthu zoyipa."
mt0: <pad> "Our answers are harsh. You're doing your own harm. We won't let you go...you know better than I do what will happen to you if you do bad things.</s>

en: Iran's military has vowed to retaliate harshly against any attack by Israel, which has often voiced concern over the Iranian nuclear program. Tehran says the program is for peaceful purposes only.
nya: Asilikari a ku Iran alonjeza kubwezera mwaukali ziwawa zilizonse zochoka ku Israel, zomwe zakhudza ndondomeko ya nukiliya ku Iran. Tehran yati ndondomekoyi cholinga chake ndi kubweretsa mtendere basi.
mt0: <pad> The Iranian military has promised to retaliate fiercely to any attack from Israel, which has affected Iran's nuclear program. Tehran has said that its nuclear program is only for peace.</s>

en: Israel, whose existence the Islamic Republic does not recognize, has long threatened military action against Iran if talks between Tehran and world powers fail to curb Iranian nuclear activity. Iran says its nuclear ambitions are peaceful.
nya: Dziko la Israel, lomwe kwa boma la asilamu ndi lopanda pake, lakhala likuwopseza kuchita nkhondo ndi dziko la Iran ngati kukambirana pakati pa Tehran ndi mphamvu za dziko lonse kungalephere kuletsa Iran kukonza zinthu za nukiliya. Iran yati zolinga za nukiliya ndi zamtendere.
mt0: <pad> Israel, which is a non-Islamic state, has been threatening to attack Iran if international talks between Tehran and the world powers fail to stop Iran's nuclear program. Iran says its nuclear goals are peaceful.</s>

en: In February, the Islamic Republic unveiled its "Kheibar Buster" missile with a range of 1,450 km (900 miles).
nya: M'mwezi wa Febuluwale, boma la asilamu linabweretsa poyera bomba lawo la "Kheiber Buster" lomwe likhoza kuyenda mlengalenga mtunda okwana ma kilomita 1,450 (900 mayilosi).
mt0: <pad> In February, the Islamic State unveiled their "Kheiber Buster" bomb which can travel over 1,450 kilometers (900 miles) into the atmosphere.</s>

en: Iran, which has one of the biggest missile programs in the Middle East, says its ballistic missiles have a range of up to 2,000 km (1,200 miles) and are capable of reaching its arch-foe Israel and U.S. bases in the region.
nya: Iran, yomwe ili ndi imodzi mwa ndindomeko zokonzera mabomba ku mayiko aluya, yati mabomba owuluka mlengalengawa akhoza kuyenda mtunda wa makilomita 2000 (1200 mayilosi) ndipo ali ndi kuthekera kokafika komwe kuli adani awo a ku Israel ndi U.S m'chigawochi.
mt0: <pad> Iran, which has one of the world's most ambitious nuclear programs, says its missile can travel up to 2000 kilometers (1200 miles) and have the capability to hit Israel and the United States in the region.</s>

en: Kheibar refers to an ancient Jewish oasis in the Arabian Peninsula's Hijaz region that was overrun by Muslim warriors in the 7th century.
nya: Kheibar akutanthauza kasupe wakale wa chi Yuda ku ndomo ya chi Arabian, m'chigawo cha Hijaz yemwe analandidwa ndi asilamu ankhondo mu 7th Century.
mt0: <pad> Kheibar means an ancient Jewish bath on the Arabian coast, in the region of Hijaz which was conquered by Muslims in the 7th Century.</s>

en: Tehran regards its ballistic missile program as an important deterrent against the United States, Israel and other adversaries, and has rejected Western demands to halt it.
nya: Tehran ikuona kuti ndondomeko yake yokonza mabomba ndi yofunika chifukwa ilepheretsa United States, Israel ndi adani ena ndipo yakana zofuna za mayiko a azungu kuti asiye.
mt0: <pad> Tehran believes its bomb program is important because it has defeated the United States, Israel and other enemies and has refused to accept Western demands to abandon it.</s>

en: Over the past year, Iran and the United States have engaged in fitful, indirect talks in Vienna to revive a 2015 nuclear deal that then-President Donald Trump reneged on in 2018 and that Iran, in turn, began violating in 2019.
nya: Mu chaka chatha, Iran ndi United States akhala akukambirana mopanda chindunji komanso mozungulira ku Vienna kuti abwezeretse pangano la nukiliya la mu 2015 lomwe mtsogoleri wa nthawi imeneyo, a Donald Trump anaphwanya ndipo pambuyo pake Iran inachita chimodzimodzi mu 2019.
mt0: <pad> Last year, Iran and the United States have been negotiating indirectly and round-the-clock in Vienna to renegotiate the 2015 nuke deal that the then president, Donald Trump broke and then Iran did the same in 2019.</s>

en: Under the 2015 deal, Iran agreed to limit its nuclear program in return for relief from economic sanctions.
nya: Pansi pa pangano la 2015, Iran inavomereza kuchepetsa ndondomeko ya nukiliya kusinthanitsa ndi kuchotseredwa chilango pa chuma.
mt0: <pad> Under the 2015 deal, Iran agreed to freeze its nuclear program in exchange for a reduction in economic sanctions.</s>

en: While they appeared close to resurrecting the deal in March, talks stalled over last-minute Russian demands and whether Washington might drop Iran's Revolutionary Guards from its Foreign Terrorist Organization list.
nya: Pamene amawoneka ngati akuyandikira kubwezeretsa panganoli mu March, zokambiranazi zinayima kaye kamba ka zofuna za Russia komanso ngati Washington ingachotse asilikari a ku Iran pandandanda wa Foreign Terrorist Organization.
mt0: <pad> While they seemed to be nearing a renewal of the deal in March, talks were stalled by Russia's demands and whether Washington would remove Iran's military from the list of Foreign Terrorist Organization.</s>

en: As Fewer Americans Attend Church, Can Coffee Shops Fill the Void?
nya: Pamene anthu a ku America ochepa akupita ku tchalitchi, sitolo zogulitsira khofi zitenga malo?
mt0: <pad> When Americans go to church less, coffee shops will build a store.</s>

en: Churches and other houses of worship have historically played critical social and political functions in American society. But fewer people are attending religious services, and the decline of churches and other houses of worship threatens to leave a void that could potentially be filled by coffee shops.
nya: Tchalitchi ndi nyumba zopemphelera, kwanthawi tsopano zatengapo gawo pa ubale komanso ndale za anthu a ku America. Koma ndi anthu ochepa omwe amapita kopemphera ndipo kuchepa kwa chiwerengero cha ma tchalitchi ndi nyumba zopembedzera kukuopseza kusiya mpata womwe sitolo za khofi zingalowepo.
mt0: <pad> Churches and temples have been a part of American culture and politics for a long time. But only a small number of people go to church and the decline in the number of churches and temples is threatening to leave the space for coffee shops.</s>

en: "For so much of American history, the church has really been — or their congregations have really been — essential, providing an unheralded role in providing cohesion and connectedness in communities … encouraging civic engagement and political participation," says Daniel Cox, director of the Survey Center on American Life and a senior fellow at the American Enterprise Institute.
nya: "Mu mbiri ya America, tchalitchi - kapena anthu osonkhanawa- akhala ofunikira potenga gawo mwakachetechete pogwira ntchito limodzi komanso kulumikizana m'dera lawo, kulimbikitsa kuthandiza dera komanso kutengapo mbali pa ndale," atero a Daniel Cox, mkulu wa Survey Centre on American Life komanso mkulu wa American Enterprise Institute.
mt0: <pad> "Throughout American history, churches - or congregations - have been important in quietly working together and connecting in their community, promoting community aid and participating in politics," said Daniel Cox, director of the Survey Center on American Life and president of the American Enterprise Institute.</s>

en: "It was not happenstance or luck that the civil rights movement emerged out of the church," Cox says.
nya: "Sikuti zinangochitika kapena kuti ndi mwayi kuti gulu lomenyera ufulu wa anthu linayambira mu tchalitchi," anatero a Cox.
mt0: <pad> "It's either by chance or luck that the civil rights movement began in church," said Cox.</s>

en: "And you see that cross-culturally … whether it's in predominantly white rural communities, in the suburbs, wherever, churches have historically been really, really important."
nya: "Mukhoza kuwona kuti pachikhalidwe, kaya ndi ku midzi kwa azungu ambiri kapena madera okulirapo, ndi kwina konse, tchalitchi zakhala zofunika kwambiri.
mt0: <pad> You can see that in culture, whether in rural English communities or in urban areas, churches have been very important.</s>

en: Churches and other houses of worship have also played a role in helping immigrants assimilate once they arrive in America, Cox says.
nya: Tchalitchi ndi nyumba zopemphererako zatenganso udindo pothandiza anthu wobwera kuti akhazikike akafika ku America, atero a Cox.
mt0: <pad> Churches and mosques have also taken on a role in helping immigrants to get established in America, Cox said.</s>

en: In 1999, 70% of Americans said they belonged to a church, mosque or synagogue.
nya: Mu 1999, anthu 70 pa 100 aliwonse ku America anati amapita ku tchalichi, ku mzikiti kapena ku kachisi.
mt0: <pad> In 1999, 70 percent of Americans said they went to church, mosque or temple.</s>

en: By 2020, that number had dropped to 47%. A 2019 survey found that only about three in 10 Americans say they attend weekly religious services.
nya: Pofika 2020, nambalayi inatsika kufika pa anthu 47 pa 100 aliwonse. Kafukufuku wa 2019 wapeza kuti anthu atatu pa anthu khumi aliwonse a ku America ndi omwe amapita kopemphera sabata iliyonse.
mt0: <pad> In 2020, the number fell to 47 per cent. A 2019 study found that three out of 10 Americans went to church every week.</s>

en: Third places  Lack of involvement and affiliation with churches, mosques and synagogues means people might be missing out on what urban sociologist Ray Oldenburg dubbed as "third places" — public gathering spots that offer something that home, the "first place," and work, the "second place," might not.
nya: Malo achitatu, kusakhudzidwa ndi kulumikizana ndi ma tchalitchi, mizikiti komanso ma kachisi kukutanthauza kuti anthu akusowekera zomwe katswiri woona za anthu m'matawuni, a Ray Oldenburg, akutchula kuti "malo achitatu."- msonkhano omwe umapereka zomwe khomo lomwe ndi "malo oyamba" komanso ntchito yomwe ndi "malo achiwiri" sizingapereke.
mt0: <pad> The lack of connection with churches, mosques and temples means that people are lacking what urban sociologist Ray Oldenburg calls the "third place"- a meeting that provides what the home as the "first place" and the work as the "second place" cannot.</s>

en: Oldenburg argued that third places are critical to a communitys social vitality.
nya: A Oldenburg ati malo achitatu amatsutsana ndi maubale komanso umoyo wa anthu m'madera.
mt0: <pad> Oldenburg and the three places are concerned with relations and life of the people in the region.</s>

en: An October 2021 survey conducted by the American Survey Center found that commercial spaces like coffee houses foster trust and connection in American communities and could help fill the void left by churches.
nya: Kafukufuku wa mu October, 2021, yemwe anachitidwa ndi gulu la American Survey Centre, anapeza kuti malo ochitila malonda monga nyumba zogulitsira khofi, zimayambitsa kukhulupilirana ndi kulumikizana m'madera a ku America zomwe zinatenga malo a tchalitchi.
mt0: <pad> October 2021 research by the American Survey Center found that commercial spaces such as coffee shops, promote trust and connection in American communities that have taken over church sites.</s>

en: "If you're a regular at a cafe, the barista may know what you usually order, and they can make it for you, and that feels good," says clinical psychologist Dr. Maria Espinola, an assistant professor in the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Neuroscience at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine.
nya: "Ngati umapitapita ku malo omwera khofi, ogulitsa amadziwa zomwe umakonda kugula, amakupangira ndipo izi zimamveka bwino," ananena izi ndi wachipatala woona zokhudzana ndi maganizo, Dr. Maria Espinola, komanso pulofesa wothandizira mu chigawo cha Psychiatry and Behavioral Neuroscience ku sukulu ya ukachenjede ya Cincinnati College of Medicine.
mt0: <pad> "If you go to a coffee shop frequently, the servers know what you like and will make it for you, and that feels good," said Dr. Maria Espinola, a psychiatrist and professor of psychiatry and behavioral neuroscience at the Cincinnati College of Medicine.</s>

en: "It feels good to be recognized, to know that people are expecting you, to know that people care about you, to know that you belong, because the need for belonging and human connection is a fundamental need that we all have, and it's important to have that fulfilled in different ways," Espinola says.
nya: "Zimakhala bwino kudziwa kuti anthu amakuzindikira, akukudikira komanso amasamala za iwe, komanso kudziwa kuti ndiwe m'modzi mwa iwo chifukwa kufuna kukhala m'modzi wa gulu ndi kulumikizana ndi anthu ndi chimodzi mwa zinthu zomwe tonse timafuna ndipo ndikofunika kuti tonse timapeza izi munjira zosiyanasiyana," atero a Espinola.
mt0: <pad> "It's good to know that people recognize you, care about you and care for you, and to know that you are one of them because the desire to be part of a group and connect with others is one of the things that we all want and it's important that we find this in different ways," Espinola said.</s>

en: "So, places like third places can allow us to do that."
nya: "Kotero malo achitatu amatilola kuchita zimenezi."
mt0: <pad> "So the three places allow us to do that."</s>

en: In the past, churches and other houses of worship have been a third place for many Americans.
nya: Kalekale, tchalitchi ndi nyumba zopemphelera zinali malo achitatu kwa anthu ambiri a ku America.
mt0: <pad> For a long time, churches and mosques were important sites for many Americans.</s>

en: In 2019, 67% of people surveyed said they have a third place — a coffee shop, bar, restaurant, park or other place in their community that they visit regularly.
nya: Mu 2019, anthu 67 pa 100 aliwonse omwe anafufuzidwa anapeza kuti ali ndi malo achitatu- malo ogulitsira khofi, malo omwela mowa, malo odyera, malo ochezera kapena malo ena aliwonse m'dera lawo omwe amapitako kawirikawiri.
mt0: <pad> In 2019, 67 percent of those surveyed said they had at least three places- coffee shop, bar, restaurant, social club or other place in their neighborhood that they frequently visited.</s>

en: That number dropped to 56% in 2021 — a number that could have been affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.
nya: Nambalayi inatsika mu 2021 kufika pa anthu 56 pa 100 aliwonse- nambala yomwe inatsika kamba ka mliri wa COVID-19.
mt0: <pad> The number fell in 2021 to 56 per 100 people- a drop attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic.</s>

en: "What we found was that people who had a third place were much more connected to their community," says Cox. "They're much more likely to engage in other activities there.
nya: "Tinapeza kuti anthu omwe ali ndi malo achitatu anali olumikizana ndi dera lawo," anatero a Cox. "Ali ndi kuthekera kochita nawo zinthu zina kumeneko."
mt0: <pad> "We found that the people who own these four properties were connected with their community," said Cox. "They have the opportunity to participate in other activities there."</s>

en: They are much more trusting of their neighbors. There's a whole great array of positive social outcomes that were connected to having a third place … and for a lot of Americans, it's a coffee shop or a cafe."
nya: Amakhulupilira anthu okhala nawo pafupi. Pali ndandanda wa zotsatira zabwino zokhudza ubale zomwe zimalumikizana ndi kukhala ndi malo achitatu…ndipo kwa anthu ambiri a ku America, malowa ndi malo ogulitsira khofi kapena malo omwera.
mt0: <pad> He trusts his neighbors. There are a long list of positive social effects associated with having three...and for most Americans, these are coffee shops or restaurants.</s>

en: What coffee shops have in their favor is that they can be found almost everywhere, all over the country, and anyone who wants to can stop by regularly.
nya: Ubwino wa malo ogulitsira khofi ndi woti malowa amapezeka kulokonse m'dzikomo ndipo aliyense amene akufuna akhoza kupitako kawirikawiri.
mt0: <pad> The advantage of coffee shops is that they are located all over the country and anybody who wants can frequent them often.</s>

en: And many are open most days of the week.
nya: Ambiri mwa iwo amatsegula masiku ambiri a mkati mwa sabata.
mt0: <pad> Most of them are open many days a week.</s>

en: Cox says even brief coffee shop encounters can increase a sense of belonging.
nya: A Cox ati kukumana kwa nthawi yochepa ku malo ogulitsira khofi kukhoza kupititsa patsogolo mtima wodziwa kuti ndiwe m'modzi mwa gulu.
mt0: <pad> A Cox and a short meeting at a coffee shop can boost the sense of knowing that you are part of the group.</s>

en: "I think there's a lot of potential here, and a lot of it is unrealized potential," Cox says.
nya: "Ndikuona ngati pali kuthekera, kuthekera komwe sikunazindikiridwe," atero a Cox.
mt0: <pad> "I think there is a possibility, a possibility that has not been identified," Cox said.</s>

en: "But in terms of what they could do, there's a lot there.
nya: "Koma kutengera ndi zomwe angathe kuchita, pali zambiri pamenepo.
mt0: <pad> "But based on what he can do, there is a lot there."</s>

en: I've been in places where the same group of folks come in there to play chess.
nya: Ndapitako ku malo kome gulu lomwelo la anthu limapita kukachita masewera a chess.
mt0: <pad> I've been to a place where the same group of people go to play chess.</s>

en: Or they have their informal bunch of retirees. … They just got together, and they talked and chatted and caught up with each other. … I don't know where else they would have gone — maybe a church, but maybe not — to share information, to encourage each other to maybe get involved in an activity.
nya: Kapena ali ndi gulu la anthu omasuka omwe anapuma ntchito…Amakumana, kuyankhulana, kucheza ndi kusangalala wina ndi mnzake….Sindikudziwa ngati pali kwina komwe akanatha kupita- mwina ku tchalitchi, mwina ayi- kukagawana uthenga, kulimbikitsana kutenga gawo pa zochitika .
mt0: <pad> Or he has a group of relaxed retired people...They meet, talk, flirt and enjoy each other....I don't know if they could go anywhere else- maybe church, maybe not- to share information, encourage each other to participate in events.</s>

en: And I think that is what is so powerful about coffee shops."
nya: Ndipo ndikuganiza kuti izi ndi zomwe zili mphamvu ya malo ogulitsira khofi.
mt0: <pad> And I think that's the power of coffee shops.</s>

en: What US Mayors Are Most Worried About After the Pandemic
nya: Zomwe mafumu a mizinda ku U.S akudandaula ukatha mliri
mt0: <pad> The U.S. mayors are complaining about the economy after the pandemic</s>

en: Americas mayors are most concerned about the lingering mental health effects of the COVID-19 pandemic, according to a nationwide survey of 126 mayors conducted during the summer of 2021.
nya: Mafumu a mizinda ku U.S ndiwokhudziwa ndi kutsalira kwa zotsatira za mliri wa COVID-19 pa maganizo a anthu, kutengera ndi kafukufuku wa mafumu a mizinda 126, yemwe anachitika m'dzikolo mu nyengo yotentha mu 2021.
mt0: <pad> U.S. mayors are concerned about the impact of COVID-19 on public opinion, according to a survey of 126 mayors conducted across the country in the summer of 2021.</s>

en: The respondents headed cities with at least 75,000 residents. The local leaders are still focused on traditional issues such as violent crime, the economy and infrastructure, but they are most concerned about the pandemics long-term impact on the mental health of their constituents.
nya: Oyankhawa amatsogolera mizinda ya anthu pafupifupi 75,000. Atsogoleri a madera ang'ono-ang'ono akanali ndi chidwi pa nkhani monga milandu ya ziwawa, zachuma ndi zomangamanga, koma iwo akukhudzidwa ndi zotsatira za nthawi yaitali za mliri pa maganizo a anthu a misinkhu yonse m'madera awo.
mt0: <pad> These respondents lead cities of about 75,000. Small-town leaders still have interests in crime, finance and construction, but they are concerned about the long-term effects of the pandemic on the attitudes of all ages in their communities.</s>

en: Mental health was top of mind for Michael Udine when he was sworn in as mayor of Broward County, Florida, in November 2021.
nya: Thanzi labwino lokhudza maganizo ndilo linali patsogolo pa maganizo a Michael Udine pamene ankalumbira kukhala mfumu ya mzinda wa Broward County, ku Florida, mu Novembala, 2021.
mt0: <pad> Mental health was the top priority for Michael Udine when he swore in as Broward County mayor in November 2021.</s>

en: "Everything that was a potential issue pre-pandemic has pretty much been exacerbated by the pandemic," he says. "There were issues going into the pandemic, and it was becoming more and more important on everyone's radar screen about the mental health of people of all ages. And I think the pandemic pretty much supercharged those issues."
nya: "Chilichonse chomwe chinali ndikuthekera kokhala vuto mliri usanabwere, zapitilira kukhala mavuto aakulu kamba ka mliriwu," iwo atero. "Panali mavuto pamene mliri unayamba, ndipo kunali kofunikira kuti aliyense azindikire ubwino wa thanzi labwino pa maganizo a anthu a misinkhu yonse. Ndikuganiza kuti mliriwu unawonjezera mavuto amenewa."
mt0: <pad> "Whatever could have been a problem before the pandemic became a problem after the pandemic," they said. "There were problems when the pandemic began, and it was important for everyone to realize the importance of good health in the minds of people of all ages. I think the pandemic increased those problems."</s>

en: It is not unusual for large outbreaks of disease to have a negative impact on mental health, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which reports that rates of anxiety and depressive disorders among adults increased during the pandemic.
nya: Sizachilendo kuti kufala kwa matenda kukhale ndi zotsatira pa maganizo a anthu, kutengera ndi lipoti lomwe bungwe loona za matenda ndi kupewa kwake la Centers for Disease Control and Prevention lapereka, loti chiwerengero cha nkhawa ndi kukhumudwa pakati pa anthu akuluakulu chakwera panthawi ya mliriwu.
mt0: <pad> It is not uncommon for epidemics to have a psychological impact, according to a report by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention that the rates of depression and anxiety in elderly people increased during the pandemic.</s>

en: The pandemic has also adversely influenced the emotional and mental health of about one-third of Americas youth.
nya: Mliriwu wawononganso maganizo ndi thanzi lokhudza maganizo a theka la achinyamata ku America.
mt0: <pad> The Hurricane also affected the minds and health of half of American young people.</s>

en: "What we've seen is just such anxiety, kids who wouldn't ordinarily have a meltdown, because it's so much change and difficulty adjusting to transitions," Maryland psychologist Mary Karapetian Alvord told VOA last month. "We've also seen a lot more sadness and depression."
nya: "Zomwe taona ndi nkhawa zokha, kwa ana omwe samaoneka okhumudwa kale, koma chifukwa cha kusintha kwakukulu,ndizovuta kuzolowera kusintha kwa zinthu," woona za maganizo ku Maryland, a Mary Karapetian Alvord anawuza VOA mwezi watha. "Tawonanso chisoni ndi kukhumudwa kwambiri."
mt0: <pad> "We have seen a lot of concern, for children who did not seem to be sad before, but because of the large change, it's difficult to adapt to the change," said Maryland psychologist Mary Karapetian Alvord last month. "We also saw a lot of sadness and very much depression."</s>

en: Early on in the pandemic, mayors were more focused on city operations, budget shortfalls and the threat the pandemic posed to small businesses, according to David Glick, an associate professor of political science at Boston University and a co-author of the 2021 Menino Survey of Mayors.
nya: Kumayambiliro kwa mliriwu, mafumu a mizinda anali ndi chidwi pa zochitika m'mizinda, mavuto a ndondomeko za chuma komanso chiopsezo chomwe mliriwu umabweretsa pa malonda ang'ono ang'ono, kutengera ndi zomwe anena a David Glick, wothandiza kuphunzitsa zandale ku sukulu ya ukachenjede ya Boston komanso analemba nawo kafukufuku wa Menno Survey of Mayors mu 2021.
mt0: <pad> At the beginning of the pandemic, mayors were concerned about city events, economic problems and the risks the pandemic posed to small business, said David Glick, an adjunct professor of politics at Boston College and co-author of the Menno Survey of Mayors in 2021.</s>

en: "Some of those concerns still remain, but what we saw more of in 2021 … is concern about some of the long-term impacts on individual residents," Glick says. "Concerns about polarization over vaccines and just people being pushed to their limits … and certainly less on their city budgets and revenues and having to cut programs and some of those types of things that were probably more top of mind earlier in the pandemic."
nya: "Zodandaulitsa zikanalipo koma zomwe tinaona mu 2021…ndi kukhudzidwa ndi zotsatira zanthawi yaitali pa anthu okhala okha," atero a Glick. "Kukhudzidwa ndi kugawanika pa nkhani ya katemera komanso kupanikizidwa kwa anthu…Izi zachititsa kusiya kulabadira kwenikweni za ndondomeko yachuma cha mzinda ndi misonkho komanso kusiya kuchita zinthu zomwe zinali patsogolo kumayambiliro kwa mliriwu.
