mt0: <pad> "The regrets would still be there but what we saw in 2021...is the impact of the long-term effects on our own," said Glick.</s>

en: Over half of mayors, 52%, are worried about "lingering mental health challenges and trauma," according to the survey. Additionally, more than one-third of mayors, 37%, are worried about learning loss among young people.
nya: Kafukufuku wati mafumu a mizinda 52 pa 100 aliwonse akudandaula za "kutsalira kwa mavuto a mmaganizo ndi mantha obwera kamba ka zochitika zam'mbuyo." Kuwonjezera apo, theka la mafumu a mizinda lomwe ndi 37 pa 100 aliwonse, akudandaula za kusiya kuphunzira kwa achinyamata.
mt0: <pad> The survey found that 52 percent of mayors complained about "lingering mental health problems and fears stemming from past events." In addition, nearly half of mayors, 37 percent, complained about the dropout of young people from education.</s>

en: "Second only to mental health and trauma, and they're probably not totally independent concerns," Glick says. "It is part of that shift of mayors concerns from immediate threats to businesses closing and people getting sick, to some of these longer-term consequences that are going to persist in the future. And learning loss among their students, theyre worried it's going to persist for many, many, many years into the future. It's hard to make up for."
nya: "Chachiwiri kwa mavuto a mmaganizo ndi mantha obwera kamba ka zochitika zam'mbuyo, ndipo sizokhudza kwenikweni," atero a Glick. "Ndi gawo la kusintha kwa zokhudza mafumu a mzinda kuchoka pa ziopsezo zotseka malonda komanso kudwala kwa anthu kufika pa zotsatira za nthawi yaitali zomwe zidzakhalepobe mtsogolo. Kusiya sukulu kwa ophunzira, kukudandaulitsa zomwe zidzachitike kwa zaka zochuluka zomwe zikubwera kutsogolo. Ndizovuta kubwezeretsa."
mt0: <pad> "The second of mental health problems is fear stemming from past events, and it's very real," said Glick. "It's part of the change in city governance from threats of closure of businesses and illnesses to long-term effects that will continue for many years to come."</s>

en: According to the survey, other top concerns for Americas mayors include the financial insecurity of low-income residents (33%), the closing of small businesses (29%) and increased crime and violence (26%).
nya: Kafukufuku wati, zina zomwe akudandaula mafumu a mizinda ndi kusowa kwa chuma kwa anthu amene amapeza ndalama zochepa omwe ndi anthu 33 pa 100 aliwonse, kutseka malonda ang'ono angono' omwe ndi 29 pa 100 aliwonse, komanso kuchuluka kwa ziwawa ndi 26%.
mt0: <pad> The survey shows that other problems the mayors are complaining about are economic inequality for low-income people who make 33 per cent, the closure of small business which is 29 per cent, and the increase in crime with 26%.</s>

en: Just 7% of mayors are worried about the shift to remote work and the long-term impact that could have on outmigration — people moving away from their cities.
nya: Mafumu a mizinda 7 pa 100 aliwonse ndi omwe akudandaula za kusintha kogwilira ntchito kutali komanso zotsatira za nthawi yaitali zomwe zingakhudze kusamuka-anthu kuchoka mmizinda yawo.
mt0: <pad> Seven out of every 100 mayors are complaining about the change in workforce and long-term effects that could affect the population shift from their cities.</s>

en: The $350 billion in funding from the American Rescue Plan to local and state governments could help mayors address some of their concerns. The survey found that 78% of mayors believe the money will allow them to make meaningful change.
nya: Thandizo la ndalama zokwana 350 biliyoni U.S Dollars lochoka ku bungwe la American Rescue Plan kwa ma boma ang'ono ang'ono ndi ma boma aakulu, likhoza kuthandiza mafumu a mmizinda kuthana ndi ena mwa mavuto awo. Kafukufuku anapezanso kuti mafumu a mmizinda 78 pa 100 aliwonse amakhulupilira kuti ndalama ziwathandiza kusintha zinthu.
mt0: <pad> The American Rescue Plan's 350 billion U.S. dollars in aid to small and medium-sized governments could help mayors deal with some of their problems. The study also found that 78 percent of the 100 mayors believed the money would help them change things.</s>

en: "What we're seeing is a large majority are using it for things they consider to be transformative and will make major changes to their cities," Glick says, "instead of feeling obligated or feeling the necessity to use it to plug up over-budget gaps to keep the doors open and the lights on."
nya: "Zomwe tikuwona ndi zoti, ambiri mwa iwo akugwiritsa ntchito ndalamazi pa zinthu zomwe akuganiza kuti zikhoza kusintha mizinda yawo," anatero a Glick, "mmalo moona ngati akuyenera kugwiritsa ntchito ndalamazi kuwonjezera ndondomeko yachuma kuti zitseko zikhalebe zotsegula komanso magetsi oyaka."
mt0: <pad> "What we see is that, most of them are spending the money on things that they think will change their cities," said Glick, "instead of seeing if they should be spending the money to boost economic programs to keep doors open and lights on."</s>

en: Young Compete Against Old in Hottest US Rental Market in a Decade
nya: Achinyamata akupikisana ndi akulu pa msika wochita lendi nyumba ku U.S mu zaka khumi
mt0: <pad> The young people are competing with the elderly in the U.S. rental market for the past 20 years.</s>

en: Renting an apartment can be a challenge for new college graduates who are facing the hottest U.S. rental market in a decade, along with some unexpected competition from millennials — people aged 24 to 40 — and even baby boomers — the over-57 club.
nya: Kupeza nyumba yochita lendi kukhoza kukhala vuto makamaka kwa omwe amaliza kumene maphunziro awo a ukachenjede pomwe akumana ndi msika wochititsa lendi ku U.S mu zaka khumi, pamodzi ndi mpikisano womwe sanawuyembekezere ndi anthu obadwa mu zaka za pakati pa 1981 ndi 1996, zaka 24 mpaka 40- komanso anthu opitilira zaka 57 omwe anabadwa nkhondo yachiwiri yadziko lonse litatha.
mt0: <pad> Finding a place to rent can be difficult, especially for recent college graduates who have been exposed to the U.S. rental market in the past 10 years, along with unexpected competition from people born between 1981 and 1996, 24 to 40, and over 57 who were born after World War II.</s>

en: "You have aging millennials who are creating families who should be moving from rental situations into ownership but, because of the lack of housing supply, that has been stopped in a lot of instances. And so, what you see is the aging millennial population continues to rent," says Doug Ressler, manager of business intelligence at Yardi-Matrix, a commercial real estate data and research firm.
nya: "Tili ndi anthu a zaka zakubadwa za pakati pa 24 ndi 40, omwe ali ndi mabanja ndipo amayenera kusiya kupanga lendi ndi kukhala ndi nyumba zawo, koma kuchepa kwa nyumba ndikomwe kwaletsa izi. Choncho anthu a zaka zapakati pa 24 ndi 40 akukula pamodzi ndi chiwerengero chawo ndipo akupitiliza kuchita lendi," anatero a Doug Ressler,mkulu wa malonda ku Yardi-Matrix, kampani yogulitsa nyumba komanso yofufuza.
mt0: <pad> "We have a population of people between 24 and 40, who are married and should stop renting and buy their own homes, but the shortage of homes has stopped this. So the population of people between 24 and 40 is growing with their population and they're continuing to rent," said Doug Ressler, senior vice president of Yardi-Matrix, a real estate agent and research company.</s>

en: "It's not just about millennials, it's not just about [Gen] Z [people under 24], we also see that boomers are making a transition, he added. "Their percentage of moving into rental properties is growing in the last five years."
nya: "Sizokhudza anthu a zaka 24 mpaka 40 okha ndi [Gen] Z omwe ndi anthu a zaka zosapitilira 24, tikuwonanso kuti anthu a zaka zoposa 57 nawonso akusintha, iwo anawonjezera. "Chiwerengero chawo cholowa m'nyumba za lendi chakhala chikukwera mu zaka zisanu zapitazo."
mt0: <pad> "It's not just about the 24 to 40 year olds and [Gen] Z, which are under 24, we also see that people over 57 are changing, they added.</s>

en: There are a variety of reasons older people are opting for rentals, according to Ressler.
nya: A Ressler ati palii zifukwa zosiyanasiyana zomwe zikupangitsa anthu achikulire kusankha kukhala pa lendi.
mt0: <pad> A Ressler said there are a number of reasons why elderly people choose to live on a rental.</s>

en: "They've lived in a home for so long and they want to be able to reduce their expenses on a fixed income," he says. "They want to live in a social cohort, like a retirement community, and things like that where it's much more socially amenable to them."
nya: "Akhala ku malo osamalira anthu achikulire kwa nthawi yaitali kotero akufuna kuchepetsa ndalama zogwiritsa ntchito kuchoka ku ndalama zomwe amalandira," iwo anatero. Akufuna kukhala pamodzi ndi anthu, malo apawokha, ndi ena otero komwe akhoza kukhala bwino."
mt0: <pad> "He's been in a nursing home for a long time so he wants to cut back on his costs from his income," they said. He wants to live with people, a place of his own, and other like that where he can be well."</s>

en: The asking price of apartment rentals was up 10.7% in September 2021 compared to last year at the same time, according to the National Association of Realtors (NAR).
nya: Bungwe logulitsa nyumba la National Assembly of Realtors (NAR), lati mtengo wochitira lendi unakwera ndi 10.7% mu September kusiyana ndi nthawi yomweyo chaka chatha.
mt0: <pad> The National Assembly of Realtors (NAR) reported that rents increased by 10.7% in September compared with the same time last year.</s>

en: "It's a hot market. We have never seen this market so hot in the last decade," says Gay Cororaton, NARs senior economist and director of housing and commercial research. "The average rent growth, year-over-year, is about 3-to-5%. We're seeing 11% rent growth now, so, clearly, way above trends weve had in the past."
nya: "Ndi msika wotentha. Sitinawonepo msikawu ukuyenda chonchi mu zaka khumi zapitazo," atero a Gay Cororaton, mkulu wa zachuma komanso woyang'anira nyumba ndi kukufuza malonda. "Chiwerenegro cha ochita lendi chimakwera pachaka chilichonse ndi 3 kapena 5%. Tsopano chiwerengerochi chakwera ndi 11%, kupitilira mmene zimakhalira kale."
mt0: <pad> "It's a hot market. We haven't seen it like this for the past 10 years," said Gay Cororaton, chief executive and director of finance and real estate at HomeHub. "The number of renters has grown by 3 or 5% every year. Therefore, the number of renters has grown by 11%, faster than ever before."</s>

en: Renters are feeling the squeeze because the COVID-19 pandemic caused supply chain issues, slowing down home building in the United States. Instead of the usual 5-to-6 month supply of available single-family homes, supply dropped below two months in January 2021. The lack of housing supply means millennials are having a harder time buying a single-family home, which has been the traditional trajectory in the past.
nya: Ochita lendi apanikizika chifukwa mliri wa COVID-19 umachedwetsa kubwera kwa zinthu, zomwenso zachedwetsa kumanga nyumba ku United States. M'malo mochita ngati kale kuti pa miyezi isanu kapena isanu ndi umodzi nyumba yokhala banja limodzi imakhala yapezeka, tsopano izi zabwerera m'mbuyo ndi miyezi iwiri kuchoka mu Januwale 2021. Kusowa kwa nyumba kukutanthauza kuti anthu a zaka zapakati pa 24 mpaka 40 akuvutika kuti agule nyumba yokhala banja limodzi, ngati momwe zimachitikira m'mbuyomu.
mt0: <pad> Renters are under pressure because of the COVID-19 pandemic, which has also delayed construction in the United States. The shortage of housing means that people aged 24 to 40 are having difficulty buying a single-family home, as they have been in the past.</s>

en: "The whole building industry was beset by supply chain issues," Cororaton says. "Shipments couldn't come in, the price of lumber was rising, manufacturing slowed, workers could not come in [to work], so you have shortages of frames, appliances. So, essentially, just a short supply."
nya: "Ogwira ntchito ya zomangamanga anakhudzidwa ndi mavuto opeza katundu," anatero a Cororaton. "Katundu wochoka kwina samatha kubwera, matabwa amakwera mtengo, kukonza zinthu kumachedwa, ogwira ntchito samabwera ku ntchito, mafelemu ndi zipangizo zina zinachepa. Tingoti pali zinthu zochepa."
mt0: <pad> "The construction industry was affected by supply chain problems," said Cororaton. "Products were delayed, wood was overpriced, repairs were delayed, workers didn't show up, frames and other materials were short. We can only say there are few things."</s>

en: The housing supply got even tighter during the pandemic as more investors put their money into housing, according to Cororaton, while existing homeowners looked for second homes.
nya: A Cororaton ati kupeza nyumba kunavutanso nthawi ya mliri pamene anthu ambiri anagwiritsa ntchito ndalama zawo pomanga nyumba pamene anthu omwe ali ndi nyumba kale amayang'ana nyumba zachiwiri.
mt0: <pad> The Cororaton said that finding a house was also difficult during the pandemic as many people used their money to build houses while those who already had houses were looking for second homes.</s>

en: "With the pandemic, there was also a big demand for second homes, for vacation homes. Typically, vacation homes accounted for just about 5% [of the market]," she says. "Early this summer they rose to about 8%. So again, strong demand and strong imbalance of demand and supply caused home prices to rise, made them less affordable."
nya: "Malingana ndi mliriwu, chiwerengero cha anthu ofuna nyumba zachiwiri kapena nyumba zokapumulako, chinachuluka. Nthawi zambiri, nyumba zopumulirako zimakwanitsa 5% ya msika," iwo anatero. "Kumayambiliro kwa nyengo yotentha ino panali kukwera ndi 8%. Choncho kukula kwa chiwerengero cha anthu ofuna nyumba ndi kusagwirizana kwa chiwerengero cha wogula ndi wogulitsa ndi komwe kwapangitsa kuti mitengo ya nyumba ikwere, kuchititsa kuti anthu ena akanike kugula.
mt0: <pad> "According to the flood, the number of people looking for second homes or holiday homes increased. Therefore the increase in the number of applicants and the unevenness of the number of buyers and sellers has caused the rise in house prices, which has caused some people to be unable to buy," they said.</s>

en: The hottest rental markets right now are in the West and South. More renters are moving to Dallas and Houston in Texas, followed by Atlanta, Georgia; New York; Los Angeles; Austin, Texas; Phoenix, Arizona; and Washington, D.C., according to NAR.
nya: NAR yati misika yochititsa lendi yomwe ikuyenda kwambiri panopa ndi ya kumadzulo ndi ku m'mwera. Ambiri ofuna kuchita lendi akusamukila ku Dallas ndi ku Houston, ku Texas, motsatizana ndi Atlanta ku Georgia; New York ku Los Angeles, Austin ku Texas; Phoenix ku Arizona ndi Washington, D.C.
mt0: <pad> NAR said the most successful rental markets are in the west and south. Most renters are moving to Dallas and Houston, Texas, along with Atlanta in Georgia; New York in Los Angeles, Austin in Texas; Phoenix in Arizona and Washington, D.C.</s>

en: Cororaton expects the coming year to be a little better but says the housing shortage is likely to continue for the next few years.
nya: A Cororaton akuyembekeza kuti mu chaka chikubwerachi zinthu zikhalako bwino koma kuchepa kwa nyumba kupitilirabe  kwa zaka zingapo mtsogolomu.
mt0: <pad> The Cororaton residents expect things to get better next year but the shortage of homes will continue for several years.</s>

en: "You know, the old adage of moving from rentals into homeownership, that whole polemic may be changing," says Ressler. "The sweet spot was always the millennials, and now the millennials are being replaced by the [Gen] Zs, but the millennials are staying longer and the Zs are coming on board, and now you've got the demographic of the boomers … What it means is a very profitable and dynamic [rental] market that's going to continue to grow."
nya: "Mukudziwa kuyankhula kwakale koti kuchoka pa lendi ndi kukhala mwini nyumba, maganizo amenewa mwina akusintha," atero a Ressler. "Omwe amakonda kuchita lendi kale anali anthu a zaka zapakat pa 24 mpaka 40, koma anabwezeretsedwa ndi [Gen] Z, omwe ndi anthu a zaka zosaposera 24. Koma anthu a zaka zapakati pa 24 mpaka 40 akukhalitsa ndipo anthu a zaka zosaposera 24 akuwapeza. Tsopano pali chiwerengero cha anthu a zaka zoposera 57. Izi zikutanthauza msika wamphamvu wochititsa lendi komanso phindu lochuluka lomwe lipitilire kukwera."
mt0: <pad> "You know the old talk of moving out of a rental to buy, that may be changing," said Ressler. "The renter's market is getting bigger and bigger, and the renters are going to continue to make more profit."</s>

en: Are COVID-19 Restrictions Stunting Children’s Immune Systems?
nya: Kodi ziletso za COVID-19 zikuchepetsa kukula kwa chitetezo mmatupi mwa ana?
mt0: <pad> Yes</s>

en: Some medical experts have expressed concern that COVID-19 preventative measures, like masking and remote schooling, are potentially weakening childrens immune systems by shielding them from the usual childhood illnesses.
nya: Akatswiri a zaumoyo ena asonyeza kukhudzidwa ponena kuti njira zopewera COVID-19, monga kuvala zotchinga kukamwa ndi kuphunzilira pa intaneti, ndi zomwe zikufooketsa chitetezo cha mmatupi mwa ana chifukwa ana sakudwalanso matenda oyenera kudwala pa umwana wawo.
mt0: <pad> Some health experts have expressed concern that measures to prevent COVID-19, such as wearing masks and online education, are weakening the immune system of children because children are not getting enough physical exercise to recover from their childhood illnesses.</s>

en: "There are a lot of reasons to believe that kids need to be exposed to things to keep their immunity complex, so that should they encounter something very dangerous, they have aspects of their immunity that might cross over and help protect them against those things," says Sara Sawyer, a professor of molecular, cellular and developmental biology at the University of Colorado Boulder.
nya: "Pali zifukwa zambiri zopangitsa kukhulupilira kuti ana amayenera kuyikidwa poyera ku zinthu kuti chitetezo chawo cha mnthupi chilimbe mu njira zosiyanasiyana, kuti akadzakumana ndi zina zoopsa, adzakhale ndi mbali ina ya chitetezo chawo cha mnthupi yomwe idzathandize kuwateteza ku zinthu zimenezi," anatero a Sara Sawyer, polofesa tinthu tosaoneka, maselo ndi zinthu zamoyo ku sukulu ya ukachenjede ya Colorado Boulder.
mt0: <pad> "There are many reasons to believe that children should be exposed to things in different ways so that when they come into contact with something more dangerous, they will have another part of their body's defenses that will help them protect against that danger," said Sara Sawyer, professor of microorganisms, cells and life science at the University of Colorado Boulder.</s>

en: At birth, vulnerable infants get antibodies from their mothers breast milk, which helps protect them until they can build their own immunity.
nya: Pobadwa, makanda opanda chitetezo chilichonse amatenga chitetezo kuchoka ku mkaka wa mmawere wa amayi awo omwe umawateteza kufikira nthawi yomwe adzakhale ndi chitetezo chawo.
mt0: <pad> When born, all babies are completely unprotected and receive protection from their mother's milk which protects them until they develop their own immune system.</s>

en: Its no accident that babies start putting things in their mouths as soon as they gain enough dexterity to pick things up.  "They're doing that because they're sampling the environment and building their immunity. That's an evolutionary trait," Sawyer says.
nya: Sikuti ndi ngozi kuti ana amayamba kuyika chilichonse mkamwa mwawo pamene ayamba kutha kugwira zinthu. "Amachita izi chifukwa amakhala akuzindikira malo omwe awazungulira komanso kumanga chitetezo chawo cha mnthupi. Uku ndiye kusintha," a Sawyer anatelo.
mt0: <pad> No, it's not a danger that children start putting things in their mouths when they can hold things. "They do this because they are being aware of their environment and building their body security. This is the change," said Sawyer.</s>

en: "Theyre exposing their body to germs in a certain, level way to build their immunity.
nya: "Sakubisa thupi lawo kwa tizilombo toyambitsa matenda, mwa njira ina akumanga chitetezo cha mnthupi mwawo.
mt0: <pad> "They don't cover their body against germs, but instead build a defense system for their body."</s>

en: So, some people would argue that childhood illnesses, like colds and stomach bugs, build our immunity so that when more dangerous things come along, we're prepared and we don't get as sick from those more dangerous things."
nya: Anthu ena akhoza kunena kuti matenda a ku umwana monga chimfine, kuwawa kwa m'mimba zimamanga chitetezo mnthupi kuti zinthu zina zoopsa zikadzabwera, zidzapeze kuti takonzeka ndipo sitingadwale ndi zinthu zimenezi.
mt0: <pad> Some people may say that childhood illnesses such as colds and coughs build a defense system so that when something more dangerous comes, we will be prepared and not be ill.</s>

en: Even before the pandemic, epidemiological evidence suggested that children in more developed countries, where handwashing and the use of sanitizer are more prevalent, might have less-developed immune systems compared to kids in developing nations who are routinely exposed to more bacteria, viruses and allergens.
nya: Ngakhale nthawi imene mliri unali usanabwere, sayansi yoona za kufala ndi kupewa matenda, inachitira umboni kuti ana a m'mayiko otukuka, komwe amasamba mmanja komanso kugwiritsa ntchito mankhwala ophera tizilombo toyambitsa matenda pafupipafupi, atha kukhala ndi chitetezo chofooka mnthupi kusiyana ndi ana a m'mayiko omwe akutukuka kumene omwe amakhala poyera ndi tizilombo toyambitsa matenda komanso kudwala kamba kodana ndi zinthu.
mt0: <pad> Even before the pandemic, epidemiology and infectious disease science reported that children in developed countries, where they wash their hands and use antiseptics regularly, may have a weaker immune system than children in developing countries who are exposed to germs and suffer from a lack of social support.</s>

en: This makes kids in more industrialized countries more vulnerable to developing autoimmune diseases, according to whats known as the "hygiene hypothesis."
nya: Izi zimapangitsa ana a m'mayiko otukuka kudwala matenda omwe thupi limayambitsa lokha kutengera ndi kafukufuku wa ukhondo wotchedwa, "hygiene hypothesis."
mt0: <pad> This causes children in developed countries to develop autoimmune diseases, according to the "hygiene hypothesis," a research of hygiene.</s>

en: "The hygiene hypothesis is actually quite controversial because it's thought that our exposure to microbes isn't the only factor," says Cody Warren, a virologist and immunologist who is a postdoctoral fellow at the University of Colorado Boulder.
nya: Kafukufuku wa ukhondo, hygiene hypothesis, amabweretsa maganizo osiyanasiyana pomwe ena amati kukhala osabisika ku tizilombo toyambitsa matenda si chifukwa chokha," anatero a Cody Warren, wowona za tizilombo toyambitsa matenda komanso chitetezo mnthupi yemwe anali dotolo wa ku sukulu ya ukachenjede ya Colorado Boulder.
mt0: <pad> The hygiene hypothesis provides different views, where some suggest that being uncovered from germs is not the only reason," said Dr. Cody Warren, an infectious disease specialist and former professor of medical school at the University of Colorado Boulder.</s>

en: "A lot of this could also be dictated by genetics, diet, and the environment that we live in.
nya: "Zambiri mwa izi zikhoza kudziwika potengera chibadwa, zakudya ndi malo amene atizungulira.
mt0: <pad> "Many of these can be distinguished by race, diet and the environment that surrounds us.</s>

en: That also shapes our immune system… it's a real multifactorial thing that we can't fully account for just by wearing masks.
nya: Izi zimawumbanso chitetezo chathu chamnthupi…pali zinthu zambiri zomwe sitingathane nazo pongovala zotchinga kukamwa.
mt0: <pad> This also weakens our body protection...there are many things that we can't fight with a mask.</s>

en: There are other things that go into that equation."
nya: Palinso zinthu zina zokhudzana nazo."
mt0: <pad> There are other things that are related to them.</s>

en: Warren, the father of three young children, says spending lots of time outdoors is one way to balance the negatives of isolation.
nya: A Warren, omwe ali ndi ana aangono atatu, ati kukhala nthawi yaitali panja ndi njira imodzi yothana ndi zotsatira za kudzipatula.
mt0: <pad> Warren, who has three young children, said spending more time outdoors is one way to deal with the effects of isolation.</s>

en: "Just exploring microbes in the environment also is benefiting [and] training our immune system," Warren says. "Our immune systems get trained through the foods that we eat, which also have microorganisms on them.
nya: "Kufufuza tizilombo m'malo omwe atizungulira ndikofunika komanso kumalimbitsa chitetezo chathu cha mnthupi," anatero a Warren. "Chitetezo cha mnthupi chimalimba kudzera mu zakudya zomwe timadya, zomwenso zimakhala ndi tizilombo.
mt0: <pad> "Checking for parasites in our environment is important and strengthens our immune system," said Warren. "Our immune system is strengthened through the food we eat, which also contains parasites."</s>

en: And so, despite the fact that we've kind of been hunkered down a little bit, I do feel that our immune systems will catch up."
nya: Choncho, ngakhale kuti tasimphina pang'ono, chitetezo chathu cha mnthupi chibwelera."
mt0: <pad> However, even though we were slightly injured, our physical protection was restored.</s>

en: There are other things parents can do, he says, to boost their childrens immune systems during pandemic times.  "One of the most important things you can do is just to stay up to date on vaccines.
nya: Pali zinthu zina zomwe makolo angachite pofuna kukweza chitetezo cha mnthupi mwa ana awo munthawi ya mliri. "Imodzi mwa zinthu zofunika kuchita ndi kulandira katemela watsopano aliyense."
mt0: <pad> There are some things parents can do to increase the immune system of their children during the pandemic. "One of the important things to do is to accept each new case of the virus."</s>

en: That's one of the best ways that we have to train our immune systems," Warren says.
nya: Iyi ndi njira yabwino kwambiri yolimbitsa chitetezo mmatupi mwathu," anatero a Warren.
mt0: <pad> This is the best way to strengthen our bodies," said Ms. Warren.</s>

en: "But also, equally important is making sure our children have a good diet and they regulate stress.
nya: "Koma njira ina yofunikanso ndi kuwonetsetsa kuti ana athu akudya zakudya zopatsa thanzi komanso amachotsa nkhawa.
mt0: <pad> But another important way is to make sure that our children eat healthy food and manage stress.</s>

en: It's been well documented that both of those — having a good diet, a less stressful environment — can have a positive impact on our immune system."
nya: Zatsimikizika kuti njira zonsezi- kudya zakudya zopatsa thanzi komanso kukhala malo opanda nkhawa- zili ndi ubwino pa chitetezo chathu cha mnthupi."
mt0: <pad> It is known that both these strategies-eating healthy food and living in a stress-free environment-have benefits on our body's protection.</s>

en: Once public health officials say masks are no longer necessary, Sawyer thinks pointing out the positives of putting our masks away could reassure hesitant parents who worry about their children getting sick.
nya: Adindo a zaumoyo akadzanena kuti kuvala zotchinga kukamwa sikofunikiranso, a Sawyer akuganiza kuti kufotokoza ubwino wosiya kovala zotchinga kukamwa kukhoza kulimbikitsa makolo ozengereza omwe amadandaula kuti ana awo akhoza kudwala.
mt0: <pad> When health officials say that masks are no longer needed, Sawyer thinks that by describing the benefits of dropping masks he can help encourage more reluctant parents who worry about their children getting ill.</s>

en: "Maybe we should have a public conversation about the possible reasons to take that mask off, if they are in school, and get back to the normal repertoire of relatively safe childhood illnesses," she says.
nya: "Mwina tidzayankhulane ndi anthu za zifukwa zosiyira kuvala zotchinga kukamwa, ngati ali kusukulu, ndi kubwelera ku moyo wakale wodwala matenda osaopsa osiyanasiyaan a umwana," iwe anatero.
mt0: <pad> "Maybe we'll talk to people about why they should stop wearing mouthguards, if they're in school, and return to their old life of having different childhood illnesses," you said.</s>

en: "The plus side of childhood illnesses is that they can build up that hornet's nest of immunity that could protect kids against new things that then come along."
nya: "Ubwino wa matenda a ubwana ndi woti ukhoza kumanga chisa cha chitetezo cha mnthupi chomwe chingateteze ana ku zinthu zatsopano zomwe zingabwere."
mt0: <pad> "The advantage of childhood disorders is that they can build a physical barrier that can protect children from new things that may come."</s>

en: US Quietly Expands Asylum Limits While Preparing to End Them
nya: Boma la America  laonjezela malire osungira anthu othawa mavuto mu dzikolo pamene likukonzekera kuthetsa kutero.
mt0: <pad> The U.S. government has increased the number of refugees it takes in while preparing to end that policy.</s>

en: The Biden administration has begun expelling Cubans and Nicaraguans to Mexico under pandemic-related powers to deny migrants a chance to seek asylum, expanding use of the rule even as it publicly says it has been trying to unwind it, officials said Wednesday.
nya: Utsogoleri wa a Biden wayamba kusamutsa  anthu a ku Cuba ndi Nicaragua kupita  ku Mexiico potsatira mphamvu zokhudzana ndi  mliri mu njira yowakanizira anthu othawa maiko awo  kukhala mdzikolo, kukulitsa ntchito ya lamulori mmene anafotokozera poyera pamene akuyesera kulithetsa, akukuakulu anatero lachitatu.
mt0: <pad> The Biden administration has begun repatriating Cubans and Nicaraguans to Mexico as a way to deter them from entering the country, expanding the use of lamulori as he explained publicly when trying to solve the problem.</s>

en: The U.S. struck agreement with Mexico to expel up to 100 Cubans and 20 Nicaraguans a day from three locations: San Diego; El Paso, Texas; and Rio Grande Valley, Texas, according to a U.S. official with direct knowledge of the effort.
nya: Dziko la United States linapanga mgwirizano ndi dziko la Mexico wotulutsa  anthu makumi khumi a ku Cuba ndi makumi awiri a ku Nicaragua tsiku lilironse kuchokera ku San Diego, El Paso, Texas ndi Rio Grande Valley, malinga ndi mkulu wa dziko la U.S yemwe akudziwa za mchitidwewu.
mt0: <pad> The United States and Mexico have reached an agreement to repatriate 20 Cubans and 22 Nicaraguans from San Diego, El Paso, Texas and the Rio Grande Valley on Monday, according to a U.S. official with knowledge of the operation.</s>

en: The expulsions began April 27 and will end May 22, the official told The Associated Press on condition of anonymity because the agreement has not been made public.
nya: Kuthamangitsidwaku, kunayamba pa 27 April ndipo kudzatha pa 22 mwezi wa May. Mkulu wa bomayu  anauza a zofalitsa nkhani kuti iwo asadziwike chifukwa mgwilizanowu siunalengezedwe poyera.
mt0: <pad> The eviction, which began on 27 April and will end on 22 May, the mayor told journalists that they should not be identified because the deal was not officially announced.</s>

en: They are carried out under Title 42 authority, a public health law that has been used to expel migrants on grounds of preventing spread of COVID-19. Title 42 is due to expire May 23, unless a judge intervenes.
nya: Izi zikuchitika pansi pa mutu 42, lamulo la zaumoyo lomwe likugwilitsidwa ntchito kutulutsa anthu osamuka mmaiko awo pazifukwa zopewera kufala kwa matenda a Covid-19' Mutu 42 utha ntchito mu mwezi wa Meyi, pokhapokha  oweruza atalowelera.
mt0: <pad> This is under Article 42, a health law used to deport migrants from their countries for the purposes of preventing the spread of Covid-19' Article 42 ends in May, unless a court intervenes.</s>

en: The U.S. and Mexico agreed April 26 to a very limited number of expulsions of Cubans and Nicaraguans, according to a high-level Mexican official who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to comment publicly.
nya: Maiko America ndi Mexico  pa 26 mwezi wa Epulo zothamangitsa anthu owerengeka a ku Cuba ndi Nicaragua, malinga ndi mkulu wogwira ntchito ku Mexico amene anayankhula mobisika chifukwa samaloledwa kupereka ndemanga poyera.
mt0: <pad> America and Mexico on April 26 deported a number of Cuban and Nicaraguans, according to a senior official in Mexico who spoke in the press because he was not allowed to speak publicly.</s>

en: It was prompted by higher numbers of migrants from those two countries coming to the U.S. border.
nya: Izi zinachitika chifukwa cha kuchuluka kwa anthu osamuka kuchokera ku maiko awiriwa  kubwe ku malire a dziko la America.
mt0: <pad> This was due to the large number of migrants from both countries crossing the United States border.</s>

en: Mexico also took into account that the U.S. government had started processing visas in Cuba again, the official said. Mexico had also begun processing visas for Cubans.
nya: Dziko la Mexico linazindikira kuti boma la America linayambanso kukonza ziphaso zokhalira mdzikolo ku Cuba,  anatero akuluakuluwo. Boma la Mexico linali litayambanso kupangira anthu a ku Cuba ziphaso zokhalira mu dzikomo.
mt0: <pad> Mexico has recognized that the U.S. government has begun re-issuing US green card applications to Cubans, officials said. The Mexico government had already begun re-issuing green cards to Cubans.</s>

en: Another Mexican official, also not authorized to comment publicly, confirmed that up to 100 Cubans and 20 Nicaraguans were being expelled from San Diego under Title 42.
nya: Mkulu winanso wa boma  wa dziko la Mexico amene sanaloledwenso kupereka ndemanga poyera, anatsimikiza kuti anthu makumi khumi a ku Cuba ndi makumi awiri a ku Nicaragua anathamangitsidwa kuchokera ku San Diego pansi pa mutu 42.
mt0: <pad> Another official of the Mexican government, who was not allowed to speak publicly, confirmed that 20 Cubans and 22 Nicaraguans were deported from San Diego under the heading "illegal immigrants."</s>

en: The U.S. Department of Homeland Security did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
nya: Unduna owona za chikhalidwe cha anthu ndi chitetezo  sunaperekepo ndemanga mwachangu monga mwa pempho.
mt0: <pad> The Ministry of Social and Security did not respond to the request for comment.</s>

en: Until last week, Mexico only agreed to take Guatemalans, Hondurans and El Salvadorans — in addition to Mexicans — under Title 42 authority. Other nationalities are subject to Title 42 but costs, strained diplomatic ties and other considerations often make it difficult to send them back to their home countries.
nya: Kuchokera sabata latha, Boma la Mexico linavomera kutenga anthu a ku Guatemala, Hondura, ndi ku El Salvadora poonjezerapo anthu a ku Mexico pansi pa mutu 42. Maiko enanso ali pansi pa mutuwu koma kamba ka chuma, kupsyinjika kwa mgwirizano wa maiko ndi zifukwa zina ndizomwe zikuvutitsa kuwabweza ku maiko akwao.
mt0: <pad> From last week, the government of Mexico has agreed to take in Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvadora as well as Mexicans under Article 42. Other countries are also under this article but due to economic difficulties, lack of international coordination and other reasons it is difficult to repatriate them to their homeland.</s>

en: It's next to impossible for the U.S. to expel migrants to Cuba or Nicaragua because of poor relations with those governments. That has posed a challenge for the Biden administration as more people from those countries seek haven in the United States.
nya: Ndizosatheka ku Boma la America kubweza anthu a ku Cuba ndi Nicaragua ku maiko akwawo chifukwa cha ubale osakhala bwino omwe uli pakati pa mabomawa. Izi zinayambita mavuto mu utsogoleri wa a Biden pamene anthu ambiri ochokera mu maikowa amafuna kuti akakhale pabwino ku America ko.
mt0: <pad> The U.S. government could not deport Cubans and Nicaraguans back to their countries because of the poor relations between the two governments. This caused problems for Biden's presidency when many people from those countries wanted to live in America.</s>

en: Cubans were stopped by U.S. authorities more than 32,000 times on the Mexican border in March, double the number in February and more than five times October's count, according to U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Nicaragua eased travel restrictions from Cuba in November, making it easier for Cubans to continue by land to the U.S. border. Most enter the U.S. in or near Yuma, Arizona, and Del Rio, Texas.
nya: anthu a ku Cuba anaimitsidwa ndi akuluakulu a ku America koposera kokwana 32,000 pa malire a dziko la Mexico mu mwezi wa Malichi, kuonjezera nambalayi kawiri mu mwezi wa Febuluwale ndi kuposa kasanu mu chiwerengero cha mwezi wa Okotobala, malinga ndi  a chitetezo ndi oyendetsa katundu pa malire  a dziko la America. Boma la Nicaragua linakhwefula malamulo a mayendedwe kochokera ku Cuba mu mwezi wa Novembala zomwe zinapangitsa anthu a ku Cuba kupitilila ndikukafika ku malire a boma la America. Ambiri mwa iwo amalowa dziko la America kudzera kapena kuyandikila malo a ku Yuma, Arizona ndi ku Del Rio, Texas.
mt0: <pad> Cubans were detained by U.S. officials over 32,000 at the Mexican border in March, up more than double the number in February and more than six times the number in October, according to U.S. immigration and customs officials. Most of them enter the United States through or near Yuma, Arizona and Del Rio, Texas.</s>

en: Nicaraguans were stopped more than 16,000 times in March, more than double September's level. The vast majority enter in South Texas.
nya: Mu mwezi  wa Malichi anthu a ku Nicaragua analetsedwa ndi akuluakulu a ku America koposera ka 16000, kumene kunaposa mwezi wa September kawiri . Ambiri mwaiwo amalowa ku mmwera kwa dera la ku  Texas.
mt0: <pad> In March, more than 16,000 Nicaraguans were detained by American authorities, which doubled in September. Most of them entered the south of Texas.</s>

en: Lifting Title 42 has proved controversial as midterm elections near, even for Biden's Democratic Party, amid concerns that the U.S. is unprepared for an anticipated increase in migrants seeking asylum. Authorities stopped migrants more than 221,000 times in March, the highest mark in 22 years.
nya: kuchotsa mutu 42 kwakhala kotsutsana pamene pakati pa nthawi yochita masankho yayandikira, ngakhalenso ku Chipani cha mtsogoleri Biden, pakati pa kukhudzidwa kwa boma la America kuti silili lokonzeka kuonjezera chiwerengero cha anthu ofuna kulowa mdziko lawo kufuna pokhala. Akuluakulu aboma analetsa anthu ofuna kulowa mdziko koposera ka 221,000 mu mwezi wa March imene ili nambala yaikulu kuchokera mu zaka makumi awiri ndi ziwiri zapitazo.
mt0: <pad> The removal of Article 42 has been controversial as the midterm election nears, even in the Biden Party, amid concerns by the U.S. government that it is not prepared to increase the number of refugees seeking asylum. Authorities said they denied more than 221,000 refugees in March which is the largest number since the last two decades.</s>

en: The White House and Homeland Security Department have publicly stood behind the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's decision to end the measure because it could no longer be justified on grounds of protecting public health.
nya: Nyumba ya chifumu ya ku America ndi unduna woona za chittezo ndi chikhalidwe yaima pambuyo chiganizo cha unduna  ochepetsa ndi kupewa matenda chothetsa lamulo chifukwa silinathenso kuthandizo komanso kuteteza pa za umoyo.
mt0: <pad> The United States House of Representatives and the Department of Health and Human Services have withdrawn the bill after the CDC's decision to terminate it because it could no longer provide treatment and protection for health.</s>

en: But the practice of expelling Cubans and Nicaraguans runs counter to the administration's public statements that it was phasing out use of the pandemic powers to prepare for May 23.
nya: Koma mchitidwe wosamutsa  anthu a ku Cuba ndi Nicaragua ukutsutsana ndi ndemanga zomwe atsogoleri  amapereka poyera pothetsa kagwiritsidwe ntchito ka mphamvu za mliri pokonzekera pa 23 mwezi wa Meyi.
mt0: <pad> But the migration of Cuban and Nicaraguan people is in conflict with the statements made by the leaders in public to solve the use of the epidemic power to prepare for the 23rd of May.</s>

en: The U.S. has expelled migrants more than 1.8 million times under Title 42 authority since March 2020, effectively overriding rights to seek asylum under U.S. law and international treaty. In doing so, migrants are not subject to immigration law, which include rights to seek protection from persecution at home.
nya: Boma la America lasamutsa anthu 1.8 million olowa mu dzikolo pansi pa mutu  42 kuchokera mu mwezi wa march mu chaka cha 2020, Kupitilira ufulu wofuna pokhala pansi pa lamulo la ku America ndi pangano lapadziko lonse. Potero, anthu osamukasamuka  sakukhudzidwa ndi lamulo losamuka lomwe limakamba za ufulu ofuna kutetezedwa ku kuzunzika kwawo.
mt0: <pad> The U.S. government has deported 1.8 million immigrants under Section 42 since March 2020, violating the right to stay under American law and international treaties. Therefore, migrants are not affected by the removal law that provides protection for the rights of the migrants from their suffering.</s>

en: The administration said in court filings that it began processing more Central American adults under immigration laws after the CDC's announcement on April 1. But a federal judge in Louisiana ruled last week that it couldn't start unwinding Title 42 while it was still in effect.
nya: Mu zolemba za ku khoti utsogoleriwo unati unayamba kukonza kwambiri mapepala a anthu achikulire a pakati pa dziko la America pansi pa malamulo a kusamuka patatha zolengeza za bungwe la CDC's pa ! Epulo. Koma oweruza milandu sabata yatha analamulira kuti sakanatha kumasula mutu 42 pamene unali ukugwira ntchitobe.
mt0: <pad> In court documents the administration said it began to prepare almost all of the documents for elderly Americans in the United States under the immigration act after the CDC's announcement in April. But a federal prosecutor last week ruled that they could not remove Section 42 while it was still in effect.</s>

en: U.S. District Judge Robert Summerhays strongly criticized the CDC's decision, suggesting he would try to keep Title 42 in effect after May 23. A hearing is scheduled May 13 for oral arguments.
nya: Oweluza milandu wa boma la America a Robert Summerhays anadzudzula maganizo a bungwe la CDS pamene anapereka maganizo ot ayesera kuti mutu 42 uzigwilabe ntchito mpakana tsiku la 23 mwezi wa Meyi. Kokamba mulanduwu kudzachitika pa 13 may.
mt0: <pad> Robert Summerhays, U.S. Attorney General, criticized the CDS's attempt to keep Article 42 in effect until May 23. The trial will begin on May 13.</s>

en: Marisa Limon, senior director of advocacy and planning at the Hope Border Institute, said advocates began learning about expulsions of Cubans and Nicaraguans from El Paso on Monday and later confirmed the new practice with U.S. officials.
nya: A Marisa Limon, mkulu woyang'anila kulimbikitsa ndi kukonzekera ku Bungwe lotchedwa, Hope Border Institute , anati olimbikitsawa anayamba kudziwa za kusamutsidwa kwa anthu a ku Cuba ndi ku Nicaragua kuchokera kwa El Paso lolemba ndipo anatsimikiza mchitidwe watsopanowu ndi akuluakulu a boma la America.
mt0: <pad> Marisa Limon, the director of advocacy and preparedness at the Hope Border Institute said advocates learned about the removal of Cuban and Nicaraguan people from El Paso on Tuesday and confirmed the new procedure with U.S. government officials.</s>

en: Limon said the administration is "trying to get every last bit out of Title 42" before it expires. She called it "sobering" but consistent with the administration's efforts to have other countries in the Western hemisphere take more responsibility for hosting people fleeing their homes.
nya: A Limon anati  utsogoleri wawo ukuyesetsa kudziwa mapeto onse a mutu 42 usanasiye kugwira ntchito. Iwo anaufotokoza kuti ndi wanzeru koma pakuyenera kuti atsogoleri aziikilako khama kuti maiko ena a kumadzulo kwa dziko lapansi akhalenso ndi udindo wosunga anthu othawa kwawo.
mt0: <pad> Limon said they were trying to understand the entire content of Article 42 before it was dissolved. They described it as a sensible measure but urged leaders to make more efforts to get other Western countries to take on the responsibility of keeping refugees.</s>

en: Mexico Relocates Migrant Camp; Haitians Appear at Border
nya: Boma la Mexico lasamutsa misasa ya anthu osamukira mu dzikolo; anthu aku  Haiti aonekera pa malire a dziko.
mt0: <pad> The Mexican government has relocated the refugee camps in the country; Haitians have been waiting at the border.</s>

en: Mexican authorities said Tuesday they have relocated a migrant camp that sprung up in a park in the border city of Reynosa, moving about 2,000 people from Central America and Haiti to a shelter in the city, across the border from McAllen, Texas.
nya: Akuluakulu a boma la Mexico lachiwiri amati asamutsa msasa wa  anthu olowa mu dzikolo omwe unatulukira ku ndime  mu mzinda wa malirewo wa  Reynosa,  asuntha pafupifupi anthu mazana awiri kuchoka pakati pa Boma la america ndi Haiti kupita ku malo  ena owasungilako  kuolokera ku malire ochokera ku McAllen Texas.
mt0: <pad> Mexico officials on Tuesday said they had relocated a refugee camp that became a riot site in the border town of Reynosa, moving about 200 people from the United States and Haiti to another immigration center in McAllen Texas.</s>

en: The camp of migrants mainly from Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras and Haiti sprung up after U.S. officials, citing the pandemic, invoked a health rule that denies migrants a chance to seek asylum.
nya: Malo okhala anthu osamukila dzikolo makamaka ochokera ku dziko la Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras ndi ku Haiti kunachuluka anthu pamene akuluakulu a boma la America  anabweretsa lamulo la zaumoyo loletsa anthu osamukira mu dzikolo kupeza mwayi wopatsidwa chitetezo chifukwa cha mliri.
mt0: <pad> Migrant camps in the United States, especially from Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras and Haiti have been crowded since the U.S. government introduced a health law that prevents migrants from getting medical protection for the disease.</s>

en: Mexico's National Immigration Institute said the migrants were taken around midnight Monday to the shelter, which it said will have better hygiene and food services.
nya: Bungwe loona zolowa ndi kutuluka kwa anthu mu dziko la Mexico lotchedwa ( Mexico's Immigration Institute linati  anthuwo anatengedwa lolemba pakati pa usiku kupita ku malo owasungilawo amene akuyenera kukhala a ukhondo komanso chakudya chabwino.
mt0: <pad> The Mexican Immigration Institute said they were taken to a detention center on Wednesday afternoon. It is supposed to have clean and good food.</s>

en: But on Monday, people in another border city, Nuevo Laredo, said hundreds of migrants, mainly Haitians, have streamed into that city, which is across the border from Laredo, Texas
nya: Lolemba lomwelo anthu ochokera ku malire a dziko a ku Nuevo Laredo anafotokoza kuti anthu opitilira makumi khumi makamaka a dziko la Haiti anakhamikira mu mzindawo umene uli mbali yoyang'anana ndi malire a dzikolo kochokera ku Laredo, Texas
mt0: <pad> On Monday, officials from the Nuevo Laredo border town said that over 100 people, mostly Haitians, had moved into the city which is located near the border from Laredo, Texas.</s>

en: The rush apparently started after the U.S. began processing some asylum-seekers there.
nya: Kukhamikilako kunayamba pamene boma la America linayamba ndondomeko yopereka chitetezo kwa anthu othawira mu dzikolo.
mt0: <pad> The protests started after the U.S. government began a program to provide security for refugees in the country.</s>

en: The Catholic bishop of Nuevo Laredo said Monday that migrant shelters there are overcrowded, with some migrants sleeping outside in tents.
nya: Mkulu wa mpingo wa katolika wa ku Nuevo, lolemba apati malo okhalako anthu osamukila mu dzikolo  ndi othinana pamene anthu ena akugona panja pa misanja.
mt0: <pad> The Catholic bishop of Nuevo, on Tuesday, closed the refugee camps in the country and called for a national emergency while some people were sleeping in the street.</s>

en: Bishop Enrique Sánchez Martínez said migrants started streaming into Nuevo Laredo in late April, though the city isn't usually popular among migrants, in part because it is dominated by the violent Northeast drug cartel.
nya: A Bishopu Enrique Sanchez Martínez anati anthuwa anayamba kulowera ku Nuevo Laredo ku mapeto kwa mwezi wa Epulo, ngakhale mzindawo sudziwika kwambiri ndi anthu ochokera maiko ena, chifukwa unadzadzidwa ndi zigawenga za ku Northeast drug carte
mt0: <pad> The Bishop Enrique Sanchez Martínez said they began to enter Nuevo Laredo in late April, even though the city is not well known to foreigners, because it is filled with Northeast drug cartels.</s>

en: "It is new for us because this is the last place they come, due to the conditions of our border, of our city, which are sometimes adverse for migrants," the bishop said. "But since they opened the door in the United States to asylum requests, a lot of them came in large groups."
nya: ‘Izi ndi zachilendo kwa ife chifukwa awa ndi malo omalizira amene iwo sangabwereko, chifukwa cha mkhalidwe wa  malire dziko lathu, mu mzinda wathu umene umatsutsana ndi anthu osamukila mu dzikoli” anatero mkulu wansembeyo. Koma chifukwa a Boma la America linatsekula khomo lopereka chitetezo ndi malo kwa anthu othawira mdzikolo, ambiri mwaiwo anabwera mwa unyinji.
mt0: <pad> This is a new experience for us, because this is the last place they can come to, because of our country's border policy, in our city that opposes refugees," said the bishop. But since the U.S. government has opened its doors to refugees, many of them have come in large numbers.</s>

en: Marvin Ajic, the director of the Casa Nazareth shelter, said that around April 16, Mexican authorities notified the shelters that the United States would resume processing asylum claims for humanitarian reasons.
nya: A Marvin Ajic, mkulu wa malo osungira anthu a ku Casa Nazareth anati pa 16 Epulo, akuluakulu a boma la Mexico anadziwitsa anthu a ku malo osungidwawo kuti boma a America liyamba  ndondomeko yothandiza anthu othawira dzikolo pa zifukwa zothandizila anthu.
mt0: <pad> Marvin Ajic, director of the Casa Nazareth shelter, said on April 16, officials from the Mexican government informed the residents of the shelter that the United States government was starting a program to help refugees in humanitarian reasons.</s>

en: The U.S. had begun allowing more people in, especially Central American adults, to prepare for lifting Title 42 — a pandemic-era health rule that denies migrants a chance to enter the U.S. seek asylum — on May 23. But a federal judge in Louisiana ruled last week that the government could not unwind the rule before the end date.
nya: Boma la America linali litayamba kulowetsa anthu mdzikolo makamaka akuluakulu a pakati pa dziko la America pokonzekera kuchotsa mutu 42, lamulo la nthawi ya mliri limene limakaniza anthu kusamukira mdziko la America kufuna chitetezo. Pa 23 Meyi, oweruza milandu wa ku Louisiana sabata yatha analamula kuti boma silingathetse lamulolo tsiku lane lisanakwane.
mt0: <pad> The U.S. government had already begun to deport people, especially middle-aged Americans, in preparation for the repeal of Article 42, a pandemic law that bans people from entering the United States for protection. On May 23, a judge in Louisiana last week ruled that the government could not repeal the law within one day without a court ruling.</s>

en: "The (Mexican) immigration officials organized things with the shelters, and the plan was to send people who had been waiting a long time, without any checks, basically anyone," Ajic said.
nya: Akuluakulu oona zolowa ndi kutuluka mdziko la Mexico anakonza zinthu ndi malo osungilako anthuwo,  ndondomeko yawo inali yotumiza  kwawo anthu omwe amadikilira kwa nthawi yaitali opanda kusechedwa makamaka aliyense, anatero a Ajic.
mt0: <pad> Mexico's immigration authorities have established conditions and facilities for the detainees, their plan is to repatriate the people who have been waiting for a long time without delays, Ajic said.</s>

en: That apparently drew the attention of other migrants, including Haitians.
nya: Izi zinakoka mitima ya anthu ena ofuna kulowa mdzikolo kuonjezerapo achokera ku Haiti.
mt0: <pad> This attracted more immigrants from Haiti.</s>

en: In September, similar rumors sparked a rush by about 15,000 mostly Haitian refugees to the Texas border, where they camped under a bridge. U.S. officials began large scale deportations of Haitians while also allowing thousands to remain in the U.S.
nya: Mwezi wa september, phekesera ngati zomwezi zinachititsa anthu othawa nwawo okwana  15,000 a ku Haiti kupita ku malire a dzikolo a  ku Texas kumene anamangako misanja pansi pa mlatho. Akuluakulu a boma la America anayamba kubweza  kwawo gulu la anthu a ku Haiti pamene ena  mazana mazana analoledwa kukhala mu dziko la America lo.
mt0: <pad> In September, similar checks led 15,000 Haitian refugees to cross the Texas border where they built camps under the bridge. U.S. officials began repatriation of the Haitians while hundreds of them were allowed to stay in the United States.</s>

en: Ajic warned migrants against coming to the border, noting the risks. On Monday, Mexico's National Immigration Institute said that so far this year, it has pulled the bodies of 19 immigrants from the Rio Grande, also known as the Rio Bravo.
nya: Ajic anachenjeza anthu ofuna kusamukira mu dzikolo kudzera ku malire a dziko la America poona zoopsa zake. Lolemba, oona za kulowa ndi kutuluka mdziko la Mexico anati chaka chino, achotsa matupi a anthu khumi ndi asanu ndi anayi kuchokera ku Rio Grande komwenso kumadziwika kuti Rio Bravo.
mt0: <pad> Ajic warned migrants to be careful when crossing the United States border. On Tuesday, the Immigration and Customs Enforcement Department said they removed 18 bodies from the Rio Grande, also known as Rio Bravo.</s>

en: New US Rule Grants Automatic Work Permit Extensions to Noncitizens
nya: lamulo latsopano la ku America likupereka nthawi yoonjezera ziphaso zogwilira ntchito mu dzikomo kwa anthu amene ndi ochokera maiko ena payokha.
mt0: <pad> New U.S. law gives longer time for individual foreigners to obtain work visas in the United States.</s>

en: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) announced Tuesday that it would automatically extend for 360 days the work permits of immigrants who applied to renew their work authorization amid the current backlog in processing times.
nya: Ogwira ntchito yöpereka ziphaso ndi oona zolowa ndi kutuluka mdzikomp lachiwiri analengeza kuti aonjezera pawokha masiku 360 ololeza anthu osamukira mdzikolo kugwirabe ntchito  kamba ka kuchedwa kulongosola mapepala komwe kukuchitika.
mt0: <pad> The passport and immigration authorities on Tuesday announced that they had extended the period of time for illegal immigrants to work in the country for 360 days.</s>

en: The new notice expands on the 180-day extension USCIS announced in November. It is expected to prevent about 260,000 immigrants from losing their work permits in the next 18 months. It will also give the agency extra time to clear applicants waiting in line, the agency said in a statement.
nya: Chidziwitso chatsopanochi  chaonjezera pa masiku 180  amene a bungwe USCIS analengeza mu mwezi wa Novembala. Izi zikuyembekezeka kupewetsa anthu osamukira mdzikolo okwana 260,000 kutaya ziphaso zawo zogwilira ntchito mdzikolo kwa miyezi 18 yomwe ikubwerayi. Izinso zipereka nthawi yokwanira ku nthambiyo kuti ilongosole ndandanda wa anthu omwe akudikilira kuthandizidwa, nthambiyo inatero.
mt0: <pad> The new announcement adds to the 180 days that USCIS announced in November. This will prevent 260,000 immigrants from losing their green cards for the next 18 months. It also gives the department time to review its list of applicants who are eligible for assistance, the department said.</s>

en: "This temporary rule will provide those noncitizens otherwise eligible for the automatic extension an opportunity to maintain employment and provide critical support for their families while avoiding further disruption for U.S. employers," USCIS Director Ur M. Jaddou said in a statement.
nya: Mu kufotokoza kwawo bwana wa bungwe la  USCIS a Ur M. Haddou anati lamulo lakanthawi kochepali lipereka mwayi kwa anthu emene sali mnzika za  mdzikolo kuti akhalebe akugwira ntchito mdzikolo kuti azithandizabe mabanja awo pamene akupewa kusokoneza ogwira ntchito a boma la America
mt0: <pad> The USCIS chief said the provisional law will allow non-citizens to continue working in the country while not delaying their families.</s>

en: The extension, which takes effect Wednesday, aims to stabilize operations for U.S. employers and help people with pending employment authorizations who have a job and are working in the U.S.
nya: Kuonjezera nthawi ku komwe kuyambe kugwira ntchito lachitatu, kukhazikitsa  kagwiridwe ntchito ka anthu  a boma la America komanso kuthandiza anthu a ku  America amene ndi ovomelezeka  kugwira ntchito mu dzikolo komanso ali pa ndandanda wodikilira kulembedwa ntchito.
mt0: <pad> Extending the time for the start of the third phase, establishing the American government's procedures and assisting American citizens who are eligible to work in the country and are on the wait list for employment.</s>

en: USCIS is the agency in charge of handling the nation's immigration paperwork. In recent years, it has struggled with backlogs, an issue made worse by the COVID-19 pandemic and budget shortfalls.
nya: USCIS ndi nthambi yomwe imayang’anira mapepala onse a anthu olowa ndi kutuluka mdzikomo. zaka zapitazo nthambiyi yakhala ikubwelera mmbuyo, mliri wa covid-19 ndi vuto la ndondomeko zachuma ndikomwe kunaonjezera kubwelera mmbuyoku.
mt0: <pad> USCIS is the department that handles all immigration documents. in the past years the department has been falling, the coronavirus pandemic and the economic crisis have only intensified the decline.</s>

en: In April, Jaddou told U.S. government officials during a congressional hearing that USCIS had 8.5 million pending immigration cases, including those seeking green cards and U.S. naturalization.
nya: Mwezi wa epulo a Jaddou anauza boma la America ku msonkhano wawo kuti a USCIS anali ndi milanduyodikila kuweruzidwa yokwana 8.5 million, kuonjezerapo ya anthu ofuna kupeza chiphaso chokhalira mdzikomo cha green card, ndi ena ofuna kutsimikiza kuti anabadwira mdzikomo.
mt0: <pad> In April, Mr. Jaddou told the US Congress that USCIS had 8.5 million unresolved cases, including green card applicants and other people who wanted to prove they were born in the United States.</s>

en: She said more than half of those pending cases were taking longer than the agency's normal processing times.
nya: Iwo anati kupitilira theka la milanduyi yodikira kuzengedwayi  inatenga nthawi yaitali  nthawi yomwe nthambiyi imagwira nthawi zonse.
mt0: <pad> They said that over half of these short-term prosecutions took longer than the normal time frame for the branch's regular work.</s>

en: Asylum-seekers, immigrants adjusting their status to permanent residence and other noncitizens going through the U.S. immigration process are among the noncitizens affected by the latest work authorization extension.

mt0: <pad> They are refugees from their own countries, migrants from other countries who want to settle in the United States and non-citizens affected by the extension of the work permits program.</s>

mt0: <pad> The government announced that it had increased the time for refugees fleeing conflict from six months in 2017 to 11 months in 2021.</s>

en: In March, USCIS announced a program to reduce backlogs, including the expansion of premium processing for certain applications where applicants could pay a higher fee to expedite paperwork processing.

mt0: <pad> Last month, USCIS announced a reduction in re-entry fees, adding to an upper level paperwork arrangement where some applicants can pay the re-entry fee to speed up their passport processing.</s>

en: According to the USCIS, most of the announced changes simply restore options offered before the Trump administration's slowdown of USCIS processing and before the COVID-19 pandemic further slowed the agency's resources.

en: "For several years, USCIS has been in a precarious financial situation that has impaired the efficient completion of caseloads. The COVID-19 pandemic exacerbated these challenges in 2020, in addition to a hiring freeze and furlough threat leading to workforce attrition and severely reduced capacity. In 2021, before USCIS could recover from these fiscal and operational impacts, there was a sudden and dramatic increase in EAD (Employment Authorization Document) initial and renewal filings," according to the USCIS statement.
nya: “Kwa zaka zambiri, bungwe la  USCIS lakhala ndi mavuto a zachuma ochuluka zomwe zimachedwetsa kumaliza ntchito zochuluka. Mu Chaka cha 2021, bungwe la USCIS lisanabwelere mchimake, panali kuchuluka mwadzidzidzi kwa mapepala a anthu ofuna kulembedwa ntchito”, kuchokera ku ndemanga ya a USCIS.
mt0: <pad> For years, USCIS has had financial difficulties that have delayed the completion of many applications. The pandemic of covid-19 has aggravated the problems already present in 2020. In addition to not being able to hire new staff, and the risk of forced layoffs due to the economic crisis, there was an unexpected surge in applicants for employment in 2021.</s>

en: The USCIS historically has been underfunded because most of the agency's funding comes from application fees that have stalled at $5 billion a year since 2019.

en: U.S. President Joe Biden recently announced the Uniting for Ukraine program, which aims to streamline the process for Ukrainians who have fled their country and are seeking safety in the United States.
nya: Mtsogoleri wa dziko la America a Joe Biden posachedwapa walengeza za ndondomeko ya mgwirizano  wa dziko la Ukraine. Cholinga chake ndi kukonzera njira anthu a dziko la Ukraine amene anathawaa dziko lawo kufuna chitetezo mu dziko la America.
mt0: <pad> The US President Joe Biden has recently announced the Ukraine Partnership. Its purpose is to provide a way for Ukrainian refugees to seek protection in the United States.</s>

en: The new program, which took effect Monday, will complement existing legal pathways available to those fleeing Russian aggression due to the ongoing Russia-Ukraine crisis, Biden administration officials said.
nya: Ndondomeko yatsopanoyi yomwe inayamba kugwira ntchito Lolemba, iwonjezela njira za malamulo zomwe zidalipo kale kwa anthu amene akuthawa ziwawa za dziko la Russia, akuluakulu a utsogoleri wa a BIden watero.
mt0: <pad> The new scheme, which began to take effect on Monday, will add to the existing legal options for refugees fleeing Russian violence, officials of the Biden administration said.</s>

en: "The U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) will continue to provide relief to the Ukrainian people, while supporting our European allies who have shouldered so much as the result of Russia's brutal invasion of Ukraine," Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas said in a statement to reporters on April 21.
nya: “ Chigawo cha malo  ndi chitetezo mu boma la America, chipitiliza kupereka thandizo kwa anthu a ku Ukraine, pamene chikuthandiza Ogwirizana a ku Ulaya amene athandiza kwambiri kamba ka zotsatira za mmene dziko la Russia linalowera mwa upandu ku dziko la Ukraine,” mlembi wa nthambi ya malo ndi chitetezo a Alejandro Mayorka anfotokoza kwa atolankhani mwezi wa Epulo chaka cha 2021.
mt0: <pad> The U.S. Department of State and Security will continue to provide aid to the people of Ukraine, while supporting European allies who have been severely affected by Russia's intervention in Ukraine," said Alejandro Mayorka, spokesman for the department of state and security in April 2021.</s>

en: What is Uniting for Ukraine?
nya: Kodi mgwirizano wa dziko la Ukraine ndichani?
mt0: <pad> What is the Union of Ukraine?</s>

en: The program allows U.S. citizens and residents to sponsor Ukrainian refugees under different immigration statuses. The online portal, open to potential sponsors or organizations, is accepting applications and has received more than 4,000 requests so far, CNN reported.
nya: Ndondomekoyi imalola mzika za dziko la America ndi anthu othawa dziko la Ukraine pa zifukwa zosiyanasiyana.  Chipata cha intaneti, chomwe chinatsekulidwa kwa mabungwe ofuna kupereka chithandizo, chikulandira ma kalata ofunsira thandizoli ndipo makalata mazana anayı alandiridwa, kuchokera ku nyumba yofalitsa nkhani ya CNN.
mt0: <pad> The program allows American citizens and Ukrainian refugees for various reasons to receive financial support. A website, open to charity donors, is receiving applications for the financial support and has received over 400 applications, according to CNN.</s>

en: Who qualifies under the program?  Ukrainians, or an immediate family member of a Ukrainian citizen. They must have a U.S. sponsor and have been a resident of Ukraine as of February 11.
nya: Amene akuyenera kutsata ndondomekoyi ndindani? Anthu a ku Ukraine, wachibale kwa mzika ya dziko la Ukraine. Akuyenera kukhala ndi munthu wowathandiza wa ku America komanso akhala mu dziko la Ukraine kuchokera mwezi wa February pa 11.
mt0: <pad> Who should follow this procedure? Ukrainians, relatives of a Ukrainian citizen. They must have an American sponsor and live in Ukraine from February 11 to February 12.</s>

en: What are the requirements?   They must pass security checks — including a fingerprint and an FBI name check and biographic and biometric screening — and meet public health requirements, such as having the proper vaccinations, before entering the U.S.
nya: Zofunikira zake ndichani? Akuyenera kudutsa posechedwa ndi a  chitetezo kuphatitizapo kuyesa zidindo za zala zawo, kufufuza dzina lawo kwa apolisi a FBI,  kuyesa thupi lawo ndi makina, komanso kukhala ndi zoyenereza za umoyo ngati ma katemera onse asanalowe mu dziko la America
mt0: <pad> What are the requirements? They must pass through security checks including fingerprints, their name being verified by FBI police, a body scan, and have all medical requirements before entering the country.</s>

en: Those approved will be allowed to travel to the U.S., be considered for humanitarian parole on a case-by-case basis, stay in the country for two years, and apply for work permits.
nya: Onse ovomelezedwa adzaloledwa kupita ku dziko la America, adzatengedwa ngati anthu othandizidwa pafupipafupi, akhale mu dzikolo kwa zaka ziwiri kenako kulembera ziphaso zowalola kugwira ntchito mu dzikolo.
mt0: <pad> All applicants will be allowed to go to the United States, be taken as regular contributors, stay in the country for two years and then file for green cards.</s>

en: "The United States strongly encourages Ukrainians seeking refuge in the United States who do not have and are not eligible for a visa to seek entry via Uniting for Ukraine from Europe. This will be the safest and most efficient way to pursue temporary refuge in the United States," a DHS statement said.

en: U.S. citizens and other residents who hold lawful status in the United States or who are beneficiaries of Deferred Enforced Departure, Temporary Protected Status, or Deferred Action, among others.

en: Sponsors will be required to prove they can financially support the refugee while they are in the U.S. They also need to pass security and background vetting "to protect against exploitation and abuse." The Ukrainian applicant will receive authorization only after everything is verified, including that the sponsor has the means to support them while they are in the U.S.

Anthu olembera a ku Ukraine adzapatsidwa chilolezo chilichonse chikadzavomelezedwa, kuonjezelaponso ngati wowathandizayo Ali ndi njira yowathandizilayo pamene  ali ku America.
mt0: <pad> These sponsors must be able to provide support to refugees while they are in the United States. They must also pass all security tests "to protect from crime". Ukrainian applicants will be given any permits once they are approved, and if the sponsor has a way to support them while they are in the United States.</s>

en: Who is not eligible for parole under the program?

en: Citing safety issues, U.S. officials have urged Ukrainians not to travel to Mexico in hopes of entering the United States. In addition, U.S. Customs and Border Protection has no place to hold them while they go through the Uniting for Ukraine vetting process.

en: Since Uniting for Ukraine's launch on Monday, Ukrainians who arrive at U.S. ports of entry without a valid visa or without preauthorization to travel to the United States through the Uniting for Ukraine program will be denied entry and told to apply to the program.

en: Those at the border must apply under the rules of Uniting for Ukraine, meaning they must have a qualifying sponsor or a non-government agency willing to sponsor them in the U.S. for up to two years. And they need to have all required vaccinations and pass background checks.

en: The Biden administration announced the private sponsorship initiative as another way the U.S. hopes to achieve President Biden's commitment to welcome up to 100,000 Ukrainians displaced by the Russian military invasion.

en: Report: Rwanda Should Ease Restrictions On 2003 National Elections - 2001-10-15

mt0: <pad> Report: Rwanda should adopt the 2003 constitution of the national election, 2001-</s>

en: In 2003 Rwanda will hold its first national elections since the 1994 genocide. A new report says the government of Rwanda needs to relax its control over public life if the polls are to have any credibility.
nya: Dziko la Rwanda  lipangitsa zisankho za dzikolo koyamba patatha kuphedwa kwa anthu kwa chipulula komwe kunachitika mu Chaka cha 1994. Lipoti latsopano lati kuti dziko la Rwanda likuyenera kuchepetsa mphavu zolamulira anthu ndi cholinga choti zisankhozi zikhale zodalirika.
mt0: <pad> Rwanda has held its first national elections since the 1994 genocide. The new report suggests that Rwanda should reduce its power of control in order to make the elections credible.</s>

en: There was relief when the Rwandan Patriotic Front seized power in Rwanda in 1994, ending the genocide in which about 800,000 minority Tutsis and moderate Hutus were killed.
nya: Anthu anapepukidwa pamene chipani cha Patriotic Front chinatenga boma mu Chaka cha 1994, kuthetsa kupha kwa anthu mwaunyinji komwe kunapha ana ochepa okwana 800,000 a mtundu wa Tutsis ndi Hutus.
mt0: <pad> People were tricked when the Patriotic Front took power in 1994, ending the mass killings that killed at least 800,000 Tutsis and Hutus children.</s>

en: The new military government promised to restore democracy to Rwanda via elections in 2003.
nya: Boma lastopano la asilikali linalonjeza kubwezeletsa ufulu wa ndale mu dziko la Rwanda kudzera mu zisankho za chaka cha 2003.
mt0: <pad> The new military government promises to restore political freedom in Rwanda through the 2003 elections.</s>

en: That process began in March this year, with district elections.
nya: Ndondomeyi inayamba mwezi wa Malichi chaka chino ndi zisankho za mmaboma.
mt0: <pad> The protests started in March this year with local elections.</s>

en: Senior analyst Francois Grignon, of the International Crisis Group, a Brussels-based policy research organization, says he was disappointed with the district poll. Mr. Grignon says the process was so tightly controlled that he maintains no genuine opposition candidates were allowed to stand.
nya: Katswiri wamkulu wa bungwe lotchedwa  International Crisis group; a Francois Grignon, bungwe lakafukufuku la ku Brussels , anati ndiwokhumudwa ndi mmene zisankho zinayendera maboma. Mr Grignon anati mavotedwewa analamuliridwa kwambiri ndipo panalibe anthu otsutsa boma amene analoledwa kuimila nawo maudindowo.
mt0: <pad> Francois Grignon, the chief analyst of the International Crisis Group, a Brussels research group, said he was disappointed with the results of the presidential elections. He said the polls were manipulated and there were no opposition candidates allowed to stand for the posts.</s>

en: "There was a screening and there was a preparation of the elections, which did not allow other candidates than those who had been rubber-stamped by the government to actually contest, especially for the executive positions within the local authorities," he says. "If consensual democracy means that the political debate is actually handled before the electoral contest in such a way that it does not lead to a real competition then there is no democracy at all."
nya: “Panali kafukufuku komanso kukonzekera zisankhozo kumene sikunalole anthu ena omwe samaimila boma kupikisana nawo, makamaka oimila maudindo akuluakulu mu madera ang’onoang’ono.” Iwo anatero. “Ngati ufulu waaliyense ukutanthauza kuti kutsutsana pa ndale  kuchitika mpikisano wa zisankho usanachitike, mpaka kulepheretsa kuchitanso zisankho zenizeni, ndekuti palibe ufulu uliwonse.
mt0: <pad> "There was a campaign and election preparation that did not allow non-governmental candidates to compete, especially in smaller areas," they said. "If any freedom means that political protests before the election, which ultimately prevented real elections, then there is no freedom at all."</s>

en: In a new report, titled Consensual Democracy in Post Genocide Rwanda, the International Crisis Group urges the international community to pressure Rwanda's government to liberalize political activity.
nya: Mu lipoti latsopano lotchedwa Consensual Democracy in Post Genocide Rwanda, gulu lapadziko lonse loona za mavuto lapempha gulu la pa dziko lonse kuti likakamize boma la Rwanda kukhazikitsa ufulu wa ndale.
mt0: <pad> In its new report, Consensual Democracy in Post Genocide Rwanda, the International Crisis Group urges the international community to pressure the Rwandan government to implement political freedom.</s>

en: The report notes that the military dominates public life and there is little open criticism of the government, either in the media or by opposition figures. The Rwanda government argues that allowing a range of opinions would be dangerous in a country struggling to come to terms with its bloody past.
nya: Lipotilo lapezanso kuti asilikali ndiomwe akulamulira  anthu komanso kunyoza boma, kudzera mu nyumba zofalitsa mawu kapena otsutsa boma. Boma la Rwanda latsutsa kuvomera maganizo  a anthu osiyanasiyana chifukwa izi zitha kukhala zoopsa ku dziko lomwe likufuna kukhazikika kutengera ndi kale lake loipa.
mt0: <pad> The report also found that the military is controlling the media and insulting the government, through the press or by opponents. The Rwandan government has refused to accept a wide range of views because it fears this could be dangerous for a country that is trying to recover from its bad past.</s>

en: But Mr. Grignon says dissent is simply being driven underground or outside Rwanda's borders.
nya: Mr Grignon anati kutsutsaku  kukumachitika mwachinsinsi kapena  kunja kwa malire a dziko la Rwanda.
mt0: <pad> Mr Grignon said the attacks were carried out in secret or outside the Rwandan border.</s>

en: "Opponents to the regime have to flee the country or to join in rebel movements outside the country or in the Congo and no chance to express a different view," he says. "All the good policies that the government has been implementing - including the organization of the elections, national elections, presidential and parliamentary, in 2003 - will lack the credibility because they were not implemented in an environment that actually allowed a fair contest to take place," he says.
nya: “Anthu otsutsa boma amathawa dzikolo kapena kulowa nawo mmagulu oukila boma kunja kwa dzikolo kapena ku dziko la Congo komwe alibe mwayi wopereka maganizo ena”, iwo anatero. “Malamulo onse abwino amene boma lakhala likukhazikitsa- kuonjezerapo kulongosola zisankho, zisankho za maiko, za mtsogoleri komanso aphungu mu Chaka cha 2003- zidzasowa chilungamo chifukwa sizinakhazitsidwe pa malo ololela kupikisana kwachilungamo, iwo anatero.
mt0: <pad> “Opponents flee the country or join a government-backed movement outside the country or in the Republic of Congo where they have no opportunity to voice their opinion,” they said. “All good measures that the government has put in place- including the election law, the national assembly, the president and the parliamentary elections in 2003- will need justice because they were not based on fair competition,” they said.</s>

en: Mr. Grignon says greater freedom of expression would strengthen Rwanda's reconciliation process and enhance its chances of a peaceful future.
nya: Mr. Grignon  anati ufulu womasuka utha kulimbikitsa  njira yobwelera mchimake ku dziko la Rwanda komanso kuojezera mphamvu zodzetsa tsogolo la mtendere  mdzikolo.
mt0: <pad> Mr. Grignon said that freedom of expression could help the process of reconstruction in Rwanda and strengthen the efforts towards a future peace in the country.</s>

en: He says the international community's involvement in reconstruction projects gives it the leverage to make this plain to the Rwandan government.

mt0: <pad> Tharissen Karugarama received the decision of the French government to force him to be arrested through their country and the International Court of Justice.</s>

en: "It is good news that Callixte Mbarushimana has been (arrested) by the French judicial authority. Good news in the sense that, first, there was an international arrest warrant against him issued by the Rwandan government in respect of (the alleged) act of genocide committed in Rwanda in 1994."
nya: Iyi ndi nkhani yabwino kwambiri pakuti a Callixte Mbarushimana amangidwa ndi akuluakulu a khoti la dziko la France. Iyi ndi nkhani yabwino pakuti dziko la Rwanda linatulutsa chikalata chokuti iye amangidwe kudzera ku mchitidwe wokupha magulu a anthu mu chaka cha 1994 ku Rwanda
mt0: <pad> This is very good news because Callixte Mbarushimana has been arrested by the French court. This is good news because Rwanda has issued a document that he was arrested by the genocide in 1994 in Rwanda.</s>

mt0: <pad> Karugarama said the Hague judges were determined to prosecute the former chief of staff, who is believed to be hiding in France.</s>
