en: "The International Criminal Court (ICC) conducted its own investigation about his other activities and they found sufficient evidence to support the charge of war crimes and crimes against humanity perpetrated in the DRC and they issued an arrest warrant, which the French judicial authorities have executed."
nya: khoti lalikulu lozenga milandu pa dziko lonse, linachita kafukufuku wawo wokhudza zina zomwe amachita ndipo linapeza umboni wokwanira wothandizira kuzenga mlandu wa nkhondo komanso milandu yoletsedwa ndi anthu yomwe inachitika mu dziko la DRC, ndipo anaika chikalata chomumanga padziko lonse chomwe akuluakulu a boma la France  akugwiritsa ntchito.
mt0: <pad> The International Criminal Court (ICC) conducted its own investigation and found sufficient evidence to support the prosecution of war crimes and human rights abuses committed in the DRC, and issued an international arrest warrant which the French government is using.</s>

en: The Hague-based court accused Mbarushimana and other rebels in the FDLR of using violence against unarmed civilians as their main tool in a campaign to forcefully obtain political power for the rebel group.
nya: khoti la ku Hague linazenga a Mbarushimana ndi ena oukira mu FDRL pogwiritsa ntchito nkhanza kwa anthu amene analibe zida zilizonse zomenyera nkhondo ndi cholinga chokakamiza kuti iwo atenge ulamuliro wa ndale  ku gulu lawo lowukira.
mt0: <pad> The Hague court convicted Mbarushimana and other rebels in the FDRL of using brutality against people who were not armed with any war weapons with the intent of forcing them to take over political control from their rebel group.</s>

en: According to the ICC, "as a result of this deadly blackmail (by the FDLR rebels), victims were killed, raped, and forcibly displaced, and entire villages were razed to the ground."
nya: Kuchokera ku khoti lapadziko lonse la  ICC, " zotsatira zakuopseza kwa gululi, anthu okhudzidwa anaphedwa, kugwiliridwa, kusamutsidwa mokakamiza  komanso midzi yonse inagwetsedwa ndi kuonongedwa.
mt0: <pad> From the International Criminal Court, " as a result of the threats, the affected people were killed, raped, forced to flee and all villages were destroyed and destroyed."</s>

en: Karugarama said Mbarushimana and his FDLR rebel forces played a pivotal role in the countrys 1994 genocide in which hundreds of thousands of people were killed.
nya: Karugarama anati Mbarushimana ndi gulu lake loukira la FDLR ndi amene anatenga mbali yaikulu pa kuphedwa kwa anthu  mazanamazana komwe kunachitika mu chaka cha 1994.
mt0: <pad> Karugarama said Mbarushimana and his rebel group the FDLR played a major role in the 1994 mass murders.</s>

en: "We believe that, in the next couple of weeks after due process has taken place in France, he should be able to be transferred to The Hague in the Netherlands to face charges and be prosecuted for war crimes and crimes against humanity committed within the territory of the DRC."
nya: "Tikukhulupilira kuti masabata angapo akubwerawa pakatha njira zomwe zikutsatidwa ndi boma la France, iye akuyenera kusamutsidwa ku Hague mu dziko la Netherlands komwe akamuimbe  milandu komanso kuzengedwa  yokhudza nkhondo komanso anthu mu dziko la DRC.
mt0: <pad> "We believe that in a few weeks after the French government's procedures are complete, he will be transferred to The Hague in the Netherlands to be indicted and prosecuted for war crimes and human rights in the DRC."</s>

en: British, French Foreign Ministers to Re-Invigorate DRC Peace Process - 2002-01-18
nya: Nduna za kunja za dziko la Britain ndi france zadzipereka ku ndondomeko yobweretsa mtendere ku dziko la DRC-2002-01-08.
mt0: <pad> The foreign ministers of the UK and France have pledged to help bring peace to the Democratic Republic of Congo.</s>

en: The British and French foreign ministers travel to the Democratic Republic of Congo Monday to kickoff a three-day, four-nation tour of the troubled region of Central Africa.
nya: Nduna za kunja za dziko la Britain ndi France zapita ku dziko la Congo lolemba komwe zikukayendera dera lovutika mu chigawo cha pakati pa Africa.
mt0: <pad> The foreign ministers of the UK and France are in Congo on Tuesday to visit the troubled region in central Africa.</s>

en: The mission will be jointly led by British Foreign Secretary Jack Straw and his French counterpart Hubert Vedrine.
nya: Ntchitoyi ikatsogozedwa mogwirizana ndi  Jack Straw omwe ali mlembi wa maiko ena wa ku Britain komanso a Hubert Vedrine a ku France.
mt0: <pad> The work was led by British Foreign Secretary Jack Straw and French Hubert Vedrine.</s>

en: They will be visiting the Democratic Republic of Congo, Rwanda, Burundi and Uganda.
nya: Iwowa akayendera maiko a Congo, Rwanda, Burundi ndi Uganda.
mt0: <pad> He has visited the Republic of the Congo, Rwanda, Burundi and Uganda.</s>

en: Their primary objective is to breathe new life into the peace process in the war-torn Congo.
nya: Cholinga chawo ndikubweretsa moyo watsopano pamene ndondomeko yodzetsa mtendere ikuchitika mu dziko la Congo
mt0: <pad> Their goal is to bring new life while the peace process is underway in the Republic of the Congo.</s>

en: Specifically, the British and French want to see the withdrawal of foreign troops who back the Congolese government (n Kinshasa, demobilization of rebels who occupy more than half the country, and peace talks to end the conflict.
nya: Makamaka, boma la Britain ndi France likufuna kuti asilikali ankhondo a maiko a kunja amene amathandiza boma la Congo asiye( ku Kinshasa kuwachotsa onse oukira amene anatenga malo  oposa theka la dzikolo, ndi kukambilana mwamtendere kuti mikangano ithe.
mt0: <pad> In particular, the British and French governments want all foreign war troops that support the Republic of the Congo to pull out (from Kinshasa to remove all rebels who have occupied more than half of the country, and to start peace talks to end the conflict.</s>

en: British Foreign Secretary Straw said the mission also has a broader goal of making sure the Congo does not become another Afghanistan.
nya: Mlembi  wakunja wa dziko la Britain a Straw anati ndondomekoyi ili ndi masomphenya aakulu oonetsetsa kuti dziko la Congo lisadzakhale ngatinso dziko la Afghanistan
mt0: <pad> British foreign secretary Jack Straw said the plan was "a major step forward" to ensure that the Republic of the Congo would not be another Rwanda.</s>

en: "The 11th of September has made it much more urgent that we take earlier action against failed, and failing states," he said.
nya: " Tsiku la 11 September linapangitsa kuti izi zikhale zachangu kwambiri moti timachitapo kanthu mwansanga motsutsana ndi kulephera , komanso kulephera madera, iwo anatero.
mt0: <pad> "The 11 September attacks made it so urgent that we took action quickly against the failure, and the failure of regions," they said.</s>

en: In Kinshasa, the ministers will meet Congolese President Joseph Kabila. He took power one year ago, after his father, President Laurent Kabila, was assassinated by one of his bodyguards.
nya: Ku Kinshasa, mtsogoleri wa dzikolo a Kabila akakumana ndi nduna. Iwowa analowa mm'boma chaka chatha pamene abambo awo mtsogoleri Laurent kabila anaphedwa ndi mmodzi  ma anthu owalondera.
mt0: <pad> In Kinshasa, the president of the country Kabila will meet with ministers. He took power last year after his father Laurent Kabila was killed by one of his guards.</s>

en: Their next stop will be Kigali for talks with Rwandan President Paul Kagame, and the leader of the Rally for Congolese Democracy rebels, Adolphe Onusumba.
nya: Akaimanso ku Kigali komwe akakhale ndi zokambirana ndi mtsogoleri wa dziko la Rwanda a Paul Kagame ndi mtsogoleri woukila wa bungwe lotchedwa Congolese Democracy Rebels wa ku Congo a Adolphe Onusumba.
mt0: <pad> He also visited Kigali where he had talks with the president of Rwanda Paul Kagame and the leader of the Congolese Democratic Rebels Adolphe Onusumba.</s>

en: The ministers will make a brief visit to Burundi to discuss that country's civil war with President Pierre Buyoya.
nya: Ndunazo zikakumana mwachidule ndi mtsogoleri wa dziko la Burundi a Pierre Buyoya kukakambirana za nkhondo ya pachiweniweni mu dzikolo.
mt0: <pad> The officials met with the president of Burundi Pierre Buyoya to discuss the ongoing conflict in the country.</s>

en: The tour will end in Uganda, where meetings are scheduled with President Yoweri Museveni and Jean-Pierre Bemba, who leads the Movement for the Liberation of Congo guerrillas.
nya: Ulendowu ukathera ku Uganda komwe kukakhale zokambirana pakati pa atogoleri Yoweri Museveni ndi Jean Pierre Bemba, amene akutsogolera bungwe lodzetsa ufulu ku zigawenga zankhondo za mdziko la Congo.
mt0: <pad> The tour ended in Uganda where the leaders Yoweri Museveni and Jean Pierre Bemba, leader of the Democratic Republic of Congo's rebel group, had talks.</s>

en: UNICEF Pushes for Demobilizing Child Soliders Near Africa's Great Lakes - 2002-10-07
nya: Bungwe la UNICEF lalimbikitsa kwambiri kuletsa ana achisilikari oyandikila dera la  Great lakes ku Afilika- 2002-10-07
mt0: <pad> UNICEF has called for the ban on child soldiers in the Great Lakes region of Africa- 2002</s>

en: The United Nations children's agency, UNICEF, is pushing for child soldiers to be demobilized in Africa's Great Lakes region, as several peace drives there build momentum. The agency says funding is in place to help the children leave the military and restart their lives.
nya: Nthambi yoona za ana ya United nations, UNICEF, likulimbikitsa kuti ana achichepere achisilikali achotsedwe ku dera la Great lakes ku Afilika, pamene mtendere ochuluka umabweretsa mphamvu. Nthambiyi inati pali chithandizo cha chuma chomwe chithandizire anawa kusiya usilikari ndi kukayambiranso moyo wawo.
mt0: <pad> UNICEF is urging the removal of child soldiers from the Great Lakes region in Africa, as peace gains strength. The organization said there was a fund to help the children quit the service and start a new life.</s>

en: UNICEF's top child protection official, Manuel Fontaine, says peace initiatives in Uganda, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Rwanda are making it possible to get more children under the age of 18 out of fighting units. "We insist that child soldiers could be demobilized, even in conflict situations. We should never wait for peace to get children out of any form of armed group. But, obviously, that's a better timing at the moment. It's more conducive to demobilization," Mr. Fontaine said.
nya: Mkulu woona za chitetezo cha ana ku bungwe la UNICEF, a Manuel Fontaine, anati njira zobweretsa mtendere ku Uganda, Congo ndi Rwanda zikupangitsa kuthekera kowachotsa ana ochepera zaka 18 mu malo omenyera nkhondo. "Tikukakamira  kuti asilikali achichepere achotsedwe ngakhale mu nyengo za kusamvetsetsana. Sitikuyenera kudikira nthawi yomwe pali mtendere kuti anawa achotsedwe mu magulu ankhondo. koma mwachidziwikire ino ndi nthawi yoyenera pakadali pano. yowasiyitsa , anatero a Fontane.
mt0: <pad> UNICEF's director of child protection Manuel Fontaine said peace efforts in Uganda, Congo and Rwanda are creating the possibility of removing children under 18 from conflict zones.</s>

en: He says there are currently 1,200 child soldiers in Uganda, fighting mainly with the rebel Lord's Resistance Army. He says that over the past 14 years, the group has abducted some 10,000 children, boys to fight and girls to serve as sex slaves.
nya: Iwo anati pakadali pano ana 1200 achisilikali ali ku Uganda kumenyana ndi gulu loukila la Lords Resistance. Ndipo anati kupitilira zaka 14 zapitazo gululi linagwira ana 10,000, anyamata okamenya nkhondo, atsikana okagona nawo mwaukapolo ndi mokakamiza.
mt0: <pad> They said that at present 1200 soldiers are in Uganda to fight the Lords Resistance. They also said that over the last 14 years the group held 10,000 children, boys and girls, who were forced into service and sex slavery.</s>

en: According to UNICEF, The Democratic Republic of Congo still has some 10,000 children recruited to fight, while Rwanda has up to 2,000 children involved in combat.
nya: Kuchokera ku UNICEF, dziko la Congo lidakali ndi ana okwanira 10,000 omwe anatengedwa kukamenya nkhondo, pamene dziko la Rwanda lili ndi ana 2000 omenya nawonso nkhondo
mt0: <pad> From UNICEF, the Congo still has 10,000 children taken to fight in the war, while Rwanda has 2000 children fighting in the war.</s>

en: UNICEF says, even though some of the children do not directly engage in fighting, they are exposed to many dangers. They may be used as porters, carrying very heavy loads, or as messengers or spies passing information and scouting out enemy territory.
nya: Bungwe la UNICEF linati ngakhale ana ena sakhudzidwa ndi kumenya nkhondo, amaonetsedwa zinthu zoopsa zambiri. Ena amagwiritsidwa ntchito ngati alonda, onyamula katundu wolemera kwambiri, otumidwa kapena a kazitape okatenga nkhani ku malo a adani awo.
mt0: <pad> UNICEF said that even though some children are not directly involved in the war, they are exposed to many dangers. Some are used as traders, heavy duty carriers, messengers or informants in the enemy's camps.</s>

en: Sometimes, boys, but mainly girls, are used as sex slaves. They are exposed to violence and HIV-AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases. The girls may become pregnant, making it harder for them to reintegrate into their communities.
nya: Nthawi zambiri atsikana amagwiritsidwa ntchito ya ukapolo pogona nawo. Iwo amaonetsedwa nkhanza komanso kupatsidwa matenda a HIV ndi matenda ena opatsilana pogonana. Atsikanawa amatha kutenga pakati zomwe zimakhala zovuta kwaiwo kubwelera kwawo.
mt0: <pad> Girls are often used as sex slaves. They are abused and given HIV and other sexually transmitted diseases. They can get pregnant which makes it difficult for them to return home.</s>

en: UNICEF's Manuel Fontaine says demobilization takes time and money. He says the children must first be found, and then removed from their government or rebel units. Then, resources are needed to help them rebuild their lives. That involves providing schools, vocational training and health care.
nya: A Manuel Fontaine a bungwe la UNICEF anati kusiyitsa anawa usilikali kumatenga nthawi ndi ndalama. Iwo anati poyambilira anawa amayenera apezeke kaye kenako ndikuwachotsa mu magulu kapena maboma oukira omwe ali. Ndalama ndi zinthu zina zofunika tsitsi ndi tisku ndizofunika kuti ziwathandize kuyambilanso moyo wawo. monga kuwapezera sukulu yophunzilapo,ntchito za manja, komanso chisamaliro cha thanzi lawo.
mt0: <pad> Manuel Fontaine of UNICEF said that removing the children from the armed forces takes time and money. He said that they need to be found first and then removed from the dangerous groups or governments they are in. Money and other necessities are needed to help them start a new life, such as getting a high school diploma, employment, and medical care.</s>

en: "You do not want to stigmatize them and individualize them. They are basically going back to communities where there are a lot of other children, many of whom have suffered from consequences of war, even if they were not recruited. So, you are trying to build services in those communities that are broad services, that would be made available to all those children," Mr. Fontaine said.
nya: "Simukuyenera kuwasala komanso kuwasiya pawokha. Iwowa akubwelera ku madera omwe kuli ana ena ambiri, amene ambiri mwaiwo akuvutika ndi zotsatira za nkhondo ngakhale sanatengedwe nawo.Ndiye chitukuko chomwe mukuyenera kuchitika mmaderamu chikuyenera kukhala chofikira aliyense, anatero a Fontane.
mt0: <pad> "You can't leave them alone. They are returning to areas where many other children are, who many of them have suffered the effects of the war even before they were adopted. So the development you need to do in these areas must be accessible to everyone," Fontane said.</s>

en: Mr. Fontaine says, as part of various peace packages in the Great Lakes region, the World Bank and other donors are providing $500 million to help demobilize children. He says, unfortunately, the needed government institutions are not yet in place in some countries to move the process ahead quickly enough. He says that's why UNICEF is pressing to see such structures develop, so that children can get back home and start to lead normal lives once again.
nya: A Fontaine anati ngati njira imodzi yobweretsera mtendere mu dera la Great lakes, banki yaikuklu dziko lonse lapansi ndi anthu ena othandiza apereka ndalama zokwana 500 million dollars zothandizira kuchotsa anawa.  Iwo anati mwatsoka mabungwe a maiko ena akuchedwa kuyendetsa ndondomekoyi mwachangu. iwo anati ndi chifukwa chake bungwe la UNICEF likufulumizitsa kumanga malowo ndi cholinga choti malo anawo abwelere kwawo ndikukayamba kukakhalanso moyo wabwinobwino.
mt0: <pad> The UN has announced that the United Nations Children's Fund and other international donors have offered $500 million to help with the removal of the children.</s>

en: World Bank, Nike Team Up for 'The Girl Effect' Initiative
nya: Banki yaikulu pa dziko lonse, komanso bungwe la nike apanga mgwirizano wothandiza atsikana wotchedwa Girl Effect.
mt0: <pad> The world's biggest bank, and the athletics company Nike have joined forces to support girls called Girl Effect.</s>

en: The Adolescent Girls Initiative partners the World Bank, the Nike Foundation and governments of developing and developed nations to empower girls in poor countries.
nya: Bungwe la atsikanali lapanga ubale ndi banki yaikulu padziko, Bungwe la Nike komanso maiko otukuka ndi amene akutukuka ndi cholinga cholimbikitsa atsikana a mmaiko osauka.
mt0: <pad> The women's organization has formed partnerships with the world's biggest bank, Nike and developed and developing countries with the aim of empowering girls in low-income countries.</s>

en: The two-year-old program is helping girls in Asia, Africa and the Middle East gain the education and skills they need to transition into the workforce.
nya: Pologalamu ya zaka ziwiri yi, ikuthandiza maphunziro a  atsikana a ku Asia, Africa ndi ku Ulaya  komanso ntchito zamanja zomwe angapite nazo mmalo a ntchito.
mt0: <pad> This two-year program supports the education of girls from Asia, Africa and Europe and modern skills that they can bring to their workplace.</s>

en: "My name is Sanchita. I come from a small village called Ishwarpur in Bangladesh," American actress Anne Hathaway delivered her lines as powerfully from behind a podium at the World Bank as she does on the silver screen, telling the story of an impoverished girl.
nya: " Dzina langa ndi Sanchita. Ndimachokera ku mudzi waung'ono wotchedwa Ishwarpur ku Bangladesh," mzimayi wa zisudzo Anne Hathaway anafotokoza mwamphamvu mizere  yake ya mu sewero  pamene anaima pa nsanja ya ku banki lalikulu ngati mmene amachitira pa kanema, akufotokoza nkhani  ya mtsikana wosauka.
mt0: <pad> "My name is Sanchita. I come from a small village called Ishwarpur in Bangladesh," the actress Anne Hathaway explained her character line as she stood on the bank platform like in the movie, telling the story of a poor girl from a small village in Bangladesh.</s>

en: "When a baby is born in Ishwarpur, families desperately hope it will be a boy," she continued. "It has been this way for as long as anyone can remember.
nya: "Mwana akabadwa ku Ishwarpur, mabanja amayembekezera kuti akhala wamwamuna,"  iye anapitiliza. Zakhala zili chonchi kwa nthawi yaitali.
mt0: <pad> "When a child is born in Ishwarpur, families expect a boy," he continued. This has been the case for a long time.</s>

en: It is believed that boys will contribute to the family income in a place where people are very poor.
nya: Anyamata amakhulupiridwa kuti ndiamene angapereke thandizo la zachuma pamalo pamene anthu ake ndiosauka kwambiri.
mt0: <pad> Men are believed to be the only ones who can provide financial support to a poor family when its people are extremely poor.</s>

en: "These circumstances are familiar to those who benefit from the Adolescent Girls Initiative.
nya: "Nyengo zimenezi ndi zofananira ndi anthu amene amapindula ku ndondomeko yothandiza atsikana otha msinkhu.
mt0: <pad> "These situations are similar to those who benefit from the program for teen girls.</s>

en: Who benefits?A dozen such teenage girls and young women visited the World Bank from developing Asian, Middle Eastern and African countries.
nya: "Amene amapindula ndindani? Atsikana komanso azimayi anapita ku banki yaikulu padziko lonse kuchokera ku maiko omwe akutukuka a kwa amwenye, ku Africa komanso ku Asia.
mt0: <pad> Who wins? Women and girls went to the world's biggest bank from developing countries in Western, African and Asian countries.</s>

en: They were just a few of the girls who benefit from training and education programs that help them transition from school to employment.
nya: Atsikana ochepa mwa iwo ndi amene anapindula ku sukulu ndi maphunziro a ukadaulo owathandizira kupeza ntchito.
mt0: <pad> Some of them have gone to school and received technical education that helped them find a job.</s>

en: Hathaway told the audience that, with the help of a development organization, Sanchita gained an education and borrowed $60 to buy a cow and start a vegetable garden.
nya: Hathaway anauza gululo kuti ndiichithandizo chochokera ku bungwe lina, Sanchita anachita maphunziro ndikubwereka ndalama zokwana 60 dollars zogulira ng'ombe ndikuyamba dimba la masamba.
mt0: <pad> Hathaway told the group that it was a donation from another organization, Sanchita went to school and borrow 60 dollars to buy pigs and start a vegetable garden.</s>

en: The teenage girl could then afford to pay her own school fees, as well as her brother's, and contribute to her family in such a way that Sanchita's parents hope she does not marry any time soon.Hathaway spoke of her own childhood in a comfortable suburban U.S. neighborhood, and of a time when she had no idea about the kind of circumstances Sanchita faced nor how much girls need safe spaces for education.
nya: Mtsikana wachichepereyu anakwanitsa kudzilipilira yekha sukulu, azichimwene ake komanso kuthandiza banja lakwawo pamenenso makolo ake  akuyembekeza kuti iyeyu sakwatira pompano. Hathaway  anafotokozanso za mmene iye anakulira ndi moyo wofewa ku tawuni mu dziko la America, pamene panthawiyo iye sanadziweko nyengo zomwe Sanchita amadutsamo komanso mmene atsikana amafunira malo obwino ochitirapo maphunziro awo.

en: To help mend the nation, President Mandela appointed Tutu as head of the country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission. The group issued a report that included numerous confessions of guilt under apartheid in return for amnesty.
nya: Pothandizira kukonza dziko, mtsogoleri wa dzikolo a Mandela anasankha a Tutu kukhala mkulu wa oyendetsa chilungamo ndi mgwirizano. Gululi linatulutsa lipoti lomwe linakamba zinthu zambiri kuphatikizapo anthu omwe amalapo ndi zoipa zomwe anachita mu nthawi ya utsamunda.
mt0: <pad> To help rebuild the country, the president Mandela appointed Tutu as the chair of the commission on justice and reconciliation. The commission issued a report that included many things including victims of crimes committed during the apartheid period.</s>

en: "It makes specific proposals on how we can cultivate a culture of human rights and of structures to insure that the atrocities of the past will not reoccur," Tutu said.Tutu also campaigned to fight poverty and AIDS.
nya: "Ma pempho apaderadera  ndi amene angachititse kuti tikhazikitse ufulu komanso njira zoonetsetsa kuti mchitidwe wankhanza wakale sudzachitikanso," anatero a Tutu. A Tutu analimbikitsanso kulimbana ndi umphawi komanso matenda a Edzi.
mt0: <pad> "The special requests are the only ones that can help us to establish freedom and measures to ensure that the past violence never happens again," Tutu said.</s>

en: In recent years, he expressed his disappointment in post-apartheid South Africa, especially the level of violent crime.
nya: Zaka zapitazi iwo anafotokoza za kusasangalala kwawo pa kukwera kwa milandu ya  nkhanza yomwe ikuchitika patatha ulamuliro wa tsankho mu dziko la South Africa.
mt0: <pad> Last year they expressed their discontent with the rise in crimes committed after the end of apartheid in South Africa.</s>

en: Despite his withdrawal from public life, Tutu says he will continue to support his peace foundation and will remain part of a group of elder statesmen who campaign for peace and human rights.
nya: Ngakhale a Tutu anasiya kuonekera ku gulu, iwo anati apitilizabe kuima pambuyo pa bungwe lawo la mtendere komanso gulu la akuluakulu a dziko omwe amalimbikitsa ufulu ndi mtendere.
mt0: <pad> Although Tutu has stopped appearing in public, he said he will continue to stand behind his peace organization and the international group of senior leaders who promote freedom and peace.</s>

en: But Tutu says he will no longer give interviews and, as he put it, will mostly "shut up."
nya: A Tutu anati iwo azingokhala chete chifukwa sadzaperekanso mwayi wofunsidwa mafunso.
mt0: <pad> Tutu said they would be quiet because they would not give any more questions.</s>

en: "I have been part of our struggle for freedom and democracy, and I am part of the celebration that we did succeed," he said. "I have been part of the post apartheid dispensation and long for us to do infinitely better."Many say his voice will be missed.
nya: "Ndakhala mbali yomenyera ufulu wa ulamuliro wa aliyense, komanso mbali ya kusangalala chipambano chathu, " iwo anatero. "Ndakhala mbali ya olamulira atsamunda atachoka komanso kulimbika kuti tichite bwino." Ambiri anati mawu awo awasowa.
mt0: <pad> "I've been part of the fight for equal rule, and part of celebrating our success, " they said. "I've been part of the colonists leaving and determined to do well."</s>

en: Malawi's Jacaranda School for Orphans Celebrates Christmas
nya: Sukula ya ana amasiye ya Jacaranda ku dziko la malawi, yasangalala khilisimasi.
mt0: <pad> The Jacaranda orphanage in Malawi celebrated Christmas.</s>

en: The management for the Jacaranda School for Orphans in Malawis commercial capital Blantyre recently hosted a party for its students as it closed for Christmas and New Years Day holidays.
nya: Oyendetsa sukulu ya ana amasiye ya Jacaranda mu mzinda wa Blantyre dziko la Malawi masiku apitawa anachititsa phwando kwa ana awo ophunzira pamene amatsekera kukapuma mu nyengo ya khilisimasi ndi nyuwere.
mt0: <pad> The managers of Jacaranda orphanage school in Blantyre, Malawi recently held a party for their students as they closed for the Christmas and New Year break.</s>

en: Around 500 people including students, staff members and others from surrounding areas attended the event, which was held at the schools premises in Chigumula area.
nya: Anthu okwana 500 kuonjezelapo ana a sukulu, ogwira ntchito ndi ena ochokera mmadera ozungulira anabwera ku phwandoli lomwe linachitikila ku malo awo a ku Chigumula.
mt0: <pad> 500 people including schoolchildren, workers and others from the surrounding areas came to the party held at their home in Chigumula.</s>

en: The party included gifts, Santa Claus, and a "dancing show case" by the students.
nya: Ku phwandoli kunali mphatso,  Santa claus komanso  gulu lovina la ana ophunzirawo.
mt0: <pad> The party included presents, Santa Claus and a singing group of students.</s>

en: The school management told VOA that the yearly celebration has been a school tradition for the past 13years.
nya: Oyendetsa sukuluyo anauza wailesi ya VOA kuti chisangalalo cha pa chakachi ndi mwambo wawo omwe wakhala ukuchitika kwa zaka khumi ndi zitatu zapitazo.
mt0: <pad> The school told the VOA that this year's celebration is their tradition for the past 13 years.</s>

en: The school's director, Luc Deschamps, said: "[We feel] it is very important for us to celebrate Christmas because the children do not have parents.
nya: Mkulu woyang'anira sukuluyo a Luc Deschamps anati "ndikofunukira kusangalala khilisimasi chifukwa anawa alibe makolo awo."
mt0: <pad> Luc Deschamps, the head of the school said "it was difficult to celebrate Christmas because the children don't have their parents."</s>

en: They stay with either a grandmother or a distant aunt or uncle, and they are not able to cerebrate at home or have a party or a little bit of sweets and cake for the children. So, we provide a happy day for the children to celebrate the spirit of Christmas. And it is also a way of our children to learn to give."
nya: Iwowa amakhala ndi  agogo awo kapena amalume, azakhali achibale chapatali ndipo samakwanitsa kusangalala kwawo kapena kuchita phwando nadya ma suwiti ndi ma keke. Ndiye timakonza tsiku lachisangalalo kwa anawa kuti asangalale khilisimasi
mt0: <pad> They live with their grandparents or uncles, they are distant relatives and can't have their own Christmas or party and eat cookies and cake. So we plan a day of fun for these children to enjoy Christmas.</s>

en: No media source currently available
nya: Palibe umboni wochokera ku nyumba zofalitsa nkhani.
mt0: <pad> No evidence from the media.</s>

en: Deschamps, who is also an Honorary Consul of France in Malawi, said before the main event the patrons were treated to "a nice meal" from the students.
nya: A Deschamps amene ali  oimila dziko la France kuno ku Malawi amati mwambowo usanayambe   akuluakulu othandiza sukuluyo anapatsidwa chakudya chabwino kuchokera kwa anawo.
mt0: <pad> A Deschamps, a French ambassador to Malawi, said that before the ceremony, the school's sponsors were given a good meal by the children.</s>

en: "We had a big, big lunch with good meat and rice,[the dish made from maize flour called] nsima, of course, and vegetables. And it was the students themselves who cooked the meal for everybody, for over 500 people," he said.
nya: "Tinali ndi nkhomaliro yopambana ya mpunga ndi nyama komanso nsima ndi masamba.anawa ndiamene anaphika chakudya cha aliyensechi chopitilira anthu 500,"  iwo anatero.
mt0: <pad> "We had a delicious rice and meat curry and nsima and vegetables. These are the people who cooked this meal for over 500 people," they said.</s>

en: One of the students, Eddah Zimba, said, "The celebrations are really cool, ... I have enjoyed myself. I have eaten, and now I am here dancing. What has interested me most is the gift that we have received the like the puffs, the biscuits, the squash and the dance."
nya: Mmodzi mwa ophunzirawo , Eddah zimba anati, " chisangalalochi ndi chabwino, ndakondwa kwambiri. Ndadya, pano ndikuvuna. Chomwe chandisangalatsa kwambiri ndi mphatso zomwe talandira ngati kamba, ma bisiketi, zakumwa ndi mavinidwe.
mt0: <pad> One of the students, Eddah Zimba said, "The festival is good, I am very happy. I have been eating, here I am harvesting. What I like most is the presents we received like bananas, cookies, drinks and music."</s>

en: She thanked the schools management for hosting the Christmas party for students who in most cases do not have such celebrations at home.
nya: Iye anathokoza akuluakulu a sukuluyo powakonzera ophunzirawo  phwando la khilisimasi chifukwa nthawi zambiri sakhala ndi chisangalalocho mmakwawo.
mt0: <pad> He thanked the school authorities for organizing the students a Christmas party because they often don't have that kind of joy in their families.</s>

en: Another student Emmanuel Chisale said good meal aside, the event has taught him the spirit of sharing.
nya: Ophunzira wina Emmanuel Chisale anati pambali pa chakudya chabwino , phwandolo lamuphunzitsa mtima wogawana.
mt0: <pad> One student Emmanuel Chisale said that besides the good food, the party taught him the spirit of sharing.</s>

en: "This party has brought a change in my life. I have learned that we have to have a heart for sharing one another as the Father Christmas was doing," he said.
nya: "Phwando labweretsa kusintha m'moyo wanga. Ndaphunzira kuti tikuyenera kukhala ndi mtima wogailana zinthu wina ndi mnzake ngati mmene tate wa Khilisimasi amachitira," iye anatero.
mt0: <pad> "The holiday has changed my life. I learned that we should be sharing like the Christmas Father," she said.</s>

en: Founded in 2002, the Jacaranda School for Orphans is the only one in Malawi which provides free primary, secondary and tertiary education to children without parents.
nya: Sukulu ya ana amasiye ya Jacaranda yomwe inayambidwa mu chaka cha 2002, ndisukulu yokhayo yomwe imapereka maphunziiro aulele a ku pulaimale, sekondale komanso sukulu yaukachenjede  kwa ana amasiye.
mt0: <pad> Jacaranda Orphanage School, founded in 2002, is the only school in Ecuador that provides free primary, secondary and vocational education to orphans.</s>

en: A Malawian woman, Marie Da Silva, started the school after she returned from the United States where she spent nineteen years working as a nanny.
nya: Marie Da silva, mzimayi wachimalawi ndi amene anatsekula sukuluyi atakhala zaka 19 ku America komwe amagwira ntchito yosamalira anthu.
mt0: <pad> Marie Da Silva, a Malawian woman, founded the school after 19 years in America where she worked as a nurse.</s>

en: Economists Predict Bumpy Road for Malawi's Economy in 2015
nya: Olondoloza  zachuma aneneratu kuti chuma cha dziko la Malawi chitha osayenda bwino mu chaka cha 2015.
mt0: <pad> Economic analysts predict that the Malawian economy may not be doing well in 2015.</s>

en: Economists in Malawi say the country is likely to continue facing financial challenges in 2015 unless the government can regain the confidence of donors, who are still withholding 40 percent of budgetary support due to the corruption scandal known as Cashgate. More than $30 million were looted from government coffers in the scandal, and several people, including government officials, were arrested.
nya: Olondoloza chuma mu dziko la Malawi afotokoza kuti dziko lino litha kupitilira kukumana ndi mavuto a zachuma pokhapokha anthu othandiza ataloweleleraponso, anthu othandizawa sanapereke mbali ya chithandizo cha ndalama yogwiritsira ntchito ku boma chokwanira gawo la 40% kamba ka mchitidwe wa katangale wotchedwa cashgate. Ndalama zopitilira 30 million dollars ndi zomwe zinabedwa kuboma. Anthu ambiri  kuphatikizapo ogwira ntchito m'boma anamangidwa.
mt0: <pad> Malawi's economic watchdog has warned that the country will continue to face financial difficulties unless aid donors step in, aid donors have withheld a 40% share of government expenditure due to the cashgate.</s>

en: The withholding of donor aid has forced Malawi's government to pass what is known as the Zero Aid national budget for the 2014-2015 fiscal year. Analysts, such as Abel Mwanyungwe, an economics lecturer at the Polytechnic College of the University of Malawi, say the drop in spending has hurt the economy.
nya: Kuimitsidwa kwa chithandizo chochokera maiko ena kwakakamiza dziko la malawi kudutsitsa madongosolo a ndalama  a chaka cha 2014-2015 otchedwa Zero Aid national budget. A  Abel Mwanyungwe mmodzi ounguza komanso mphunzitsi wa ndondomeko za chuma ku sukulu ya ukachenjede ya Polytechnic College anati kutsika kwa kagwiritsidwe ntchito ka ndalama  kwasokoneza ndondomeko ya chuma.
mt0: <pad> The suspension of aid from other countries has forced Malawi to cut its budget for the 2014-2015 fiscal year to zero aid.</s>

en: "This has been a bumpy year as we are coming from the Cashgate effects that have quite a major dent on the economys performance. We have seen that in most cases the very delicate and crucial departments and service providers have been affected, in the sense that we dont have enough drugs in the hospitals. In schools, in terms of teachers payments is not in time," said Mwanyungwe.
nya: "Chaka chino chakhala chovuta kwambiri pamene tikuchokera kuzotsatira za Cashgate zimene zaononga kayendetsedwe ka chuma. Malo antchito ambiri komanso anthu obweretsa katundu mdzikoli akhudzidwa monga tilibe mankhwala mzipatala, komanso malipiro a aphunzitsi sakumafika mu nthawi yake, anatero a mwanyungwe.
mt0: <pad> "This year has been the most difficult as we recover from the effects of the Cashgate which have damaged the financial system. Many companies and importers have been affected as there are no medicines in hospitals, and teacher pay is not paid on time," said the official.</s>

en: Mwanyungwe also links Cashgate to the recent depreciation of Malawis currency, the kwacha, which has resulted in strikes by various government workers demanding higher pay.
nya: A Manyungwe analumikizanso kutsika kwa ndalama ya Malawi ndi kubedwa kwa ndalama mosakadza komwe kunachitika, zomwe zachititsa zionetsero kuchokera kwa  anthu osiyanasiyana ogwira ntchito m'boma pomwe akufuna kukwezedwa malipiro awo.
mt0: <pad> Manyungwe also linked the fall in the Malawian currency to the widespread embezzlement, which has led to protests by different government employees demanding a raise in their pay.</s>

en: For example, support staff for the judiciary have been on strike for six weeks, seeking a 45 percent pay increase which the government says it cannot afford because it has no money.
nya: Mwachitsanzo anthu othandizira ntchito ku khoti akhala akunyanyala ntchito kwa masabata asanu ndi imodzi pofuna kuti malipiro awo akwezedwe kufika pa 45% zomwe aboma akuti sangakwanitse kutero  chifukwa alibe ndalama.
mt0: <pad> For example, court assistants have been on strike for eight weeks to demand a 45% pay raise, which the government says it can't do because it doesn't have the money.</s>

en: Workers at Malawi's Anti-Corruption Bureau went on strike demanding a 70 percent pay raise until the government threatened to forfeit their December salaries if they did not return.
nya: Ogwira ntchito a ku bungwe lothana ndi ziphuphu ananyanyala ntchito pofuna kuti malipiro awo akwezedwe kufika pa 70%  koma a boma anawaopseza kuti salandira malipiro awo a mwezi wa Disembala ngati sabwelera kunchito.
mt0: <pad> The employees of the anti-corruption organization went on strike to demand a 70% pay hike but the government threatened them with not receiving their December salary if they did not return to work.</s>

en: Mwanyungwe said the government can only avoid further strikes in 2015 if it makes efforts to restore donor confidence in the management of its public finances.
nya: A Manyungwe anati boma litha kupewa kunyanyala ntchito kwinanso mu chaka cha 2015 ngati lingayesetse  kubwezeretsa chikhulupiliro cha anthu othandiza boma pa kagwiritsidwe ntchito ka ndalama za dziko.
mt0: <pad> The government can avoid another general strike in 2015 if it tries to regain the trust of the people who support it on its use of public money.</s>

en: "My fear is that if we dont have this donor confidence and donor support coming back to the economy, we may force the government to go into serious local borrowing that would lead to serious repercussions in terms of inflation, in terms of interest rates and this may have a sort of catch-catch lose situation," said Mwanyungwe.
nya: Chomwe ndikuopa ndichakuti ngati athu otithandiza sangatikhulupilirenso, ndikukhalanso opanda chithandizo ku ndondomeko ya chuma chathu, boma litha kukakamizidwa kukabwerekanso ndalama mudziko mommuno zomwe zingadzetse mavuto monga kukwera kwa zinthu, kudzera mu ndalama yaapamwamba yoperekedwa pobweza ndalama. Iyi ndi nyengo yapakatikati, anatero a Manyungwe.
mt0: <pad> I'm afraid that if our donors don't trust us anymore, and we lose support for our economic policy, the government may be forced to reinvest in the country which can lead to problems like price increases, through a high interest rate on the loan. This is a midterm period, said Mr Manyungwe.</s>

en: The donors are, among other things, demanding that the government prosecute all those involved in the scandal and strengthen its financial management system.
nya: Mwa zina zomwe anthu othandizawa akufuna dziko lichite ndi kumanga anthu onse amene anakhudzidwa ndi kuba ndalamazo ndicholinga cholimbitsa njira ya  kagwiritsidwe ntchito ka ndalama.
mt0: <pad> Other goals they want the country to have include rebuilding all people affected by the money laundering in order to strengthen the system of fiscal management.</s>

en: Newton Kambala, the president of the Malawi Confederation of Chambers of Commerce and Industry, said the scandal rendered 2014 as "a very bad year for the business sector, because of huge debts that the government owes the private sector."
nya: Mtsogoleri wa bungwe la Malawi Confederation of Chambers of commerce and Industry a Newton kambala, anati kuba ndalama komwe kunachitika mu chaka cha 2014 kunaipitsa nthambi ya anthu ochita malonda chifukwa cha ngongole zochuluka zomwe boma linali nazo kwa anthu a malondawa.
mt0: <pad> The chief of the Malawi Confederation of Chambers of Commerce and Industry Newton kambala said the 2014 financial scandal has affected the business sector because of the large debts that the government had to pay to the business community.</s>

en: He warned that if the situation persists, "2015 will be worse."
nya: Iwo anachenjeza kuti ngati zipitilire chonchi, chaka cha 2015 chidzaipa kuposera pano.
mt0: <pad> They warned that if this continues, 2015 will be even worse.</s>

en: In his state of the nation address last Saturday, Malawi president Peter Mutharika said his government is doing everything possible to address the problems caused by the Cashgate scandal.
nya: Mtsogoleri wa dziko lino a Peter Mutharika pamene amalankhula ku  mtundu wa a  Malawi loweruka lapitali, anati boma lawo likuyesetsa kuchita mothekera kukonza mavuto amene anadza ndi kuba ndalama.
mt0: <pad> The President of the Republic of Malawi, Peter Mutharika, when he spoke to the nation on Sunday, said his government is trying to do all it can to fix the problems caused by the money theft.</s>

en: "My government has strengthened the financial system to make sure that Cashgate never occurs again in Malawi. We have resourced fairly well the law enforcement institutions, including the Anti-Corruption Bureau, so that they do a thorough independent job, prosecute all suspects, and recover the stolen resources where possible," said Mutharika.
nya: Boma langa lakhwimitsa malamulo ku nthambi ya zachuma oonetsetsa kuti kuba ndalama mosakadza kusadzachitikenso mu dziko la Malawi. Tayesetsa kupereka katundu wokwanira wogwilira ntchito mu mabungwe a malamulo,  othetsa katangale kuti agwire ntchito  moyenelera, amange onse akuganiziridwa, komanso kulanda katundu yense anabedwa ngati kuli kotheka," anatero a Mutharika.
mt0: <pad> My government has tightened up the law in the financial sector to ensure that money laundering will never happen again in Malawi. We have tried to provide adequate equipment to the law enforcement, anti-corruption agencies to work effectively, arrest all suspects and seize any stolen property if possible," he said.</s>

en: Mutharika also said his government is implementing newly-adopted fiscal reforms that seek to grow the countrys economy by 5.5 percent in 2014, up from an estimated 5.0 percent in 2013.
nya: A Mutharika anatinso boma lawo libweretsa njira yatsopano ya kagwiritsidwe ntchito ka ndalama zaboma kamene kakulitse chuma cha dziko kufika pa 5.5% mu chaka  cha 2014 kuchokera pa 5.0 percent mu chaka cha 2013.
mt0: <pad> Mutharika also said that the government had introduced a new fiscal policy that boosted the country's economic growth to 5.5% in 2014 from 5.0 percent in 2013.</s>

en: Malawi to Conduct Door-to-Door HIV Testing
nya: Dziko la Malawi liyamba kuyeza matenda a edzi khomo ndi khomo.
mt0: <pad> Malawi has begun to test for dengue fever every doorstep.</s>

en: Malawians have mixed reactions to government plans to introduce door-to door HIV testing early next year. Supporters say the step is urgently needed because 100 Malawians get infected each day, and an average of 138 die from AIDS daily. Minister of Health Jean Kalirani announced the plans during the recent commemoration of World AIDS Day in the northern district of Karonga.
nya: Amalawi  ali ndi maganizo osiyanasiyana pamene boma likukonzekera kuyambitsa kuyeza matenda a edzi khomo ndi khomo kumayambiliro kwa chaka cha mawa. Omwe ali pa mbuyo pa maganizowa akuti njirayi ikufunika kwambiri chifukwa tsiku lilironse amalawi 100 amatenga matendawa ndipo anthu osachepera 138 amamwalira tsiku lilironse ndi matenda a Edzi. nduna ya zaumoyo a Jean Kalirani analengeza ndondomekoyi pa tsiku lokumbukira matenda a Edzi mu boma la Karonga.
mt0: <pad> Malawians have different views on the government's plan to start testing for Ebola every doorstep in the country starting next year.</s>

en: "We will go in the villages asking for blood samples to check whether that person is HIV positive or not. And those that will be found HIV positive will definitely be given the care they need. And those who are found negative will also be counseled so that they remain negative," said Kalirani.
nya: Tizipita mmidzi kukatenga magazi kwa anthu pofuna kudziwa ngati ali ndi kachiromboko kapena ayi. Amene azipezeka ndi matendawo azipatsidwa chisamaliro choyenera. Ndipo amene alibe azipatsidwa malangizo a mmene angakhalire osatengabe matendawo, anatero a kalirani.
mt0: <pad> We will go into the communities to take blood from people to see if they have the virus. Those who are found to be infected will be treated properly. Those who are not infected will be given instructions on how to prevent transmission of the virus, said Dr. Kalirani.</s>

en: Kalirani said the campaign will start in mid-March and will aim to reach everyone in the country, including people who are far from health facilities that provide HIV testing and counseling services. She said the campaign is in line with the goal of ending HIV infection by 2030. Malawi's HIV infection rate is currently at 10 percent, a slight drop from three years ago.
nya: A kalirani anati ntchitoyi iyamba mkatikati mwa mwezi wa Malichi ndipo afikira munthu aliyense amene ali ndi kachilombo kapena ayi, kuphatikizapo anthu amene anatalikilana ndi zipatala zazing'ono zomwe zimayeza magazi komanso kupereka uphungu. Iwo anati ntchitoyi ikulingana ndi cholinga chothetsa kutenga kachilombo ka HIV pofikira chaka cha 2030. 10% ndi mlingo wa katengedwe ka matendawa mu dziko lino komwe katsika kuchokera zaka zitatu zapitazo.
mt0: <pad> The officials said the campaign will target all people in the country, whether they have HIV or not, and will cover everyone who is at risk of contracting the disease.</s>

en: The announcement has raised fears in some Malawians, such as Steven Jailosi, a primary school teacher in rural Blantyre, who feel the campaign will likely infringe upon peoples privacy.
nya: Izi zitalengezedwa, zadzetsa mantha mwa amalawi ena ngati  a Steven Jailosi mphunzitsi wa sukulu ya pulaimale mu mzinda wa Blantyre amene akuona ngati  ntchitoyi idzaika zinsinsi za anthu poyera.
mt0: <pad> When this was announced, it has caused concern to some Malawians like Steven Jailosi a teacher at a primary school in Blantyre who fears that the project will put people's privacy at risk.</s>

en: "I think it is not okay because they will be invading our privacy. HIV testing is supposed to be private. No one is supposed to know that I went for an HIV testing unless I make a choice to tell them," said Jailosi.
nya: Ine ndikuona ngati njirayi siyabwino chifukwa ndizosemphana ndi moyo wathu wa Chinsinsi. Kuyezetsa magazi kumayenera kukhala kobisika. Palibe amene amayenera kudziwa zoti ndinapita kukayezetsa magazi pokhapokha nditapanga chisankho chomuuza, anatero a Jailosi.
mt0: <pad> I think this is not a good idea because it's inconsistent with our privacy. Blood tests should be confidential. No one should know that I went for a blood test unless I decide to tell him, said Jailosi.</s>

en: Ester Makonokaya, a secretary in Blantyre, said that although she has been tested already, she feels the door-to-door HIV testing will violate people's privacy.
nya: A Ester Makonokaya,  mlembi mu mzinda wa Blantyre anena kuti ngakhale iwo ayezedwa kale akuona kuti kuyeza magazi khomo ndi khomo ndi kuononga zinsinsi za anthu.
mt0: <pad> Ester Makonokaya, a spokesperson for Blantyre said that although they have been tested, they feel that testing at every doorstep is breaking the privacy of people.</s>

en: "Government should instead take the mobile clinics to the villages where people will be able to access them on their own rather than taking testing in their homes, because that might mean that some of the people who are not supposed to know other peoples status will know because, you know, when someone has been tested you show some reactions," said Makonokaya.
nya: Boma likuyenera kutenga zipatala zoyendera mmidzi komwe anthu akakwanitse kuyezetsa pawokha kusiyana ndi kuyezedwa mmakomo mwawo, chifukwa anthu amene samayenera kudziwa zotsatira zawo atha kudziwa chifukwa munthu amene wayezedwa magazi khalidwe lake limasintha, anatero a Makonokaya.
mt0: <pad> The government should take mobile clinics to ensure that people can test themselves instead of being tested in their homes, because people who don't want to know the results of a blood test can know because a person who has been tested for HIV changes his behavior, said Mr Makonokaya.</s>

en: Macpherson Maulana, a journalist in Blantyre and a producer of radio programs on health, told VOA that government would do better to educate Malawians on the need for HIV testing so that people will go for tests on their own "without being pushed."
nya: A Macpherson Maulana, mtolankhani komanso wokonza ma pologalamu a zaumoyo  mu mzinda wa Blantyre anauza wailesi ya VOA kuti boma likuyenera kuphunzitsa anthu ubwino woyezetsa magatsi ndicholinga choti anthu akayezetse pawokha mosakakamizidwa.
mt0: <pad> A Macpherson Maulana, a journalist and presenter of health programs in Blantyre, told the VOA that the government should educate people about the importance of testing for HIV so that people can test themselves without being forced.</s>

en: "I fear it could end up into fights. You see it happened in Liberia recently where people who were coming to help people suspected to have contracted Ebola were even killed. So, civic education is the most important element for people to be encouraged to come out for testing voluntarily," said Maulana.
nya: Ndikuopa kuti izi zitha kuyambitsa kumenyana. Ku dziko la Liberia pompano anthu amene anapita kukathandiza anthu owaganizira kuti anali ndi matenda a Ebola anaphedwa. Choncho anthuwa akuyenera kuwaphunzitsa kuti alimbikitsidwe kukayezetsa mwakufuna kwawo,  anatero a Maulana.
mt0: <pad> I'm afraid this could lead to conflict. In Liberia recently people who helped Ebola patients were killed. So they need to be educated to be encouraged to get tested voluntarily, he said.</s>

en: However, HIV/AIDS counselor David Odali, whose NGO Umunthu Foundation runs HIV-related projects, insisted privacy will be protected.
nya: Mlangizi wa matenda a HIV a David Odali omwe ali ndi bungwe lawo logwira ntchito zokhudzana ndi matenda a Edzi lotchedwa Umunthu Foundation anatsimikiza kuti zinsinsi za anthu ndi zotetezedwa.
mt0: <pad> David O'Dowd, a HIV specialist with the Humanity Foundation, has confirmed that privacy is protected.</s>

en: "Confidentiality will be upheld. Lets consider the household setup. I think the first thing would be to provide group counseling to members of that family. [Of course] people can be tested while others are watching, but when it comes to disclosing the results, a counselor is supposed to disclose that results to each and every individual separately," said Odali.
nya: Zinsinsi za anthu zidzasungidwa, tikatengera mmene nyumba imakhalira, chinthu choyambilira ndi kulangiza anthu a nyumba yonse pamodzi. Kenako aliyense atha kuyezedwa pomwepo aliyense akuona koma popereka zotsatira za magazi mlangiziyo akuyenera kumuuza munthu aliyense payekha, anatero a Odali.
mt0: <pad> The privacy of the people will be kept, depending on the structure of the house, the first thing is to warn the whole house together. After that everyone can be tested in front of everyone but the doctor must tell each person individually when giving the blood results, said Mr Odale.</s>

en: Odali said it will be up to the person who has been tested to disclose his or her status.
nya: A Odali anati zili kwa munthu yemwe wayezedwa kuulula zotsatira za magazi ake.
mt0: <pad> Odal said they belong to a man who has been tested for HIV.</s>

en: In 2006, the charity Development Aid from People to People conducted door-to-door HIV testing in the district of Thyolo and Blantyre, reaching 400,000 people. The organization says it worked well.
nya: Mu chaka cha 2006 a Bungwe lothandiza anthu la Charity Development Aid from people to people anayeza magazi khomo ndi khomo anthu okwanira 400,000 mu maboma a Blantyre ndi Thyolo ndipo anati zinayenda bwino.
mt0: <pad> In 2006, Charity Development Aid from people to people tested 400,000 people in Blantyre and Thyolo counties and said it was a success.</s>

en: Water Crisis Raises Fears of Waterborne Disease in Malawi
nya: Kusowa kwa  madzi kwabweretsa mantha kwa Malawi odzetsa matenda amene amayamba ndi madzi opanda ukhondo.
mt0: <pad> Water shortage has brought fears to Malawi of the risk of disease that starts with unclean water.</s>

en: Malawians in the country's commercial capital, Blantyre, usually rely on tap water. But for the past five months, the taps have often run dry, forcing residents to draw water from unprotected sources like rivers and wells, while work is being done at the city main pumping station.The risk of contracting water-borne diseases is rising.
nya: A Malawi okhala mu mzinda wa malonda wa  Blantyre amadalira madzi a pa mpopi. Koma miyezi isanu yapitayi, mipopi yakhala youma zomwe zimakakamiza anthu kukatunga madzi ku zitsime ndi mitsinje komwe madzi ake siotetezedwa, izi zikuchitika pamene akukuakulu amu mzinda akupopa madzi kuchokera ku mgodi wawo. Njira yotengera matenda a madzi opanda ukhondo ikuchulukirabe.
mt0: <pad> Malawians in Blantyre depend on tap water. But for the past five months, the taps have been drying out which has forced people to go to fetch water from wells and rivers where the water is not cleaned. The risk of contracting disease from unsafe water is increasing.</s>

en: In Blantyre and surrounding areas, residents have spent five days without tap water.
nya: Anthu a boma la Blantyre ndi malo ozungulira akhala masiku asanu opanda madzi ochokera pa mpopi.
mt0: <pad> People in Blantyre and the surrounding areas have been without water for five days.</s>

en: Women, who by Malawi tradition are responsible for household tasks, complain of the risks they face when fetching water from rivers far from residential areas.
nya: Azimayi amene pachikhalidwe amagwira ntchito za mnyumba adandaula pa zomwe akukumanazo pamene akumakatunga madzi ku mitsinje yakutali kuchokera kwawo.
mt0: <pad> Women who traditionally do housework complain about the difficulty they have in carrying water from rivers far from their villages.</s>

en: Rhoda Milanzi, a housewife and mother of three, tells VOA the journeys through bushy footpaths are risky. "We wake up every day 2 a.m., sometimes 1 a.m., to go and collect water. There are so many risks. You see, sometimes we would meet witches, snakes on the way," she says, "even hyenas have been chasing us."
nya: A Rhoda Milanzi mzimayi wa ana atatu yemwe amakhala pakhomo, wauza wailesi ya VOA mmene maulendo odutsa mutchire amakhalira oopsa. "Timadzuka 2 koloko kapena 1 koloko mammawa kukatunga madzi. Pamakhala zoopsa zambiri.. Nthawi zina timakumana ndi afiti, njoka munjira, komanso afisi amatithamangitsa," iwo anatero.
mt0: <pad> Rhoda Milanzi, a three-child mother, has told the VOA how dangerous it is to cross the forest.</s>

en: Milanzi says to ease the burden of carrying water home for bathing, women prefer to bathe in the river. But she says they have been disturbed by youths who hide in the nearby bush.
nya: A Milanzi anati pochepetsa ntchito yosenza madzi osamba kupita nawo kwawo, azimayi amasankha kusamba mu mtsinjewo. Koma anati amasokonezedwa ndi achinyamata omwe amabisala mu tchire lapafupi.
mt0: <pad> Milanzi said that to save money, women choose to bathe in the river. But she said they are discouraged by young men who hide in the nearby bushes.</s>

en: "These youths of today would come there and hide somewhere to see us naked. This has been a major embarrassment. In fact we complained to the chiefs about it.
nya: "Achinyamata amasiku anowa amabwera kubisala  ndikumatisuzumila tili amaliseche. Zimatichititsa manyazi kwambiri ndipo tinakadandaulako kwa amfumu.
mt0: <pad> "The young men of the day came to us and looked at us naked. It was so humiliating that we complained to the kings.</s>

en: They punished some of them, but you know they would sometimes climb trees just to look at older women like us taking a bath," she explains.
nya: Ena  mwa iwo analandira chilango , komabe nthawi zina amakwera mmitengo ndicholinga choonera azimayi akuluakulu ngati ife tikamasamba, iwo anafotokoza.
mt0: <pad> Some of them have been punished, but they sometimes go up the stairs to watch the elderly women if we get away, they explained.</s>

en: The water problem also has affected the delivery of health services.
nya: Vuto la madzili lakhudza kagwiridwe ntchito ka zaumoyo
mt0: <pad> The water problem affects health services.</s>

en: Three weeks ago, authorities at Queen Elizabeth Central Hospital in Blantyre confirmed that they had suspended surgical operations due to water scarcity.
nya: Masabata atatu apitawo akuluakulu a chipatala  cha Queens mu mzinda wa Blantyre anatsimikiza kuti aimitsa kuchita ma opaleshoni kamba ka kusowa kwa madzi.
mt0: <pad> Three weeks ago, Queens Hospital in Blantyre announced that it had stopped operations because of water shortage.</s>

en: Health rights campaigners warn of the possible outbreak of waterborne diseases, especially in densely populated areas, if the situation is left unresolved.
nya: Anthu omenyera ufulu wa zaumoyo achenjeza  anthu zokhudza matenda oyamba ndi madzi opanda ukhondo makamaka mmadera omwe muli anthu ochuluka ngati zinthu sizisintha.
mt0: <pad> Health activists have warned people about the dangers of unsafe water in particular in high-populated areas if things don't change.</s>

en: Officials at the Blantyre Water Board attribute the problem largely to an ongoing European Union-funded project that seeks to install new pumping machines at Walkers Ferry, the main pumping station.  Priscilla Mateyu, the spokesperson for the Blantyre Water Board, says the project is expected to increase water production capacity to 105,000 cubic meters per day from the current daily production of 78,000 cubic meters.
nya: Ogwira ntchito ku Bungwe loona za madzi la Blantyre waterboard ati vutoli likuchokera ku ntchito yoika makina atsopano opopera madzi ku Walkers Ferry  mothandizidwa ndi ndalama zochokera ku European Union. Mneneri wa Blantyre water board anati ntchitoyi ikuyenera kuchulutsa kapangidwe ka madzi kufika pa ma mita a madzi okwana 105,000 patsiku kuchokera pa 78,000 kwapano.
mt0: <pad> The lack of water in Blantyre has been blamed on a new clean-up project at Walkers Ferry.</s>

en: "January is when the project is finishing. But for the new machines and everything else to start working properly, we have to wait until March [2015]. That's when we expect the levels would increase and also production capacity improving to least what we expect it to be," Mateyu said.
nya: Ntchitoyi imalizika mwezi wa Januwale. Pakadali pano kuti makinawa ayambe kugwira ntchito bwinobwino tikuyenera kudikira mwezi wa Malichi (2015). Apa ndipamene tikuyembekeza kuti mlingo wa madzi uchuluka komanso madziwo azipezeka ambiri kusiyana ndi mmene ziliri pano,  iwo anafotokoza.
mt0: <pad> The work will be completed in January. At this point, we expect the machine to start working properly in March 2015. This is when we expect the water level to rise and the water available to be more than what it is now, they said.</s>

en: The local consumer rights watchdog, the Consumers Association of Malawi, had been planning to hold vigils at the water board until the water supply was normalized, but the board asked protesters to hold off, promising to distribute water to residents through mobile water tanks.  The consumer rights group has given the water board two weeks to fulfill its commitment before proceeding with the protests.
nya: Bungwe la Consumers Association of Malawi lomwe limayang'anira anthu ogula zinthu mmisika, lakhala likukonzekera m'bindikiro ku Waterboard pofikila madzi atayambanso kutuluka bwinobwino, koma ogwira ntchito ku Waterboard anawauza anthuwa kuti aime kaye, powalonjeza kuti iwo akhala akupereka madzi mmakomo mwa anthu kudzera mu ma tanki awo. A Bungweli apereka masabata awiri kwa a Waterboard kuti akwanilitse lonjezo lawo asanapitilire ndi zionetsero zawo.
mt0: <pad> The Consumers Association of Malawi, a trade body, had been preparing to stage a protest against Waterboard when water was back in the taps, but Waterboard officials told them to wait until they were able to provide water to the people through their tanks. The Consumers Association of Malawi has given Waterboard two weeks to fulfill their promise before they continue with their protests.</s>

en: Malawi President Under Fire for Giving Money to Journalists
nya: Mtsogoleri wa dziko la Malawi ali pa moto kamba kopereka ndalama kwa atolankhani.
mt0: <pad> President of Malawi is under fire for giving money to journalists.</s>

en: Malawi President Peter Mutharika is under fire for giving envelopes containing $125 to more than 80 media people at a dinner he hosted last month in Blantyre. The editor of the privately owned Times Television said reporters were told the envelopes contained the presidents plans for the media - which has been critical of the governments economic performance.
nya: Mtsogoleri wa dziko la Malawi a Peter Mutharika ali pa moto popereka ndalama zokwa 125 dolazi kwa ogwira ntchito nyumba zofalitsa nkhani okwana makumi asanu ndi atatu pa mgoneri omwe anachititsa mu mzinda wa Blantyre mwezi watha. Wokonza nkhani wa wailesi ya  kanema ya TImes Television anati atolankhaniwo anauzidwa kuti muma envelopuwo  munali ma pulani a mtsogoleriyo okhudza nyumba zofalitsa nkhani zomwe zakhala zikuvutitsa kayendetsedwe cha chuma cha boma.
mt0: <pad> Peter Mutharika has been criticized for giving 125 US dollars to journalists at a press conference in Blantyre last month.</s>

en: In his column published in Malawis Sunday Times newspaper, editor Grecian Tukula said he was not sure why the money was given to journalists at the state dinner.
nya: Mu tsamba lawo lomwe analemba Lamulungu mu nyuzi ya Sunday Times a Gretian Tukula anati iwo sakudziwa chifukwa chenicheni chomwe atolankhani anawapatsira ndalamayo ku mgonero wa bomawo.
mt0: <pad> In their Sunday Times article, the Tukulas said they did not know why journalists gave them money at their funeral.</s>

en: Tukula said he initially decided to return the money but reversed the decision to avoid "creating a scene."
nya: A Tukula anati analingalira zokabweza ndalamayo koma anabweza chiganizo chawo posafuna kuchititsa mpungwepungwe.
mt0: <pad> Tukula said they considered turning down the money but decided not to do so in order not to create a crisis.</s>

en: But the editor for the Weekend Nation newspaper, George Kasakula, told VOA that he returned the money right away.
nya: Koma mlembi wa nyuzipepala ya Weekend Nation  a George Kasakula anauza wailesi ya VOA kuti iwo anabweza ndalamayo nthawi yomweyo.
mt0: <pad> But a spokesman for the Weekend Nation newspaper George Kasakula told the VOA that they refunded the money immediately.</s>

en: "I just felt it was not right for me to receive the money, so I returned it. My understanding is that if someone invites me to a workshop, its their duty to ensure that they feed me, they accommodate me and they transport me. But in this case, I didnt see why I should get that allowance because I didnt spend anything to go to Sanjika [Palace]," said Kasakula.
nya: Ine ndinaona kuti sikunali koyenera kulandira ndalamayo, choncho ndinaibweza. Ine ndimadziwa kuti ndikaitanidwa kogwira ntchito kwina ndi udindo wawo kundidyetsa, kundipatsa malo ogona komanso mayendedwe. Koma ndi mmene zinaliri, sindinaone chifukwa chopatsilidwa ndalama poti sindinagwiritse  ntchito ndalama iliyonse kupita ku Sanjika, anatero a Kasakula.
mt0: <pad> I felt it wasn't fair to take the money, so I refused it. I know that if I am hired somewhere else it is their responsibility to provide me with food, accommodation and transport. But in my case, I didn't see any reason to get the money because I didn't use any money to go to Sanjika, he said.</s>

en: The issue has attracted more public attention after privately owned Capital Radio aired a story questioning the meaning of the cash handouts from the president.
nya: Nkhaniyi yachititsa chidwi chachikulu kwa anthu pamene  wailesi yoima payokha ya Capital Radio inaulutsa nkhani yofunsa tanthauzo la ndalama zinagawidwazi kuchokera kwa mtsogoleri wadzikoyu.
mt0: <pad> The story drew widespread attention when the independent radio station Capital Radio aired a report questioning the meaning of the money distributed by the president of the country.</s>

en: "As Capital FM we serve the interest of the public. This issue has been all over the social media, and even we as a media are implicated [we believe] it is paramount that we follow up and get to the bottom of the matter," said Steven Dakalira, the head of news and current affairs at Capital Radio.
nya: Ife a wailesi ya Capital Radio timagwira ntchito  mokomera dziko. Nkhaniyi ili pa masamba onse ofalitsa nkhani, komanso ife ofalitsa nkhani takhudzidwa nawo, choncho ndikoyenera kutsatira nkhaniyi moyenera, anatero a Steve Dakalira, mkulu wa nkhani ku wailesi ya Capital radio.
mt0: <pad> We at Capital Radio work for the country. This story is on all news channels, and we are affected, so it is important to follow it up," said Steve Dakalira, the head of news at Capital radio.</s>

en: In his column in the Nyasa Times, Malawi professor of law Danwood Mzikenge Chirwa said what President Mutharika did by giving money handouts to journalists at a news event was tantamount to bribery. He has called on Mutharika to resign or face impeachment proceedings.
nya: A Danwood Mzikenge Chirwa mphunzitsi wa zamalamulo; mu tsamba lawo ya nyuzipepala ya Nyasa Times anati zomwe mtsogoleri wa dziko lino a Mutharika  popereka ndalama kwa atolankhani ku msonkhano womwe anachititsa kukufanana ndi mchitidwe wa katangale. Iwo auza a Mutharika kuti atule pansi udindo wawo kapena akonzekere kuchotsedwa pa mpando wawo.
mt0: <pad> Danwood Mzikenge Chirwa, a professor of law; in their online publication the Nyasa Times said that President Peter Mutharika's behavior at his press conference was similar to corruption. He urged Mr. Mutharika to resign or prepare for impeachment.</s>

en: Local civil society groups said that "by attempting to bribe the journalists" Mutharika subjected his leadership style to disrepute.
nya: Magulu a anthu omwe siaboma anati a Mutharika sanaonetse khalidwe labwino pamene amayesera kuchita katangale ndi atolankhaniwo.
mt0: <pad> Non-governmental organizations said President Mugabe did not show good behavior when he attempted to intimidate journalists.</s>

en: Meanwhile, some journalists are donating the money to charity.
nya: Pakadali pano atolankhani ena akupereka ndalamayo ku chithandizo.
mt0: <pad> Some journalists are offering money for treatment.</s>

en: Brian Ligomeka, the Managing Editor for the Times Group, told Times Television that all four employees there have donated the money to an orphanage.
nya: A Brian Ligomeka mkulu wa okonza nkhani ku Times Group, auza kanema ya Times television kuti ogwira ntchito anayi apereka ndalamayo kumalo osungila ana amasiye.
mt0: <pad> Brian Ligomeka, the chief editor of the Times Group, told a television show that four of the company's employees donated the money to an orphanage.</s>

en: "At first we decided to return the money to the president but we later thought it wise to buy assorted items like sugar, salt, notebooks and donate it to needy children," said Ligomeka.
nya: "Poyambilira tinali ndi maganizo obwenza ndalamayo kwa mtsogoleri wathu koma tinaganiza mwanzeru kugula zinthu zosiyanasiyana ngati Shuga, mchere, makope ndi kukapereka kwa ana ovutika," anatero a Ligomeka.
mt0: <pad> "We initially thought to return the money to our leader but we decided to buy various things like sugar, salt, rice and distribute it to the children," said Ligomeka.</s>

en: In his latest Sunday Times column, Raphael Tenthani, who also writes for BBC, apologized on behalf of other journalists "for letting down the public that trust journalists unreservedly."
nya: Mu tsamba lomwe amalemba lamulungu lilironse a Ralph Tenthani amene amalemberanso nyumba yofalitsa nkhani yaikulu ya BBC, anapepesa mmalo mwa atolankhani ena pokhumudzwitsa anthu amene amakhulupilira atolankhani ndi mtima wonse.
mt0: <pad> In his weekly column on Sunday, Ralph Tennant, a journalist for the BBC, apologised in his name for offending people who trust journalists with all their heart.</s>

en: Tenthani has since donated the money for charity work and said that although the journalists could have done better if they returned the money right away, doing so would have been perceived as disrespect to the head of state.
nya: A Tenthani adapereka ndalamayo ku chithandizo ndipo anati  ngakhale atolankhaniwo anakachita bwino kukabwenza ndalamayo nthawi yomweyo, kutero kunakoneka ngati kusalemekeza mtsogoleri wadziko.
mt0: <pad> Tenthani donated the money to charity and said that although the journalists could have done better to return the money immediately, doing so would have been unrespectful of the president.</s>

en: Maclan Kanyangwa, who heads the Department of Journalism and Media Studies at the Polytechnic College of the University of Malawi, said a media code of ethics bars journalists from accepting payment on a story.
nya: A Maclan kanyangwa mkulu wa chigawo cha atolankhani ndi maphunziro a zofalitsa nkhani ku sukulu ya ukachenjede ya Polytechnic anati malamulo  a utolankhani amawaletsa kulandira ndalama pa nkhani iliyonse.
mt0: <pad> A Maclan kanyangwa, head of the department of journalism and media education at Polytechnic University of Technology said that journalistic ethics prohibit them from accepting any payment for any article.</s>

en: "Obviously the meeting at the palace was the newsworthy event. There was a possibility that something was going to be published. And in the event that this payment would have influenced journalist decision [on news judgment], then that becomes a problem," said Kanyangwa.
nya: "Mwachidziwikire msonkhanowu unali nkhani yaikulu yoyenera kudziwika kwa anthu. Panali kuthekera koti nkhaniyi ilembedwa mu masamba. Inakakhala kuti ndalamayi yasintha maganizo a atolankhani mu kaweluzidwe kawo ka nkhani, linakakhala vuto .' anatero  a Kanyangwa.
mt0: <pad> "Obviously the meeting was a big news story. There was a possibility that it would be covered in the press. If the money changed the perception of journalists about the story, it would be a problem," said Kanyangwa.</s>

en: Kanyangwa said he feels many journalists failed to return the money immediately because they might have been out of their ethical senses when they got the money.
nya: A Kanyangwa anati akuona ngati atolankhani ambiri sanabweze ndalamayo chifukwa sanaganizire bwinobwino pamene alalandira.
mt0: <pad> Kanyangwa said he believes most journalists did not return the money because they did not think it over before receiving it.</s>

en: Efforts to talk to Presidential Press Officer Fredrick Ndala were not successful. But some government authorities say the payment was not a bribe but meant for a fuel refund to those who attended the night event.
nya: Njira zonse zomwe tinayesa kulankhula ndi  mneneri wa mtsogoleri wa dziko a Fredrick Ndala sizinatheke. Koma akuluakulu ena a  boma anati ndalamayi siinali yakatangale koma inali yowabwezera ya mafuta a galimoto kwa anthu amene anabwera ku mwambowo.
mt0: <pad> All our attempts to speak with the president's spokesman Fredrick Ndala were unsuccessful.</s>

en: Report: Manufacturing Could Free Poorest Nations From Poverty
nya: Lipoti: Maiko osaukitsitsa atha kuthetsa unphwawi pozipangila zipangizo pawokha mu mafakitale.
mt0: <pad> Report: Poor countries can end poverty by producing materials for themselves in the industry</s>

en: A new United Nations report urges the poorest countries in the world to shift from low- to high-productivity activities to improve their economies.
nya: Lipoti latsopano la Bungwe la United Nations lalimbikitsa maiko osaukitsitsa kuti asunthe kapangidwe kawo ka zinthu kufika patali ndicholinga chosintha chuma cha maiko awo.
mt0: <pad> A new UN report urges low-income countries to radically change their production patterns in order to transform the economic state of their countries.</s>

en: In its annual Least Developed Countries Report, UNCTAD — the U.N. Conference on Trade and Development — says these countries must structurally transform their economies to free themselves from the "poverty trap," which is stunting economic growth and development.
nya: Mu lipoti la pa chaka lokhudza maiko osatukuka, a UNCTAD, ku msonkhano wa za ndalama ndi chitukuko anati maiko osaukawa akuyenera kudzimasula okha mu ngodya ya umphawi , yomwe ikuchedwetsa chitukuko ndi kusintha kwa chuma chawo.
mt0: <pad> In its annual report on underdeveloped countries, the UN Conference on Economic and Development said that the poor countries should free themselves from the cycle of poverty, which is slowing development and economic transformation.</s>

en: Of the 48 nations the U.N. considers "Least Developed Countries" (LDCs), only one, Laos, is on track to achieve all seven of the Millennium Development Goals (MDG's) by 2015.
nya: Pa maiko 48 amene bungwe la UN limati ndi osatukuka, dziko limodzi lokha  la Laos ndilimene likupita kokwanitsa zinthu zisanu ndi ziwiri zomwe likufuna pa njira yotchedwa Millenium development goals mu pofika chaka cha 2015.
mt0: <pad> From the 48 UN-defined developing countries, Laos is the only one that is progressing towards achieving all eight of its Millennium development goals by 2015.</s>

en: Only four African countries — Ethiopia, Malawi, Rwanda and Uganda — are likely to meet a majority of these targets.
nya: Maiko anayi okha mu Afilika, Ethiopia, Malawi, Rwanda ndi Uganda  ndi amene atha kukwanitsa zolinga zawo.
mt0: <pad> Four African countries, Ethiopia, Malawi, Rwanda and Uganda, are the only four in Africa that can achieve their goals.</s>

en: This assessment is particularly grim in light of the even greater challenges awaiting these countries in the coming years. The MDGs set a goal for nations to halve their poverty levels by 2015. The so-called Sustainable Development Goals, which carry on from where the MDGs leave off, call for eradication of poverty by 2030.
nya: Ntchito yomwe maikowa anapatsidwa itha kukanika  chifukwa cha mavuto akuluakulu amene maikowa angakumane nawo zaka zikubwerazi. A MDGs anaika malire kwa maiko osaukawa kuti achepetse umphawi ndi theka pofika chaka cha 2015. zomwe maikowa akufuna atafikira kuchokera pomwe a MDGs anasiyira zitha kuthetsa umphawi pofika chaka cha 2030.
mt0: <pad> The work assigned to the poor countries may be difficult because of the great difficulties they will face in the future. The MDGs set a target for the poor countries to reduce poverty by half by 2015. The goals they want to achieve from the MDGs' remaining targets may end poverty by 2030.</s>

en: According to Taffere Tesfachew, an UNCTAD official who works with African nations, it would be nothing short of a miracle for the LDCs to pull this off.
nya: A Taffere Tesfachew a bungwe la UNCTAD lomwe limagwira ntchito ndi maiko a ku Afilika anati zidzatengera chozizwa kuti mabungwe a LDCs adzathe kuchita izi.
mt0: <pad> Taffere Tesfachew of the UN UNCTAD African Program said it will take time for LDCs to achieve this.</s>

en: In order for the least developed countries to achieve this miraculous performance, he says they will need to structurally change their economies.
nya: Kuti maiko osatukukawa adzafikire pamenepa, akuyenera kusintha kagwiritsidwe ntchito ka chuma chawo.
mt0: <pad> To achieve this, developing countries must change the way they use their resources.</s>

en: He tells VOA this means shifting labor from activities with low productivity, such as small-scale agriculture and services to more dynamic activities with higher productivity, such as manufacturing and high-value services.
nya: Iwowa anauza wailesi ya VOA kuti izi zikutanthauza kuti kapangidwe ka zinthu komanso ulimi ukuyenera kusuntha kuchoka pa zokolora zochepa kufika ku zambiri, komanso anati akuyenera kupanga zinthu zobweretsa phindu lalikulu.
mt0: <pad> Iwoa told the VOA that this means that production and agriculture must move from small-scale to large-scale, and he said that they must produce products that bring greater profits.</s>

en: "Countries that have moved up are the ones that are creating opportunities for those that are leaving agriculture to engage in things where they add value, where they get training and as it happens, manufacturing tends to have that sort of feature, that is why this call for manufacturing," he said. "Countries that are using policies to shift and influence capital and labor to move into this activity sector tend to do better."
nya: "Maiko amene zinthu zawo zasintha ndi amene akupereka mwayi kwa anthu amene anasiya ulimi kuti akachite zinthu zina zoonjezera phindu, komwenso angachite maphunziro ake,  iwo anatero," "Maiko amene amagwiritsa ntchito mfundo izi polimbikitsa ntchito yopanga zinthu okha amachita bwino."
mt0: <pad> "Mothers who have changed are those who provide opportunities for people who left the farm to pursue other higher-paying jobs, and to continue their education," they said. "Mothers who use these principles to encourage self-employment do well."</s>

en: Tesfachew says these high-productivity sectors tend to pay higher wages and create a demand for goods. This, he says, encourages investment.
nya: A Tesfachew anati  zigawo zopanga katundu wochuluka malipiro ake amakhala ambiri komanso amabweretsa msika wa katunduyo. Iwo anati izi zimalimbikitsa  kuikako ndalama.
mt0: <pad> Tesfachew said that areas of high-volume production pay more and bring in market. He said this encourages investment.</s>

en: On the surface, it appears that the LDCs are not doing badly. UNCTAD economic data show growth in these poor countries between 2002 and 2008 exceeded the seven percent target set by the international community. And, even after the 2008 financial crisis, UNCTAD notes the LDCs grew faster than other developing countries, at an average of 5.7 percent per year.
nya: Zikuonetsa kuti a maiko a LDCs sakulephera kwambiri. Malipoti a ndalama a  bungwe la UNCTAD anaonetsa kusintha kwa maiko osaukawa pakati pa chaka cha 2002 ndi 2008 komwe anapitiliza mulingo wa 7 pelesenti omwe iwo amayenera kufikira. Ngahale papatatha vuto la ndalama la mu chaka cha 2008, bungwe la UNCTAD linaona kuti maiko osaukawa anachita bwino msanga kusiyana ndi maiko amene akutukuka ndi 5.7 pelesenti chaka chilichonse.
mt0: <pad> It shows that LDCs are not really failing. The UN CTAD financial report showed that the poor countries had continued to achieve the 7 percent target they were supposed to achieve.
