Even after the 2008 economic crisis, the UN CTAD found that the poor countries had done better than the developing countries with 5.7 percent growth every year.</s>

en: But U.N. economists say the outlook for the least developed countries in the short and medium term remains uncertain. They say increasing peoples productivity is the best way to break the patter of human and economic underdevelopment that continues to entrap them in poverty.
nya: Olondoloza ndalama a bungwe la U.N anati  maiko osatukukawa tsogolo lawo silikuoneka kwenikweni mu nthawi yochepa kapena yapakatikati. Iwo anati  kuchulutsa mlingo wa zinthu zopangidwa ndi anthu ndi njira imodzi yothetsera kusatukuka komwe kudakawaika mu umphwawi.
mt0: <pad> UN financial watchdogs said that the future of developing countries is not clear at all in the short or medium term. They said that boosting production was one way to solve the problems that led to poverty.</s>

en: UN: Most African Nations to Miss 2015 MDG Goals
nya: UN: Maiko ambiri a ku Afilika alephera kufikira zolinga za chitukuko zotchedwa MDG za chaka cha 2015.
mt0: <pad> UN: Many African countries have failed to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) of 2015.</s>

en: Most African countries will not reach the Millennium Development Goals set for 2015 because of the gap between economic and human development. That is one of the conclusions in this years annual U.N. report on the Least Developed Countries, presented Thursday.
nya: Maiko ambiri amu Afilika safikira zolinga zawo za chitukuko kufikira chaka cha 2015 chifukwa chakusiyana komwe kulipo pakati pa ndalama ndi chitukuko cha anthu. Izi zinali chimodzi cha mathero a kukambilana mu lipoti lokhudza maiko osatukuka  la bungwe la U.N lomwe linapelekedwa Lachinayi.
mt0: <pad> Many African countries will not achieve their development goals by 2015 because of the gap between economic and human development. This was one of the main points of discussion in the UN's report on under-developed countries released on Thursday.</s>

en: Junior Davis, U.N. economic affairs officer for Africa, said African countries have not been able to translate their economic growth into structural transformation.
nya: A Junior Davis amene amayan'ganira nkhani zokhudza ndalama mu Afilika kuchokera ku bungwe lla U.N, anati maiko a ku Afilika sanakwanitse  kusintha makulidwe a chuma chawo kupita ku kachitidwe ka mphamvu kopindulitsa.
mt0: <pad> Junior Davis, a UN expert on African finance, said that African countries have not been able to transform their economic structure into a profitable energy system.</s>

en: "We think that is the case because these countries have not focused efficiently on building what we call their productive capacities," Davis said. "These are the basic human and economic development capacities that are needed to promote sustainable economic development. And the MDG, as they were constructed, largely ignored the need to develop the productive capacities."
nya: Tikuona  ngati izi zili choncho chifukwa maikowa salimbikira kumanga kapena kuchita malonda ndi zinthu zomwe zingawabweretsere  phindu lochuluka, anatero a Davis.  Izi ndi zinthu zomwe zingabweretse  chitukuko cha chuma chokhazikika. Mmene malamulo  a MDGs anakonzedwera, kwakukulu amanyalanyaza kufunika kosintha zinthu zowabweletsera phindu.
mt0: <pad> We think this is because they don't invest in or trade in high-profit products, Davis said. These are things that can bring about sustainable economic development. When the MDGs were proposed, they largely ignored the need to change the productive cycle.</s>

en: Slow progress
nya: Kupita patsogolo pang'onopang'ono.
mt0: <pad> moving forward slowly</s>

en: African countries also are not on course to halve poverty by 2015, and their overall progress on reducing hunger is relatively slow. Poverty limits human development and undermines productivity. And economic development is needed to make gains in human development.
nya: Maiko a mu Afilika Sali panjira yochepetsa umphawi ndi theka pofika chaka cha 2015, ndipo kupita pa tsogolo kwawo pochepetsa njala ndi kochedwa kwambiri. Umphawi umachepetsa chitukuko komanso uumapeputsa kachitidwe ka zinthu. Chitukuko cha zachuma chimayenera kupindula mu chitukuko cha anthu.
mt0: <pad> Africa is not on the path to halving poverty by 2015, and progress in ending famine is very slow. Poverty decreases development and impedes social reform. Economic development should benefit people's development.</s>

en: Ethiopia, Rwanda, Uganda and Malawi are the only African countries on track to reach the majority of the development goals. They are making progress because they heavily invested in areas that create sustainable development such as infrastructure, health and education.
nya: Maiko a Ethiopia, Malawi ndi Rwanda ndi amene ali mu njira yokwanitsa njira za chitukukozi. Iwowa akupita patsogolo chifukwa adayika ndalama mu zitukuko zokhazikika monga, zomangamanga, zaumoyo ndi maphunziro.
mt0: <pad> Ethiopia, Malawi and Rwanda are the countries that are in the process of achieving these development objectives. They are progressing because they have invested in sustainable development such as, infrastructure, health and education.</s>

en: The post-2015 development agenda for fragile countries where governance remains an issue — such as South Sudan and the Democratic Republic of Congo — will still largely depend on support from the international community to achieve social and economic development, Davis said.
nya: Ndondomeko ya chitukuko ya chaka cha 2015 yokhudza maiko amene ulamuliro udakali nkhani yovuta, monga dziko la South Sudan ndi Democratic Republic of Congo, kwakukulu azidalirabe thandizo lochokera ku gulu la dziko lonse kuti  afikire chitukuko cha anthu ndi chuma, anatero a Davis. ndalama ndi chikhalidwe, anatero a Davis.
mt0: <pad> The 2015 development plan for countries where governance is still a challenge, such as South Sudan and the Democratic Republic of Congo, will largely depend on international support to achieve people and economic development, said Davis.</s>

en: Improvements in rural development, industrial productivity, agriculture and the services sectors in these countries will require "ways in which we can have a pattern of growth which is not just sustainable but jobs-rich," Davis said. "Because we see the growth in jobs and employment is central to any development strategy that aims to reduce poverty in a sustainable way."
nya: Kusintha chitukuko cha mmidzi, zokolola za makampani, ulimi ndi malo a ntchito mu maiko amenewa, payenera kukhala ndondomeko ya kukula kokhazikika komanso ntchito zolemera," anatero a Davis. "Chifukwa tikuona kuti pali kuchuluka kwa ntchito komanso kalembedwe ka ntchito komwe kwa khazikika pa njira yachitukuko iliyonse yochepetsera umphawi mokhazikika.
mt0: <pad> "To change rural development, agricultural production, industry and jobs in these countries, there must be a process of stable growth and heavy work," said Davis. "Because we see that there is a large amount of work and a fixed pattern of work in any development path to permanently reduce poverty," he added.</s>

en: A country is placed on the Least Developed Countries list based on its per capita income, economic vulnerability, and human development indicators such as health and nutrition.
nya: Dziko  limaikidwa pa ndandanda wa maiko osatukuka limatengera ndalama zabomalo, kusatetezeka kwa chuma komanso chitukuko cha anthu kudzera mu zaumoyo ndi zakudya.
mt0: <pad> The country is classified as a low-income country by the amount of money it has, economic instability and human development through health and food.</s>

en: Of the 48 least developed countries in the world, 34 are in Africa. Three countries have graduated from their least developed status: Botswana, Cape Verde and Samoa.
nya: Pa Maiko 43 osatukuka pa dziko lonse, 34 ali mu Afilika. Maiko amene asuntha pa mlingo wosatukuka ndi Botswana, Cape Verde ndi Samoa.
mt0: <pad> From the 43 least developed countries in the world, 34 are in Africa. The three countries that have moved up to developing are Botswana, Cape Verde and Samoa.</s>

en: Strike Paralyzes Malawi's Judicial Services
nya: Kunyanyala ntchito ku ma ofesi oweruza milandu a ku Malawi kwaimitsa ntchito yawo.
mt0: <pad> The strike by the Malawian prosecutors offices has halted their work.</s>

en: A week-long strike by the support staff of Malawi's judiciary system has paralyzed the courts, causing overcrowding in police cells and the indefinite suspension of major cases - including government corruption trials. Court marshals, clerks and messengers are demanding the 30 percent salary increases promised by the government two years ago.
nya: Kunyanyala ntchito kwa sabata imodzi kwa anthu othandizira ntchito ku nthambi yoweruza milandu ya ku Malawi kwaimitsa ntchito za ma khoti, izi zachititsa kuchulukana mu malo amene amasungilamo anthu a kuba ku polisi komanso kuyimitsa milandu ikuluikulu monga ya katangale wa boma. Ma Marshal a khoti, ma kalaliki ndi ma mesinjala akufuna malipiro awo atakwezedwa kufika pa 30 pelesenti monga mmene boma linawalonjezera zaka ziwiri zapitazo.
mt0: <pad> The strike by court officers, marshal and clerks has caused a shortage of policemen in the custody of prisons and has delayed major criminal cases such as graft.</s>

en: Chanting and singing around the court premises has become a pastime activity for the striking court workers since the onset of a sit-in last week.  Linley Hebert, a spokesperson for the striking workers, told VOA the strike is a result of the governments failure to honor a 2012 agreement.
nya: Kuimba mozungulira malo a khotilo kwakhala chizolowezi cha anthu onyanyala ntchitowo kuchokera sabata yatha. A Linley Herbert, woyankhulira anthu onyanyala ntchitowa wauza wailesi ya VOA kuti kunyanyala ntchitoku ndi kamba ka kulephera kukwaniritsa lonjezo lomwe boma linapereka mu mgwirizano wawo chaka cha 2012.
mt0: <pad> The strike has been going on for the past week.</s>

en: "In October [this year], the government reviewed the salaries of the civil servants, but we were not included in that revision," Hebert said.
nya: Mu mwezi wa Okotobala chaka chino, boma linakonzaso malipiro a anthu ogwira ntchito mb'oma, koma ife sitinaikidwe nawo mgululi," anatero a Herbert.
mt0: <pad> In October this year, the government raised the pay of public servants, but we were not included in that increase," said Mr. Herbert.</s>

en: "Yet in 2012, we had an agreement that each time they are revising the salaries of the civil servants, [they will be increasing our salaries as well].
nya: "Pamene chaka cha 2012 tinagwirizana  nawo kuti pamene akukonza malipiro a ogwira ntchito, azionjezeranso malipiro athu.
mt0: <pad> "In 2012 we agreed with them that when they restructured the wages of their employees, they would also add to ours."</s>

en: So, [after adhering to the agreement in 2013], we are surprised to see that this time we are left out."  Government authorities say the failure to increase judicial workers salaries this year is largely because of financial constraints, following a donor aid freeze against Malawi's government.
nya: Patatha mgwirizano wathu mu chaka cha 2013 tikudabwa kuti ulendo uno sanatiikepo." akuluakulu aboma anati kulephera kukweza malipiro kwa ogwira ntchito mu ofesi yoweruza milandu ndichifukwa cha mavuto a zachuma, kuchokera ku kusiya kulandira chithandizo kwa dziko la Malawi kuchokera kwa othandiza.
mt0: <pad> After our agreement in 2013, we are surprised that this time they did not include us."</s>

en: The freeze is a result of a government financial scandal in which more than $30 million was looted from government coffers.  Ministry of Finance spokesperson Nations Msowoya told a local radio station it is hard for the government to meet the workers' demand.
nya: Kuimitsa kulandira thandizoku ndi chifukwa cha ndalama zoposa 30 miliyoni zomwe zinabedwa ndiogwira ntchito m'boma. Mneneri wa unduna wa za chuma a Nations Msowoya anauza wailesi ina kuti ndizovuta kuti dziko lifikire zofuna za ogwira ntchitowa.
mt0: <pad> The suspension of the payments is due to theft of over 30 million dollars by government employees.</s>

en: "It is difficult to promise what the treasury will do. But suffice to say that the prevailing economic circumstances and budgetary constraints will make a little bit difficult for the treasury to bow down to the demands," "Msowoya said.
nya: "Ndizovuta kulonjeza zomwe asungi chuma angachite. Koma titha kunena kuti ndimmene nyengo yachuma iliri ndi zopinga za bajeti, zikhala zovutirapo kuchita monga mmene iwo akufunira," anatero a Msowoya.
mt0: <pad> "It's hard to promise what the IMF will do. But we can say that with the current economic situation and budgetary difficulties, it's going to be hard for them to do what they want," Msowoya said.</s>

en: But according to Hebert, the strikers will not resume work until their demands are met.  "Since I was born [there has been] no time the government said it had some money.
nya: A Herbert anati athu onyanyala ntchitowo  sayambiranso  kugwira ntchito pokhapokha atalandira zofuna zawo. " Chibadwileni changa palibe nthawi yomwe a boma ananena kuti ali ndi ndalama.
mt0: <pad> Herbert said the striking workers would not return to work until they were satisfied with their demands. "In my lifetime, the government has never said they have money," he said.</s>

en: It has its own means [of finding the money] and it will find the same means to give us the money," Hebert insisted.  The ongoing strike is hampering progress of trials, as court operations remain suspended.
nya: Boma liri ndi njira zake zopezera ndalama ndipo lipeza njira zomwezo kutipatsa ife ndalama," ananenetsa a Herbert. Kunyanyala ntchitoku kukusokoneza kuzenga milandu pamene ntchito za khoti zaimitsidwa.
mt0: <pad> The government has its own ways of making money and it will find the same ways to provide us with money," he said. The strike is hampering prosecutions as court services are suspended.</s>

en: Several trials, including that of former justice minister Ralph Kasambara, who is answering charges in connection with the financial scandal, were indefinitely suspended last week.
nya: Milandu yambiri kuphatikizapo wa nduna yakale za za chilungamo a Ralph Kasambara, amane akuyankha mlandu polumikizana ndi kuba ndalamaku inaimitsidwa sabata latha.
mt0: <pad> Many cases, including that of former minister of justice Ralph Kasambara, who is answering charges of money laundering were suspended last week.</s>

en: Police are complaining of congestion in jail cells, as no suspects are being taken to court.
nya: Apolisi akudandaula kuchulukana kwa anthu mu ndende  pamene anthu owakaikira ndi milandu sakutengedwa ku khoti.
mt0: <pad> Police are complaining about a lack of justice in jails when accused people are not brought to court.</s>

en: Malawi police spokesperson Rhoda Manjolo told VOA the only option they have is "giving police bail to those with minor offenses."   Human rights campaigners and legal experts say the strike is contributing to human rights violations.
nya: Mneneri wa polisi  a Rhoda Manjolo anauza wailesi ya VOA kuti kuti njira yokhayo yomwe alinayo ndi  kuwatulutsa kaye  anthu amene ali ndi zolakwa zazing'ono. Anthu omenyera ufulu ndi malamulo akuti kunyanyala ntchitoku kukuphwanya malamulo a ufulu wa anthu.
mt0: <pad> The police spokesman Rhoda Manjolo told the VOA that the only way they can do is to release people with minor offenses.</s>

en: "There are those people who have to be taken to court within 48 hours," noted Lawyer George Kadzipatike who works in a private practice in the northern city of Mzuzu. "We cannot make application for them to be granted bail.
nya: "Pali anthu ena amene akuyenera kukaonekera ku khoti maola 48 asanathe," anatero oyimira milandu a George Kadzipatike amene amagwira ntchito pawokha ku mpoto kwa mzinda wa Mzuzu. "Sitingawalembele kuti iwo atulutsidwe kaye.
mt0: <pad> "There are some people who have to appear in court 48 hours before the end," said George Kadzipatike, an independent barrister in north Mzuzu. "We can't ask them to be released until they show up."</s>

en: There are those people who do not want to live with their partners, they would like the court to decree that they be divorced, we cannot file any petition through the courts."
nya: Pali anthu ena amene sakufuna kukhala limodzi ndi okondedwa awo, akufuna khoti litawasudzula, sitingakwanitse kupempha kudzera ku khoti."
mt0: <pad> Some people don't want to live with their loved ones, they want a divorce, we can't ask through the court.</s>

en: Government authorities say closed door negotiations to resolve the matter continue in the capital, Lilongwe.  But the striking workers told VOA whatever the case, they will accept nothing short of a 30 percent increase in their salaries.
nya: Akuluakulu a boma anati akuchita zokambirana mu mzinda wa Lilongwe kuti alongosole nkhaniyi. Koma onyanyala ntchitoyi awuza wailesi ya VOA kuti iwo savomera kukwezedwa  malipiro ochepera 30%.
mt0: <pad> Officials said they were in discussions in Lilongwe to rectify the situation. But the striking teachers told the VOA that they will not accept a pay rise of less than 30%.</s>

en: A similar strike lasted three months in 2012 after the magistrates and judges joined the labor action.
nya: Kunyanyala ntchito ngati komweku kunatenga  miyezi itatu  mu chaka cha 2012 pamene oweruza milandu anachita nawo.
mt0: <pad> The same strike lasted for three months in 2012 when they were prosecuted by the prosecutors.</s>

en: Famine in Southern Africa Worse Than Predicted - 2002-07-24
nya: Chilala ku mmwera kwa Afilika chiipiraipira kusiyana ndi mmene zinanenedwela- 2002-07-24
mt0: <pad> The southern African famine is worse than predicted - 2002</s>

en: The United Nations World Food Program says the famine in southern Africa is even worse than predicted. WFP officials are warning that 13 million people in six countries: Malawi, Zambia, Lesotho, Zimbabwe, Swaziland and Mozambique are in danger of starvation if they do not get food aid.
nya: Mgwirizano wa dziko lonse wokhudza chakudya ( United Nations World Food Program) wati chilala ku mmwera  kwa Afilika chaipiraipira kusiyana ndi mmene amaganizira. Akuluakulu a bungwe la WFP achenjeza  kuti anthu okwana 13 million mmaiko a Malawi, Zambia, Lesotho, Swazilandi ndi Mozambique  ali pa chiopsezo ngati salandira thandizo la chakudya.
mt0: <pad> The United Nations World Food Program (WFP) has warned that the famine in southern Africa is worse than previously thought.</s>

en: World Food Program officials say they need one million tons of food to alleviate hunger in southern Africa, but they are not confident they will get it. In an appeal to the international community at the beginning of July, WFP officials asked for more than $0.5 billion to buy food. So far they have received only 20 percent of that. WFP's director for the southern Africa region, Judith Lewis, says the situation is getting desperate. "The window of opportunity to avert what could be a major humanitarian crisis is closing," she said. "We need more assistance now. We need food on the high seas now, or we need cash to buy commodities that are still available in southern Africa, so we can avert this major, major crisis."
nya: Akuluakulu a World Food program ati akufunika  ma tani 1 million a chakudya kuti achepetse njala ku mmwera kwa Afilika, koma iwo alibe chikhulupiliro kwenikweni kuti atha kuchipeza. Pempho lomwe anapempha ku gulu lapadziko lonse lapansi kumayambiliro kwa mwezi wa Julayi, akuluakulu a  WFP anapempha ndalama zopitilira 0.5 biliyoni zogulira chakudya. Koma pakadali pano iwo alandira gawo la 20 pelesenti la ndalamayo. Wotsogolera gulu la WFP ku mmwera kwa Afilika a Judith Lewis, anati vutoli likupita kuwasowetsa chiyembekezo. "Mwayi omwe unapezeka  othetsera  vuto lalikululi ukutsekedwa," iwo anatero. "Tikufuna chithandizo chochuluka tsopano. Tikufuna chakudya chochuluka kapena ndalama zoti tigulire katundu yemwe adakapezeka kummwera kwa Afilika kuti tichepetse vuto lalikululi.
mt0: <pad> World Food Program officials say they need to buy more than one million tons of food to tackle the severe famine in southern Africa, but they are not sure they will be able to get it.</s>

en: Currently, the WFP is assisting six million of the most vulnerable people in the six most severely affected countries. About half of these people are in Zimbabwe. The agency says it is sure the number of people needing its help will rise.
nya: Pakadali pano bungwe la WFP likuthandiza anthu amene ali pa chiopsezo okwana 6 miliyoni ku maiko omwe akhudzidwa kwambiri. Theka la anthuwa ndi ochokera ku dziko la Zimbabwe. Nthambiyi inati ali ndi chikhulupiliro kuti chiwerengero cha anthuwa chikula.
mt0: <pad> At present the World Food Program is supporting 6 million people in the most affected countries. A quarter of these people come from Zimbabwe. The official hopes that the number of people will increase.</s>

en: The World Health Organization notes southern Africa, in addition to having the highest prevalence of HIV/AIDS in the world, also has the world's highest chronic malnutrition rates. It predicts about 300,000 people could die over the next six months from diseases related to malnutrition.
nya: Bungwe loona zaumoyo dziko lonse lapansi la World Health Organisation lati maiko a  kummwera kwa Afilika  poonjezerapo kukhala ndi anthu ochuluka a matenda a Edzi padziko lonse, lilinso ndi chiwelengelo chochuluka cha anthu osoya zakudya  mthupi. iwo anati anthu 300,000 atha kufa ndi matenda osowa chakudyawa pa miyezi isanu ndi umodzi ikubwerayi.
mt0: <pad> The World Health Organization says that south Africa, in addition to having the highest number of Ebola patients in the world, has also the highest percentage of malnutrition. They predict that 300,000 people may die from malnutrition in the next six months.</s>

en: Ms. Lewis says the dying has already begun. "We are seeing people moving from their villages," she said. "If they know there is going to be a food distribution, they immediately go there. The problem is we do not even have enough food to feed the people who are on the rolls, let alone add food for other people in the areas. Is there a potential to become chaotic? Yes. "
nya: Mai Lewis anati anthu ayamba kale kufa. "anthu akumasamuka mmidzi mwawo, kupita ku malo omwe amvetsedwa kuti kuli chakudya. Vuto ndilakuti tilibe chakudya chokwanira choti tingawadyetse anthu omwe ali pa ndandandawa komanso omwe ali mmadera ena. Kodi pali kuthekera koti zitha kubweretsa chipwirikiti ? eya."
mt0: <pad> Ms. Lewis said people have already begun to die. "People are fleeing their villages, going to places where they heard about food. The problem is that we don't have enough food to feed those on the list and those in other areas. Is there a possibility that it can lead to a crisis? yes.</s>

en: WFP'S Judith Lewis says at this time of year the agency is usually planning how to get food supplies into the region before the rainy season hits in October. But she says since the WFP is already having difficulty meeting its present targets, it can't even begin to plan for future food deliveries.
nya: A Judith Lewiis a bungwe la WFP anati nthawi ngati ino mu chaka chilichonse nthambiyi imakhala ikukonzekera mmene ingapezere chakudya cha maderawa nyengo yamvula isanayambe mu  mwezi wa Okotobala. Koma iwo anati poti bungwe la WFP likupeza kale mavuto kukwaniritsa  mmene amafunira, sangayambe kukonzekera ndondomeko ina yopereka zakudya mttsogolomu.
mt0: <pad> Judith Lewiis of the World Food Program said that although they are preparing for the next season of rainfall, they cannot begin to plan for another food aid program.</s>

en: Canadian PM Impressed With African Development Plan - 2002-04-05
nya: Nduna yaikulu ya dziko la Canada yasangalatsidwa ndi ndondomeko ya chitukuko cha mu Afilika-2002-04-05
mt0: <pad> Canada's Deputy Prime Minister is pleased with the African Development Program 2002-2004.</s>

en: Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien says he is impressed with the progress being made towards implementing an African development plan.
nya: Nduna yaikulu ya ku Canada a Jean Chretien anati iwo ndi okhutitsidwa ndi kupita patsogolo komwe kukuchitika pokafikila ndondomeko ya chitukukoyi mu  Afilika.
mt0: <pad> Canada's Chief of the Cabinet Jean Chretien said they were pleased with the progress made in achieving the development agenda in Africa.</s>

en: Mr. Chretien made the remarks Sunday after meeting with South African President Thabo Mbeki and other regional leaders in Pretoria.
nya: A Mr. Chretien anaperenga ndemangayi Lamulungu atatha kukumana ndi mtsogoleri Wa dziko la South Africa, a Thabo Mbeki ndi atsogoleri ena a mmadera ku Pretoria.
mt0: <pad> Mr. Chretien read the statement on Sunday after meeting with South African President Thabo Mbeki and other regional leaders in Pretoria.</s>

en: Mr. Chretien, the current chairman of the group of the seven most industrialized nations plus Russia, is visiting Africa to discuss the New Partnership for Africa's Development, known as NEPAD.
nya: Mkulu wa gulu la maiko asanu ndi awiri omwe ali ndi mafakitale ochuluka kuonjezelapo dziko la Russia , a Mr. Chiretien akuyendera ku Afilika kuti akambilane mgwirizano wotukula dera la Afilika wotchedwa NEPAD.
mt0: <pad> The chief of the eight industrialized countries plus Russia, Mr. Chiretien is in Africa to discuss the NEPAD development agreement.</s>

en: He said NEPAD will be one of the top agendas at the June G-8 summit in Kananaskis, Canada.
nya: Iwo anati NEPAD idzakhala imodzi mwa zokambirana za msonkhano wa atsogoleri a maiko mwezi wa juni wotchedwa G-8 summit ku Kananaskis mu  dziko la Canada.
mt0: <pad> They said NEPAD will be one of the main topics at the G-8 summit in June in Kananaskis, Canada.</s>

en: The G-8 nations are Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United States and Russia.
nya: Maiko omwe ali mu gulu la G-8 ndi Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, United States ndi Russia.
mt0: <pad> The countries of the G-8 are Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, United States and Russia.</s>

en: Mr. Chretien says topics such as human rights, democracy the rule of law, transparency and good governance will be discussed at the G8 summit.
nya: a Mr. Chretien anati mitu yokambilana ngati ufulu wa anthu, ufulu olamulila wa demokalase, chilungamo ndi ulamuliro wabwino zikakambidwa ku msonkhano wa atsogoleri a G-8 wo.
mt0: <pad> Mr. Chretien said that topics of discussion such as human rights, democratic rule, justice and good governance will be discussed at the G-8 leaders' meeting.</s>

en: NEPAD outlines objectives of promoting democracy and good governance in Africa in return for Western economic assistance. It seeks to achieve an annual growth rate of seven-percent on the African continent by 2015.
nya: NEPAD inapereka zolinga zopititsa patsogolo demokalase ndi ulamuliro wabwino mu Afilika kuti iwo apeze chithandizo cha ndalama chochokera ku maiko a azungu. Iwo akuyembekeza kufikira kukula kwa pa chaka kokwana 7 pelesenti mu dera la Afilika pofika chaka cha 2015.
mt0: <pad> NEPAD aims to improve democracy and good governance in Africa to get European aid. They expect to achieve a 7 percent annual growth in the African region by 2015.</s>

en: South African President Mbeki said he is convinced that Africa is ready for NEPAD saying there has been definite progress toward democracy in the continent.
nya: Mtsogoleri wa dziko la South Africa a Thabo Mbeki anati ndiwokhutitsidwa kuti Afilika yakonzekera bungwe la NEPAD ndipo anati pali kupita patsogolo ndi demokalase mu derali.
mt0: <pad> South African President Thabo Mbeki said he was pleased that Africa had prepared for NEPAD and said there was progress in democracy in the region.</s>

en: Later, Mr. Chretien and Mr. Mbeki were joined by presidents Festus Mogae of Botswana, Bakili Muluzu of Malawi, Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique, Sam Nujoma of Namibia, Benjamin Makapa of Tanzania and Vice President Enoch Kavindele of Zambia.
nya: A mr. Chretien ndi a Mbeki anakumana ndi atsogoleri a maiko  monga a Festus Mogae a ku Botswana, Bakili Muluzi a ku Malawi, Joaquim Chissano a ku Mozambique, Sam Nujoma a ku Nambibia, Benjamin Makapa a ku Tanzania ndi wachiwiri kwa mtsogoleri a Enoch Kavindele a ku Zambia.
mt0: <pad> Mr. Chretien and Mbeki met with Botswana's Festus Mogae, Malawi's Bakili Muluzi, Mozambique's Joaquim Chissano, Namibia's Sam Nujoma, Tanzania's Benjamin Makapa and Zambia's deputy president Enoch Kavindele.</s>

en: Zimbabwe's President Robert Mugabe, who won re-election in disputed voting last month, was not invited.
nya: Mtsogoleri wa dziko la Zimbabwe a Robert Mugabe amene anawinanso masankho otsutsana mu dziko lawo, sanaitanidwe ku msonkhanowu.
mt0: <pad> Robert Mugabe, the Zimbabwean leader who won a disputed election in his country, was not invited to the meeting.</s>

en: Reuters news agency reports the Canadian prime minister who has already visited Morocco, Algeria and Nigeria on his six-nation tour will visit Ethiopia and Senegal after South Africa.
nya: Bungwe lolemba nkhani lotchedwa Reuters News Agency lati nduna yaikulu ya dziko la Canada yayendera kale dziko la Morocco, Algeria ndi Nigeria pa ulendo wawo woyendera maiko asanu ndi limodzi. Iwo ayenderanso dziko la Ethiopia ndi Senegal akachoka ku South Africa.
mt0: <pad> The Canadian Prime Minister has already visited Morocco, Algeria and Nigeria on his eight-nation tour. He also visited Ethiopia and Senegal after leaving South Africa.</s>

en: Some information for this report provided by Reuters and AFP.
nya: Nkhani zina mu lipotili anapereka ndi  Reuters ndi a AFP.
mt0: <pad> Other news reports were provided by Reuters and AFP.</s>

en: Child Labor in Malawi - 2002-02-28
nya: Kugwiritsa ntchito ana ku Malawi-2002-02-28
mt0: <pad> Child labour in Malawi-2002-02</s>

en: The organization, Eye of the Child, is expressing concern about what is says is a large number of children who are being forced to work due to poverty.
nya: Bungwe lotchedwa Eye of the Child, laonetsa kukhudziwa ndi chiwelengero chochuluka cha ana amene akukakamizidwa kugwira ntchito chifukwa cha umphawi.
mt0: <pad> Eye of the Child has expressed concern about the growing number of children who are forced to work for poor living conditions.</s>

en: It says these children risk being abused.
nya: iwo anati ana amenewa amakhala pa chiopsezo chozunzidwa.
mt0: <pad> They said these children were at risk of abuse.</s>

en: Some under aged children work as mini – bus call boys in the busy business district of Limbe in the commercial capital, Blantyre. They are some of the many children who have been forced into employment because of poverty.
nya: Ana ena achichepere amagwira ntchito yoitanila ma minibasi ku boma la malonda la Limbe mu mzinda wa Blantyre.  Pali ana ena ambiri omwe amakakamizidwa kukagwira ntcito chifukwa cha umphawi.
mt0: <pad> Some children work as mini-bus drivers in the Limbe commercial district in Blantyre. There are many other children who are forced to work because of poverty.</s>

en: Maxwell Matewere is the executive director of Eye of the Child. He says many of the children come from rural areas. He says, "Currently we havent done a data analysis but the Ministry of Labor intends to do that as soon as possible with financial resources from the International Labor Organization.
nya: A maxwell Matewere ndi mkulu woyang'anira bungwe la Eye of the Child. Iwo anati  ana ambiri amachokera kumamidzi. Iwo anati , "pakadali pano sitinapange kaundula koma a  unduna wa zantchito akukonzekera kutero ndi ndalama zochokera  ku bungwe lapadziko lonse ,loona za ntchito.
mt0: <pad> Maxwell Matewere is the director of Eye of the Child. He said most of the children were from rural areas. He said, "For now we haven't been formally registerd but the ministry of work is preparing to do so with funding from the World Labour Organization."</s>

en: But basing on our own assessment and through our works, we feel child labor is a serious problem particularly in the rural areas and you can tell that from trafficking of children from rural areas to urban areas where most of the young people are working in peoples houses.
nya: Kuchokera ku ntchito ndi kafukufuku wathu, tikuona kuti kugwiritsa ntchito ana ndi vuto lalikulu makamaka madera a mmidzi, ndipo mutha kuona kuti kutenga ana opanda chilolezo kuchokera ku mmidzi kupita ku tawuni komwe achinyamata ambiri akugwira ntchito mu nyumba za anthu.
mt0: <pad> From our work and research, we see that child labor is a major problem especially in rural areas, and you can see that the unauthorized taking of children from rural areas to urban areas where many young people are working in private homes.</s>

en: " Mr. Matewere says poor children often find work on large farm estates.
nya: A Matewere anati ana osauka kawirikawiri amapeza ntchito ku minda ikuluikulu yochitira ulimi.
mt0: <pad> Matewere said that children from the poor often find jobs in large farms.</s>

en: He said, "We have noticed that there are some indications that there are children who are working in tea estates and tobacco estates.
nya: Iwo anati, "Tazindikira kuti pali ana ena omwe akugwira ntchito ku minda ikuluikulu yolima Tiyi ndi Fodya.
mt0: <pad> They said, "We have discovered that some children are working in the large tea and tobacco plantations.</s>

en: There also are children who are working in brick making mostly their parents will facilitate for them to work in those kinds of employment. "
nya: Palinso ana ena  amene akumagwira ncthito youmba njerwa makamaka kuchokera kwa makolo awo amene akumawalimbikitsa kugwira ntchito zotero.
mt0: <pad> There are also some children who work in construction, especially from their parents who encourage them to do such work.</s>

en: Mr. Matewere says the Eye of the Child has established that there are gross violations of children rights in the country. These include, rape, defilement and being overworked.
nya: A Mr. Matewere anati bungwe la Eye of the Child lazindikira kuti pali kuphwanya ufulu wa ana kwakukulu mdziko muno. Monga kugwililira, kuipitsa koma kugwiritsa ntchito mopyola muyeso.
mt0: <pad> Mr. Matewere said the Eye of the Child has identified serious violations of children's rights in the country. Such as rape, harassment and excessive use.</s>

en: He says this violates the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.
nya: Iwo anati uku ndi kuphwanya malamulo okhudza ana a bungwe ladziko lonse la United Nations.
mt0: <pad> They said that this violated the UN Child Poverty Law.</s>

en: "If you look at the Convention of the Rights of a Child," he said, "you will see that it provides for the protection for children from any kind of exploitation from any kind of harmful activities or act which threatens their health, their development which is a threat to education.
nya: "Mukaona malamulo okhudza ana," iwo anati, " muona kuti limapereka malamulo oteteza ana ku zoipa zilizonse zoika pa chiopsezo moyo wao,kakulidwe kawo kamene kangasokoneze maphunziro awo.
mt0: <pad> "When you look at the Child Protective Act," they said, "you will see that it provides a law to protect children from any harm that puts their life, development or education at risk.</s>

en: So children who are found working in tea estates, who are found in brick making, obvious, their rights as it is provided for in the Convention for the Rights of the Children as well as in the constitution are violated. "
nya: Choncho ana amene amapezeka akugwira ntchito mminda yaikulu yolima Tiyi, oumba njerwa, mwachidziwikire kuchokera mu malamulo a ufulu wa ana ufulu wawo ukuphwanyidwa.
mt0: <pad> But the children who are found working in the tea plantations, stone blocks, obviously from the childhood rights laws their rights are violated.</s>

en: The Eye of the Child executive director says his organization is looking at ways of protecting the rights of a child.
nya: Mkulu woyang'anira bungwe la The Eye of the Child ati bungwe lawo likufufuza njira zotetezera ufula wa ana.
mt0: <pad> The Eye of the Child and their organization are investigating ways to protect children's graves.</s>

en: He says to achieve this, the group has started a number of programs. "We have recently started a new program and what we are trying to do is to inform the general public on the best interests of the child and to inform them on the rights of a child.
nya: Iwo anati kuti akwanitse zimenezi, gululo layambitsa ma pologalamu angapo. "Tayambitsa pologalamu yatsopano ndipo chomwe tikufuna kuchita ndi kudziwitsa dziko zinthu zomwe zingathandize moyo wa mwana komanso ufulu wa mwana.
mt0: <pad> They said that to achieve this, the group has launched several programs. "We have launched a new program and what we want to do is inform the world about things that can affect the life and the rights of children."</s>

en: At the same we want also to build up the capacity of the children themselves so that may be they can be use their authentic voice out their concerns. "
nya: Komanso tikufuna tibweretse kuthekera  mwa anawa kuti azitha kufotokoza nkhawa zawo.
mt0: <pad> We also want to increase the ability of children to express their concerns.</s>

en: According to the Ministry of Labor authorities, many children are forced to leave school and find work because parents cannot afford school fees.
nya: Kuchokera kwa akuluakulu a ku unduna wa za ntchito, ana ambiri amakakamizidwa kusiya sukulu ndi kukapeza ntchito chifukwa makolo awo sangakwanitse kuwalipilira ndalama yokaphunziliira.
mt0: <pad> From the Ministry of Labor, many children are forced to quit school and find a job because their parents can't afford to pay for their education.</s>

en: Although primary school is free in Malawi, most children do not attend due to lack of necessities like clothes.
nya: Ngakhale sukulu za pulaimale zili zaulele ku Malawi, ana ambiri samapita chifukwa chosowa zinthu ngati zovala.
mt0: <pad> Although primary school is free in Malawi, many children don't go to school because of the lack of things like clothing.</s>

en: Over 60 per cent of Malawis nearly 11 million people live below the poverty line.
nya: A Malawi okwana 11 million opitilira mlingo wa 60 pelesenti amakhala moyo osauka.
mt0: <pad> Malawian people are poor.</s>

en: Malawi Court Convicts 12 People in Albino Attack
nya: Khoti la boma la Malawi lazenga athu khumi ndi awiri okhudzidwa ndi imfa ya munthu wakhungu lachi alubino.
mt0: <pad> The Malawian government court has charged 12 people with the murder of an albino.</s>

en: A high court in Malawi has convicted five people of murder for the 2018 killing of a 22-year-old albino man, including the victims brother.
nya: Khoti lalikulu mu dziko la Malawi lamnga athu asanu kamba kokupha mnyamata wa zaka 22 mu chaka cha 2018 kuphatikizapo mchimwene wake.
mt0: <pad> The Malawian High Court has convicted five people of murdering a 22-year-old man in 2018 including his brother.</s>

en: The court convicted seven other people of selling the victim's body parts.
nya: Khotilo linamangaso anthu asanu ndi anayi pogulitsa ziwalo za thupi la malemuyi.
mt0: <pad> The court also charged nine people with selling the body parts of the man.</s>

en: Malawi officials say more than 170 albinos have been attacked in the country since 2014 by people who believe their body parts bring luck and wealth.
nya: Akuluakulu a boma la Malawi ati anthu a chi alubino opitilira 170 anagwidwa kuyambira chaka cha 2014, pokhulupilira kuti ziwalo zawo zimabweretsa mwayi ndi chuma.
mt0: <pad> Malawian officials and over 170 albino people have been arrested since 2014, believing that their skin brings them opportunities and money.</s>

en: Family members of the deceased, MacDonald Masambuka, left the courtroom Thursday with hopes of justice being served after the court convicted all 12 people accused in his death.  F
nya: Abale awo a malemuyi a MacDonald Masambuka, anachoka mu khoti lachinayi ndi chiyembekezo choti chilungamo chipelekedwa, khoti litamanga anthu onse khumi ndi awiri omwe akuimbidwa mlandu wokhudza imfayi.
mt0: <pad> The brothers of the late MacDonald Masambuka left court on Thursday with hope that justice will be done, after the court arrested all twelve people accused of involvement in the death.</s>

en: amily members, including Masambukas mother, appeared calm and composed as Judge Dorothy NyaKaunda Kamanga read the judgments.
nya: Achibalewo, kuphatikizapo mayi ake a Masambuka, anali odekha pamene oweluza milandu a Dorothy Nyakaunda amawerenga zigamulo.
mt0: <pad> The family, including his mother Masambuka, was quiet as the prosecutor Dorothy Nyakaunda read the answers.</s>

en: Those convicted included a Catholic priest, Father Thomas Muhosa, police officer Chikondi Chileka, clinician Lumbani Kamanga, and the deceaseds brother, Cassim Masambuka. Charges included murder, extracting human tissues, causing harm to a person with disability, and trafficking in persons.
nya: Anthu amene aweruzidwa ndi wansembe wachikatolika a Thomas Muhosa, wapolisi a Chikondi Chileka,  a dokotala a Lumbani Kamanga ndi mchimwene wa malemuyo a Cassim Masambuka. Iwo anagamulidwa ku milandu ya kupha, kuchotsa ziwalo za anthu, kuvulaza thupi la munthu olumala ndi kugulitsa anthu.
mt0: <pad> The four people convicted were a priest, a policeman, a doctor and the brother of the victim. They were convicted of murder, excision, mutilation, abuse of the body of a disabled person and human trafficking.</s>

en: Kamanga convicted the victims brother and four others of murder.
nya: A Kamanga anaweluza mlandu wakupha mchimwene wa malemuwo ndi anthu ena anayi.
mt0: <pad> The judge convicted Kamanga of murdering the brother of the elderly man and four other people.</s>

en: The court convicted seven other people, including the priest and police officer, of selling the victim's body parts.
nya: Khotili linaweruzanso anthu ena asanu ndi awiri, kuphatikizapo ansembe ndi wapolisiyo pogulitsa ziwalo za munthuyo.
mt0: <pad> The court also convicted nine other people, including the priest and the policeman, of selling the body parts of the man.</s>

en: Business with tissue  According to the court, Muhosha, Chileka and others offered to conduct business using human tissue extracted from a human corpse.
nya: Malonda a minofu ya anthu kuchokera ku khoti, a Muhosha, a Chileka ndi ena anadzipeleka kuchita malonda a mnofu wa thupi la munthu wakufa.
mt0: <pad> According to the court, Muhosha, Chileka and others offered to sell human flesh.</s>

en: The judge said the state proved beyond reasonable doubt the 12 people conspired to kill Masambuka to extract his bones based on a perception they would benefit financially.
nya: Oweruza mlanduwu anati boma linatsimikiza mosakaikira kuti anthu khumi ndi awiri  anapha a Masambuka kuti achotse mafupa awo poona ngati zithandizira chuma chawo.
mt0: <pad> The judge said the government has proven without doubt that 12 people killed the Masambuka to remove their bones to see if they could help their wealth.</s>

en: She said Masambuka is the latest victim of violent attacks on persons with albinism who have not been protected by the community.
nya: Iwo anati a Masambuka ndi mmodzi mwa anthu a chi Alubino  omwe achitidwa chiwembu posachedwapa koma sanatetezedwe ndi dera lawo.
mt0: <pad> They said the Masambuka was one of the Alubino people who were recently attacked but were not protected by their community.</s>

en: Director of Public Prosecutions Steve Kayuni represented the state in the case. He said he was pleased the court agreed on all the seven charges he presented.
nya: Mkulu wozenga milandu a Steve kayuni ndi omwe anayimila boma pa  mlanduwu. Iwo anati anali okondwa kuti a khoti anavomeleza chigamulo chomwe anapereka chokwana zisanu ndi ziwiri.
mt0: <pad> Steve Kayuni, the state prosecutor, said he was pleased that the court approved his eight-point conviction.</s>

en: "Its really something overwhelming on the part of the state considering that this matter, if you notice, there is a police officer involved, a priest involved and there is a brother involved.
nya: "Ndi nkhani yokhudza kwambiri ku mbali ya dziko poona kuti pali wapolisi, wansembe komanso mchimwene wa malemuyu amene akukhudzidwa pa nkhaniyi.
mt0: <pad> "This is a very important matter in the country as there are a policeman, a priest and the brother of the woman involved in this case."</s>

en: If you notice, it all revolves around the position of trust — that somebody like the late Macdonald Masambuka trusted so much, they are the ones who ended up betraying him," Kayuni said.
nya: Mukhoza kuona kuti nkhaniyi ikuthera pa nkhani yokhuupilirana. Kuti annthu amene a MacDonald amawakhulupilira kwambiri ndi amene anawapereka ndi kuwachita chipongwe," anaetero a Kayuni.
mt0: <pad> You can see that this case ends on a matter of trust. That the people who McDonald trusted most are the ones who gave them up and abused them," said Kayuni.</s>

en: Masambuka went missing from his village on March 9, 2018, and his limbless body was found buried in a garden on April 2, 2018, in his home district of Machinga south of Malawi.
nya: A masambuka anasowa mmudzi mwawo pa 9 Malichi mwezi wa 2018, ndipo thupi lawo lopanda manja ndi miyendo linapezeka atalikwilira mu dimba pa 2 epulo mwezi wa 2018 kumudzi kwawo ku Machinga, ku mmwera kwa dziko la malawi.
mt0: <pad> The elderly Msambuka went missing from his village on March 9, 2018, and his body was found unconscious in a house on April 2, 2018 in his village in Machinga, south of Malawi.</s>

en: Enticement  Court documents show that Masambuka was enticed by his brother to meet his friends, who he claimed had found a girl for him to marry.
nya: Mapepala a ku khoti anaonetsa kuti a Masambuka anayengeleredwa ndi mchimwene wawo kuti akakumana ndi anzake amene amati amupezera mkazi woti iye akwatire.
mt0: <pad> Court documents showed that the Masambukas were asked by their brother to meet with his friends who he said could find him a woman to marry.</s>

en: But when they reached the scene, the alleged friends grabbed Masambuka by the neck and dragged him to a garden where they killed him. Here, his assailants cut off his limbs, burned his body using petrol and buried it there.
nya: Koma atafika pa malopo, anzake amanenawo anawagwira pakhosi a masambuka ndikuwakokera ku dimba komwe anakawapha.  Pamenepo achiwembuwo anadula manja ndi miyendo yawo, kuwotcha thupi lawo ndi petulo ndikulikwilira pomwepo.
mt0: <pad> But when they arrived, their four friends were captured by the north guards and brought them to the garden where they were killed. Then the attackers cut off their hands and legs, burned their body with fire and buried them there.</s>

en: This was the first such case involving high-profile community members involved in attacks on persons with albinism.
nya: Uwu unali mlandu woyamba okhudza anthu apamwamba a mu dera omwe anachita nawo chiwembu munthu wa chi Alubino
mt0: <pad> This was the first trial of local officials who participated in the murder of an Alubino.</s>

en: Masauko Chamkakala, the lawyer for the 12 defendants in the case, said he would comment once he had gone through the judgment.
nya: A Masauko Chamkakala, woimila mlandu anthu ozengedwa mlanduwu anati iwo aikilapo ndemanga akawerenga bwinobwino chigamulocho.
mt0: <pad> Masauko Chamkakala, the lawyer for the accused, said they will comment on the verdict after reading it carefully.</s>

en: "We are still waiting to see the perfected judgment so that we can read it and study it and talk to our clients," Chamkakala said.
nya: "Tidakadikilabe chigamulo choyenera cha mlanduwu kuti  tiwerenge bwinobwino kenako tiyankhule ndi makasitomala athu," anatero a Chamkaka.
mt0: <pad> "We're still waiting for the full verdict to read it and talk to our customers," said Mr. Brown.</s>

en: Rights activists said they expected the court to give stiffer punishment to those convicted.
nya: Anthu omenyela ufulu anati iwo amayembekezera khoti kuti lipereke chilango cholimba kwa anthu anamangidwawa.
mt0: <pad> Rights activists said they expect the court to give a strong punishment to the arrested.</s>

en: 'Serious sentencing'
nya: Chilango chachikulu.'
mt0: <pad> The greatest mistake.</s>

en: Ian Simbota represented the Association of Persons with Albinism at the court.
nya: A Ian Simbota ndi omwe anayimila mgwirizano wa anthu a chi Alubino ku khotilo.
mt0: <pad> Ian Simbota is the lawyer who represented the Albino community in court.</s>

en: "When the judge was reading, what concerned me was that part of a [Priest] Father Muhosha [and others] who have been convicted of transacting body parts.
nya: "Pamene oweruza mlandu amawerenga, pomwe panandikhudza ndi pamene ansembe a Muhosha ndi ena amaweruzidwa chifukwa chogulitsa ziwalo za anthu.
mt0: <pad> "When the judge read, the part that touched me most was when the priests Muhosha and others were convicted of human organ trafficking.</s>

en: If you go to the Anatomy Act, it is not so hard on such offenses.
nya: Mukapita ku malamulo a zochotsa ziwalo za matupi a anthu,  sizovuta kwambiri pa nkhani zolakwa ngati zimenezi.
mt0: <pad> When it comes to the law on human organ transplantation, it is not very difficult to deal with such crimes.</s>

en: So, we are really looking forward to the judge, if at all its possible, to put a human face to the case so that at least we really need to see serious sentencing on this case," Simbota said.
nya: Tikuyang'anira oweruza mlandu kuti ngati kuli kotheka nkhaniyi aione kufunikira kwake kuti pakhale chilango chachikulu," anatero a Simbota.
mt0: <pad> We are looking for the judge to see if there is a need for a maximum punishment," Simbota said.</s>

en: The high court is expected to sentence the perpetrators on May 30.
nya: Khoti lalikulu likuyembekezeka kupereka chilango kwa anthu ochita zoipawa pa 30 mwezi wa Meyi.
mt0: <pad> The Supreme Court is expected to condemn the criminals on May 30.</s>

en: In another case, a high court on Thursday sentenced a 37-year-old man to life in prison for the 2020 murder of a 14-year-old-boy with albinism in Phalombe district.
nya: A Khoti lalikulu agamulanso mlandu wina lachinayi pamene mzibambo wina wa zaka 37 anapha mnyamata wa chi Alubino wa zaka 14 ku Phalombe. Mzibamboyi akakhala ku ndende moyo wake onse.
mt0: <pad> The High Court in Phalombe has also convicted a 37-year-old man of murdering an Alubino boy aged 14. The man will be jailed for life.</s>

en: Zimbabwe Official Defends Crackdown on Protests, Urges Patience with Economy
nya: Akuluakulu a boma la zimbabwe aziikila kumbuyo polanga anthu ophwanya malamulo  pa zionetsero, alimbikitsa kudekha ndi ndondomeko ya chuma.
mt0: <pad> Zimbabwean officials have backed the crackdown on protesters, urging self-rule and economic reforms.</s>

en: Zimbabwe's minister of foreign affairs and international trade on Monday defended crackdowns on anti-government demonstrations and urged patience in turning around the country's foundering economy.
nya: Nduna yoona nkhani zakunja ndi malonda a padziko lonse lolemba laziikila  kumbuyo polanga anthu ophwanya malamulo ku zionetsero zotsutsana  ndi boma ndipo linauza anthuwo kuti adekhe pamene akusintha kayendetsedwe katsopano ka chuma.
mt0: <pad> The minister of foreign and international trade on Monday backed the protesters who broke the law in the recent anti-government protests and told them to wait while they change the current economic policy.</s>

en: Though "everybody's got the right to demonstrate," there have "been a lot of insinuations and campaigns of violence," Sibusiso B. Moyo told VOA in an interview. Citing public safety, he endorsed a Zimbabwe court's ruling hours earlier to uphold a police ban on a protest organized by the opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) alliance.
nya: Ngakhale aliyense ali ndi ufulu wochita zionetsero, " pakhala malingaliro oipa ochuluka  komanso kulimbikitsa mchitidwe wa nkhanza," a Sibusiso B. Moyo anauza waielsi ya VOA pamene amafunsidwa mafunso. Poitanitsa chitetezo cha dziko, iwo anavomera nthawi yogamula milandi ku khoti la ku ZImbabwe msanga kuti akalimbikitse kuletsa komwe apolisi akuchita pa zionetsero zomwe a chipani chotsutsa boma cha MDC akonza.
mt0: <pad> Although everyone has the right to protest, "there are many bad ideas and inciting violence," Sibusiso B. Moyo said in an interview with the VOA.</s>

en: Alliance leaders are pressing President Emmerson Mnangagwa and the ruling ZANU-PF party for a role in a transitional government. They had organized a demonstration Monday in Bulawayo, the country's second-largest city, but police authorities banned it hours before its intended start. Two other opposition demonstrations still are planned this week: for the central city of Gweru on Tuesday and the southeastern city of Masvingo on Wednesday.
nya: Akuluakulu a mgwirizano wa zipani akukakamiza mtsogoleri Emmerson Mnangagwa ndi chipani cholamula cha ZANU-PF kuti achitepo kanthu posinntha boma. Anakonsa zionetsero lolemba ku mzinda wachiwiri wa dzikolo ku Bulawayo, koma apolisi analetsa patatsala maola ochepa kuti zionetselozi ziyambe. Zionetsero zina zakonzedwa sabata yamawa, ku mzinda wa pakati wa Gweru lLachiwiri komanso kummwera chakummawa kwa mzinda wa Masvingo Lachitatu.
mt0: <pad> The opposition coalition is pressuring the president and the ruling party to step down.</s>

en: Police also had pre-emptively banned a demonstration in Harare last Friday, a decision upheld by a Zimbabwe court. Hundreds of MDC supporters ignored the ban, leading to clashes between civilians and police. Video and photographs showed police hitting and kicking some demonstrators among actions that drew complaints of excessive force from civil and human rights groups, including the United Nations human rights office.
nya: Apolisi anali ataletselatu zionetsero zina zomwe zimayenera kuchitika Lachisanu lapitali ku Harare, chiganizo chomwe analetsa ndi a khoti la Zimbabwe. Otsatira chipani cha MDC ochuluka sanalabadile za kuletsedwako zomwe zinachititsa chisokonezo pakati pa anthu ndi Apolisi. Makanema ndi zithunzi zinaonetsa Apolisiwo akumenya anthu ochita zionetselo zomwe zinabweretsa madandaulo kuchoka ku mabungwe oona za ufulu wa anthu, kuphatikizapo ofesi ya dziko lonse lapansi ya United Nations.
mt0: <pad> Police had already banned other protests in Harare on Friday, a decision that was overturned by the court.</s>

en: Police, not demonstrators, showed up in force on Bulawayo streets Monday, with foot patrols wielding shields, batons and, in some cases, pistols. The Associated Press reported police trucks and water cannons positioned in the downtown area.
nya: Apolisi ambiri osati anthu ochita zionetsero adawonekera mwamphamvu mmisewu ya ku Bulawayo Lolemba, iwo anali kuyendayenda mmisewumo atavala zishango za kumaso, atanyamula zikwapu, ndi mfuti. Atolankhani anati Apolisiwo anabwera ndi magalimoto awo ndi mizinga ya madzi yomwe anaisiya mtawunimo.
mt0: <pad> Many policemen, not protesters, were seen in the streets of Bulawayo on Monday, wearing face masks, carrying shields and guns.</s>

en: A young man in Bulawayo, identifying himself only as James, told VOA that negotiations between the government and opposition leaders were even more important than demonstrations.
nya: Wachinyamata wina yemwe anadzitchula dzina lake kuti ndi James mu dera la Bulawayo, anauza wailesi ya VOA kuti zokambirana pakati pa boma ndi atsogoleri otsutsa ndizofunika kwambiri kuposa zionetsero.
mt0: <pad> A young man named James in Bulawayo told the VOA that talks between the government and the opposition leaders were more important than protests.</s>

en: "Honestly, to demonstrate, we can end up being hurt by being beaten, being chased around. There's really nothing that we see coming out of it," James said. "But these men should sit down and see what they can do for us, especially us, the youth. … We have been affected a lot, and we are getting old just running."
nya: "Kunena chilungamo, kuchita zionetsero titha kuvulala pomenyedwa ndi kuthamangitsidwa. Palibe chomwe ife tikuona kuti chitha kutulukapo," anatero James. "Koma anthuwa akuyenera kukhala pansi ndikuona chomwe angatichitire, makama ifeyo achinyamata. Takhudzidwa kwambiri ndipo tikukula ndikumangothamanga.
mt0: <pad> "To tell the truth, protesting can be dangerous. There is nothing we see that will come out of it," James said. "But they need to sit down and see what they can do to us, especially us young people. We have been so affected and we're growing up and running around and running."</s>

en: Moyo, the foreign minister, told VOA the administration is "undertaking economic reforms [that] are fundamental and they are key to ensuring that even the youth would finally have jobs created for them, so that we can create an environment where investors and the capital will find it easy to come into this country, where jobs will be created, and the youth will be part and parcel of economic activity."
nya: Nduna yoona zakunja a Moyo anauza wailesi ya VOA kuti iwo akupanga njira zofunika zosinthira chuma zomwe akutsimikiza kuti ngakhale achinyamata adzawapezera ntchito kuti ndalama ndi anthu obweretsa ndalamazo asamavutike kubwera mu dziko lino lomwe ntchito zizipangidwa ndipo achinyamata adzakhala mbali ya chuma chi.
mt0: <pad> The foreign minister told the VOA that they are making important economic reforms that will ensure that young people will be employed so that money and investors can come to this country and create jobs and the young people will be part of this economy.</s>

en: Moyo said Zimbabwe is midway into a two-year "transition stabilization program" to revive the country's devastated economy: "We have got one year to go and we are saying we should by then be out of the doldrums."
nya: A Moyo anati dziko la Zimbabwe liri pakati pa pologalamu ya zaka ziwiri yokhazikitsa dzikolo kuti abwezeretse chuma chawo chomwe chinawonongeka. "Tili ndi chaka chimodzi, ndipo tikuti tidzakala titatuluka mu nyengo yowawitsayi."
mt0: <pad> The Zimbabwean President said the country was in the middle of a two-year reconstruction plan to recover from the economic losses.</s>

en: The southern African country of nearly 16 million is experiencing its worst financial crisis since 2008, beset by hyperinflation and the fallout of decades of corruption. Many struggle to buy basics such as food and medicine. With the poor economy and crops devastated by drought and a spring cyclone, the UN World Food Program anticipates that 5.5 million people will need emergency food aid by next April.
nya: Kum'mwera kwa Afilika anthu pafupifupi 16 miliyoni akukumana ndi mavuto a zachuma ochuluka kuyambira chaka cha 2008, kuvutika ndi kukwera kwambiri kwa mitengo ya zinthu komanso katangale wa zakazaka. Ambiri amavutika kugula  zinthu zofunikira ngati chakudya ndi mankhwala. Ndi kusoweratu chuma komanso mbewu zoonongeka ndi chilala ndi mphempo yamphamvu, a UN World Food Program akuyembekeza kuti anthu okwana 5.5 million adzafunika chithandizo chadzidzidzi cha chakudya mwezi wa Epulo.
mt0: <pad> Since 2008, nearly 16 million people in South Africa have been experiencing severe economic difficulties, suffering from the high cost of living and corruption. Many are struggling to buy essentials like food and medicine. UN World Food Program estimates that 5.5 million people will need emergency food treatment by April.</s>

en: Finance Minister Mthuli Ncube, who had predicted 3.1% growth for 2019, offered a sobering update to Zimbabwe's parliament in early August. "The revised 2019 GDP growth is expected to be negative," Reuters news service reported him as saying.
nya: Nduna yoona za chuma a Mthuli Ncube amene ananeneratu za kukula kokwana 3.1 pelesenti pamene amapereka lipoti ku nyumba ya aphungu ya ku Zimbabwe mwezi wa Ogasiti. "Kaundula wa 2019 wa kakulidwe ka chuma akuyenera kufika mlingo wochepera," atolankhani a Reuters ndi amene anapeleka lipotili.
mt0: <pad> The Zimbabwean minister of finance Mthuli Ncube predicted a 3.1 percent economic growth in 2019 when he presented his report to the House of Commons in August. "The 2019 economic growth rate should be at least 3.1 percent," Reuters reported.</s>

en: Ncube did not provide any updated figure.
nya: A Ncube sanapeleke nambala iliyonse yatsopano.
mt0: <pad> Ncube did not provide any new numbers.</s>

en: Civil Society Workers Run Afoul of Tanzania Security Officials in Sign of Increasing Clampdown
nya: Anthu osagwira ntchito m'boma, atsutsana ndi akuluakulu a chitetezo m'boma la Tanzania poletsa machitidwe a zinthu.
mt0: <pad> Freelancers have been clashing with Tanzanian security officials for blocking traffic.</s>

en: African civil society campaigners attending a conference in Tanzania were questioned and warned over the weekend, in what human rights activists say is part of a continuing clampdown on free speech in the East African nation.
nya: Anthu a mu Afilika osagwira ntchito m'boma omwe akukumana nawo pa msonkhano ku Tanzania anafunsidwa komanso kuchenjezedwa mathero a sabatayi,mu zimene omenyera ufulu wa anthu amati ndi njira imodzi yoletsera ufulu wa malankhulidwe mu dera la East Africa.
mt0: <pad> African non-governmental workers who were attending the meeting in Tanzania this weekend were questioned and warned, in what human rights activists say is one way to restrict free speech in East Africa.</s>

en: Details are still emerging over what exactly happened to at least 40 civil society workers who ran afoul of security officials at this year's summit of the Southern African Development Community in Dar es Salaam.
nya: Zambiri zikutulukirabe pa zomwe zinachitika kwa anthu makumi anayi osagwila ntchito m'boma amene anali pa mkangano ndi akuluakulu a chitetezo pa msonkhano waukulu wotukula maiko a kummwera kwa Africa  wotchedwa Southern African Development Community ku Dar es Salaam.
mt0: <pad> More is emerging about the fate of the 40 government workers who were in clashes with security officials at the Southern African Development Community Conference in Dar es Salaam.</s>

en: But rights experts said Monday that the episode is another worrying sign of heightened paranoia and harassment from the government.
nya: Koma akatswiri a za ufulu Lolemba anati gawo ili ndi  chizindikiro china chodandaulitsa pa kuchuluka kosowa chikhulupiliro ndi nkhanza kuchokera ku boma.
mt0: <pad> But rights experts on Tuesday said the move is another alarming sign of the government's lack of trust and violence.</s>

en: Catherine Eden, a lawyer for the Tanzania Human Rights Defenders Coalition, says the incident stemmed from a misunderstanding. South African delegates to the 15-nation conference, she said, wanted to hold a short commemoration of the seventh anniversary of South Africa's deadly Marikana mine massacre on Aug. 16. Thirty-four striking miners were killed by police in the deadliest security incident since the end of apartheid in 1994.
nya: A Catherine Eden, woimila milandu ku bungwe la Tanzania Human Rights Coalition, anati zomwe zinachitikazo zinayambira pa kusamvetsetsana. Nthumwi khumi ndi zisanu zochokera ku dziko la South Africa, iwo anati, zinafuna kuchita chikumbutso patatha zaka zisanu ndi ziwiri pa anthu ambiri omwe anaphedwa ku mgodi wa ku Marikana pa 16 mwezi wa Ogasiti. Okumba migodi makumi atatu ndi anayi omwe ankachita zionetsero anaphedwa ndi apolisi, mu kuphedwa kochuluka chitheleni ulamuliro wa tsankho mu chaka cha 1994.
mt0: <pad> Catherine Eden, a lawyer for the Tanzanian Human Rights Coalition, said the incidents were a result of misunderstanding.</s>

en: So delegates at a side event sang the South African anthem, held a moment of silence and availed on their government to better protect its people. But something they wrote on a piece of paper convinced security police the delegates had bigger plans.
nya: Nthumwi pa zochitika zina zinayimba nyimbo ya fuko la dziko la South  Africa, anakhala ndi mphindi ya chete ndipo anauza boma lawo kuti likuyenera kuteteza anthu awo. Koma chinthu china chomwe analemba pa pepala chinatsimikizila a polisi a chitetezo kuti nthumwizo zinali ndi zolinga zina zazikulu.
mt0: <pad> Some protesters sang the national anthem of South Africa, held a minute of silence and told their government to protect their people. But something else on a paper assured security police that the protesters had other larger objectives.</s>

en: "They wrote some messages on the flip charts, of which the little content that was captured in the flip charts read, 'Stop killing our people,'" she said. "... So I think there was a national security person in that meeting and he saw those messages and so he interpreted that as a plan to demonstrate. But if you look closely, you can't see any relationship as to why they would want to demonstrate for the Marikana shootings in Tanzania."
nya: "Iwo analemba ma uthenga pa mapepala akuluakulu, amene pa zooneka zomwe zomwe anajambula anati, 'lekani kupha anthu athu', iwo anatero. Ndikuona ngati munali munthu wachitetezo cha boma mu msonkhanowo yemwe anaona mauthengawo ndikuwamasulira ngati kuti panali dongosolo lochita zionetsero. Koma mukaona bwinobwino palibe ubale wina uliwonse woonetsa kuti amafuna kuchita zionetsero chifukwa cha kuombera kwa a Marikana ku Tanzania.
mt0: <pad> "They wrote messages on large posters, which in the video said, "Stop killing our people," they said. I think there was a government security person at the meeting who saw the messages and interpreted them as a plan for protests. But if you look closely there is no other connection that suggests they are planning to protest the shooting of Marikana in Tanzania."</s>

en: It's not clear if anyone was actually arrested. Other rights groups say that some foreign campaigners were arrested, but not interrogated.
nya: Sizikudziwika bwino ngati panali amene anamangidwa. Magulu ena a zaufulu anati koma anthu amaiko ena omwe anachita nawo zionetserozo anamangidwa koma sanafunsidwe kalikonse.
mt0: <pad> It is not clear whether anyone was arrested. Some human rights groups said that some international protesters were arrested but not questioned.</s>

en: 'Afraid, insecure'
nya: Amantha, osatetezeka'
mt0: <pad> Very quiet, safe.</s>

en: Eden says she was summoned by authorities as she went to the police station Friday night to meet with a local coordinator and then was let go with a warning. Police later went to delegates' hotel rooms looking for materials that they thought were a security threat. They found nothing, she said.
nya: A Eden anati anaitaniidwa ndi akuluakulu pamene anapita ku polisi lachisanu kukakumana ndi oyan'ganila a muderalo ndipo iwo anasiidwa atawapatsa chenjezo. Kenako apolisi anapita kumalo ogona  nthumwizo kukayang'ana zida zomwe amayesa kuti zinali za chiopsezo. iwo sanapeze chilichonse, anatero.
mt0: <pad> Eden said he was called to the police station on Friday to meet with the officers who were being held and then they went to the refugee's hotel to inspect what they thought was a potentially dangerous device. They didn't find anything, she said.</s>

en: Janet Zhou, director of the Zimbabwe Coalition on Debt and Development, was one of the campaigners questioned by security forces at her hotel.
nya: A janet Zhou mkulu wa bungwe loona za mgwirizano wa ngongole ndi chitukuko lotchedwa Zimbabwe Coalition on Debt and Development, anali mmodzi wa anthu amene anafunsidwa mafunso ndi a chitetezo ku malo ogona wo.
mt0: <pad> Janet Zhou, the director of the Zimbabwe Coalition on Debt and Development, was one of the people questioned by security guards at the hotel.</s>

en: "I was afraid, I was insecure, I was traumatized to say the least," she told VOA, after returning home to Harare. "Because seven security details coming over after midnight and questioning me about a demonstration and placards that I wasn't going to be able to give them, was something else. I didn't understand it. It left me really terrified."
nya: "Ndinali ndi mantha, ndinali osatetezedwa, Ndinadzidzimutsidwa kungokambapo zochepa," iwo anauza wailesi ya VOA atabwelera kwao ku Harare. "patatha pakati pausiku achitetezo asanu ndi awiri anabwera kumadzandifunsa zokhudza zionetsero ndi mapepala olembedwa, zomwe sindikanatha kuwapatsa, zinali zinazake. Sindinazimvetsetse. Zinandisiya ndi mantha."
mt0: <pad> "I was afraid, I was unsafe, I was told to speak only a little," she told the VOA after returning to Harare.</s>

en: She said police then told her — and her 40-person delegation — to remain in their hotel all day Saturday. She asked them if they were under arrest, to which they did not reply.
nya: Apolisi akuti anawauza iwo ndi nthumwi zina makumi anayi kuti akhale mmalo awo ogona tsiku lonse la loweruka. Iwo anawafunsa ngati anali atamangidwa koma sanawayankhe.
mt0: <pad> Police said they were told to stay at their hotel room all day Saturday. They asked if they were arrested but they didn't answer.</s>

en: 'Perfectly valid'
nya: "Zomveka bwino."
mt0: <pad> "That sounds good."</s>

en: Oryem Nyeko, a Kampala-based researcher for Human Rights Watch, noted that Tanzanian police didn't do anything technically illegal. But, he said, that doesn't make it right, either.
nya: A Oryem Nyeko ofufuza nkhani za ufulu wa athu a  ku Kampala, anazindikira kuti apolisi a ku Tanzania sanachitepo chilichonse chophwanya malamulo. Koma iwo anati sikuti izi zochita zolondola.
mt0: <pad> Oryem Nyeko, a Kampala human rights investigator, recognized that Tanzanian police had not done anything wrong. But they said it was not right.</s>

en: "I think it's a perfectly valid thing for police to do," he said. "However, the challenge with that is that it speaks to a wider problem in Tanzania as far as a closing civic space and the opportunities that people in civic society have to freely express themselves. This is part of a wider pattern of civic repression in the country."
nya: "Ndikuganiza kuti ndichinthu choyenera kuti apolisi achite," iwo anatero. " Koma chophinja ndichoti zikudzetsa vuto lalikulu ku Tanzania pothetsa  malo ndi mwayi wa anthu osagwila ntchito m'boma pamene  akuyenera kumasuka kudzifotokoza. Iyi ndi mbali imodzi yobweretsa kupondeleza anthu mudziko.
mt0: <pad> "I think it's something that the police should do," they said. "But the difference is that it's creating a major problem in Tanzania by breaking the rights and opportunities of the unemployed when they have to be free to express themselves. This is part of the growing political repression in the country."</s>

en: International groups like the Committee to Protect Journalists have also warned of increased repression. Ahead of the SADC summit, the watchdog group noted its concerns about a "deeply troubling erosion of press freedom," and of "attacks on individual journalists, media suspensions, internet shutdowns, and restrictive legislation."
nya: Magulu apadziko lonse monga gulu loteteza atolankhani lachenjezanso kuchuluka kwa kupondeleza. Pa msonkhano waukulu wa SADC gulu la oyang'anira linazindikila  madandaulo a kusokonekela kwa ufulu wa nyumba zofalitsa nkhani komanso kuukira atolankhani, kuimitsa  njira zofalitsa nkhani, kutseka intaneti ndi kuletsa kulembetsa.
mt0: <pad> Global organizations such as the Reporters Without Borders have also warned of the increased intrusion. At the SADC general assembly the monitors highlighted complaints about violation of press freedom and journalistic attacks, closure of media channels, blocking of the internet and ban on registration.</s>

en: The CPJ made special mention of Tanzanian journalists Azory Gwanda, who has been missing since 2017, and Erick Kabendera, who was arrested last month and charged with economic crimes, which the organization says is in retaliation for his critical journalism.
nya: A CPJ anatchula mwapadera mtolankhani wa ku Tanzania a Azory Gwanda, amene anasowa kuchokera mu chaka cha 2017 ndi a Erick kabendera amene anamangidwa mwezi watha pozengedwa mlandu wokhudza ndalama zomwe bungwelo linati zikugwirizana ndi utolankhani wawo otsutsa.
mt0: <pad> CPJ named specifically Tanzanian journalist Azory Gwanda, who has been missing since 2017 and Erick Kabendera, who was arrested last month in connection with money-related allegations the CPJ said were linked to their critical press.</s>

en: Kabendera remains behind bars. On Monday, Eden, his lawyer, said the court decided to adjourn to give prosecutors more time to investigate. That will keep him in jail for more than a week longer, until Aug. 30.
nya: A Kambendera adakali kundende. Lolemba, a Eden woimila milandu wawo, anati a khoti apanga chiganizo chosuntha tsiku lawo lokaonekera ku khoti kuti awapatse ozenga mlanduwo nthawi yofufuza. Izi ziwasungabe mu ndende kupitilira sabata imodzi mpaka pa 30 Ogasiti.
mt0: <pad> Kambanda is still in prison. On Monday, the lawyer for them, Mr Eden, said the court decided to postpone their hearing to give the prosecutors time to investigate. This will keep them in prison for a week until August 30.</s>

en: 'Worrying trend'
nya: "Kuda nkhawa kosefukila".
mt0: <pad> "More than a hidden fear."</s>

en: Anna Henga, director of the Legal and Human Rights Center, said police actions only further a worrying trend in Tanzania under President John Magafuli, whom critics say is becoming increasingly authoritarian.
nya: A Anna Henga mkulu wa  bungwe la malamulo ndi ufulu wa anthu lotchedwa Legal and Human Rights Center, anati zomwe apolisi akuchita zikubweretsabe kudandaula ku Tanzania pansi pa mtsogoleri wawo a John Magufuli, pamene kutsutsana kukuchulukira.
mt0: <pad> Anna Henga, the head of the Legal and Human Rights Center, said the police's action is still causing concern in Tanzania under President John Magufuli, as protests are growing.</s>

en: "This means the continuation of a limited civic space. Because this has happened since 2016. There are a lot of issues, there is a negative development toward limited civic space. And it is targeted to people like civil society organizations, the media, hindering the freedom of speech, the freedom of association."
nya: Izi zikutanthauza kuti zipitiliza kuchepetsa malo oti anthu angamasukilepo. Chifukwa izi zinachitika mu chaka cha 2016. Pali nkhani zambiri, pali chitukuko chosakhala bwino ku malo a anthu osagwira ntchito m'boma. Ndipo ndi cholunjika kwa anthu ngati mabungwe oti siaboma, ofalitsa nkhani, kupondeleza ufulu wa kayankhulidwe komanso ufulu wa mgwirizano.
mt0: <pad> This means that they will continue to restrict access. Because this happened in 2016. There are many problems, there are bad developments in non-governmental spaces. And it is directed at people like non-governmental organizations, journalists, violating the right to free speech and the right to union.</s>

en: Few Demonstrators Turn Up for Zimbabwe Protest in Bulawayo
nya: Ochita zionetsero ochepa anaonekera ku Bulawayo mu dziko la Zimbabwe
mt0: <pad> A small number of protesters appeared in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe.</s>

en: Few people have turned up for an opposition protest in Bulawayo, Zimbabwe's second city, on Monday as armed police maintained heavy presence on the streets and at a courthouse where the opposition is pressing to be allowed to hold the demonstration.
nya: Anthu ochepa anaonekera ku zionetsero zotsutsa boma ku Bulawayo mzinda wachiwiri waukulu ku Zimbabwe pamene apolisi ndi zida zawo anazungulira mmisewu ndi kukhoti komwe otsutsa boma makakamila kuti aloledwe kuchita zionetsero.
mt0: <pad> Zimbabwe's second-largest city Bulawayo saw a small number of people attend a protest in the capital, while police and their armed force surrounded the streets and court where opposition activists had fought for permission to hold a protest.</s>

en: Business in Bulawayo's usually bustling downtown was subdued with the most traffic from police trucks, water cannons and dozens of police officers patrolling on foot.
nya: Malonda omwe amakhala pikiripikiri ku tawuni ya Bulawayo analephereka chifukwa cha kuchuluka kwa magalimoto a a polisi, mizinga ya madzi ndi apolisi ochuluka amene amayenda pansi.
mt0: <pad> The usual bustling trade in Bulawayo was hampered by the number of police cars, water cannons and the many on-foot policemen.</s>

en: The opposition party, the Movement for Democratic Change, had called the protest as part of a planned series of demonstrations to push President Emmerson Mnangagwa to agree to a transitional government amid a rapidly deteriorating economy and rising political tensions.
nya: A chipani chotsutsa a Movement for Democratic Change anaitanitsa zionetserozo ngati njira yowakakamiza a Emmerson Mnangagwa, mtsogoleri wa dzikolo kuti avomere  kusintha  boma pakati pa mavuto a zachuma ndi kusagwilizana mu ndale.
mt0: <pad> The opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) party organized the protests as a way to pressure President Emmerson Mnangagwa, to agree to a government change amid economic and political unrest.</s>

en: But the police banned the protest in the southern city, citing security concerns. A Bulawayo magistrate is hearing the opposition party's challenge to the ban.
nya: Koma apolisiwo analetsa zionetserozo kummwera kwa mzindawo kamba ka nkhani ya chitetezo. Oweruza milandu ku Bulawayo akumvetsera kutsutsa kwaa mbali yotsutsa boma pa zionetserozi.
mt0: <pad> But police blocked protests in the south of the city because of security concerns. A court in Bulawayo is hearing the opposition's complaint about the protests.</s>

en: The protest was planned as a follow up to demonstrations held in the capital, Harare, on Friday when several hundred demonstrators marched in defiance of a police ban that was upheld by the High Court. Police used tear gas and beatings with batons to quell the Harare protest.
nya: Zionetserozi zinakonzedwa potsatira zionetsero zomwe zinachitika mu mzinda wa Harare lachisanu pamene anthu 700  anaguba ngakhale sanamvere kuletsedwa ndi apolisi komwe kunalengezedwa ku khoti lalikulu. Apolisi anagwiritsa ntchito utsi wotulutsa misozi, kumenya ndi ndodo kuti athetse zionetserozo.
mt0: <pad> The protests were organized after a large crowd of people broke into the capital city of Harare on Friday when 700 people gathered despite a police ban announced by the high court. Police used tear gas, beating and stones to break up the protests.</s>

en: Zimbabweans Claim Police Brutality During Economic Protests
nya: Anthu a ku Zimbabwe akamba za nkhanza za apolisi mu nthawi ya zionetsero zokhudza chuma.
mt0: <pad> Zimbabweans complained about police brutality during economic protests.</s>

en: Zimbabweans defied a police ban Friday and held demonstrations to protest the country's deteriorating economy.
nya: Anthu a ku Zimbabwe sanagwirizane ndi kuletsedwa kuchita zionetsero ndi apolisi Lachisanu, ndipo iwo anakachita zionetserozi zokhudza  kuwonongeka kwa chuma cha mu dzikolo.
mt0: <pad> Zimbabweans did not agree with the police ban on protests on Friday, and they held their protests about the country's economic losses.</s>

en: Despite the High Court ban on planned protests, members of the Movement for Democratic Change took to the streets and clashed with police. Some of the injured accused police of derailing protests, which they said were meant to persuade President Emmerson Mnangagwa's government to breathe life into Zimbabwe's moribund economy.
